'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rigs dge ba rin po che'i 'byung gnas su gyur pa la shin tu byung ba'o/ /chos nyid kyi rnam pa thams cad du khyad par yod pa dang / khyad par med pa'i spyod pas rnam par dag pa'i rgyan gyi ye shes skye ba thams cad kyi nang du gtogs pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs bsgribs pa med pa'i rgyud rnam par dag pas 'jig rten gyi mi snyan pa thams cad kyis mi snyan pa brjod du med pa ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi rigs dang rgyud rnam par dag pa'i rgyan mchog dam pa bla na med pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni byams pa chen po'i mthu dang / rang bzhin gyi rgyan mnga' ba ste/ shin tu dang ba yongs su rtog pa'i rnyog pa mi mnga' ba sku'i 'phrin las yongs su gsal ba/ blta bas mi skyo ba/ thugs shin tu rnam par gsal ba/ thugs rje chen po mnga' ba/ 'gro ba thams cad skyo ba pa yon gyi gnas kyi dam pa/ bla na med pa yongs su 'dzin pa'i nang na thugs brtse ba can phan par mdzad pa/ sems can thams cad kyi don du ye shes chen po byin gyis brlabs te/ bsod nams chen pos yongs su 'phags pa/ 'gro ba thams cad kyi bsod nams kyi zhing du gyur pa/ sems can rnams kyi yon tan dang / ye shes kyi phung po thams cad rnam par 'phel bar mdzad pa ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi byams pa chen po dang / thugs rje chen po'i mthar thug pa'i bsod nams kyi rgyan mchog dam pa bla na med pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po de dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi rgyan mchog dam pa bla na med pa'o/ /

“Buddhas have ten kinds of supreme adornment. What are they? All buddhas have all the marks and refinements of greatness—this is the first, buddhas’ supreme physical adornment. All buddhas have sixty kinds of vocal sound, each with five hundred elements, each element with countless hundreds of thousands of pure, clear tones adorning it, and they are able, in the midst of all groups in the cosmos, without any qualms or fears, to roar the great lion’s roar, expounding the meaning of the extremely profound teaching of the enlightened, so that all who hear are delighted and are edified according to their faculties and inclinations—this is the second, buddhas’ supreme adornment of speech. All buddhas are endowed with the ten powers, the great concentrations, and the eighteen unique qualities, adorning their mental activity; in their sphere of operation, they comprehend and master all enlightening principles without obstruction, and all attain the adornments of the all-inclusive cosmos of reality as their adornment; they are able to clearly perceive in a single instant the mental patterns, past, present, and future, each different, of the beings of the cosmos—this is the third, the supreme mental adornment of buddhas. All buddhas are able to emanate countless beams of light, each beam of light accompanied by untold webs of light, illumining all buddha-lands, destroying the darkness in all worlds, revealing the emergence of innumerable buddhas, their bodies equal, all pure, their buddha-works all effective, able to cause sentient beings to reach nonregression—this is the fourth, buddhas’ supreme adornment of light. When the buddhas smile, zillions of rays of light radiate from their faces, each light having innumerable, inconceivably many hues of all kinds, lighting up all the worlds in the ten directions; among the masses they utter truthful words, giving innumerable, countless, inconceivably many sentient beings directions for supreme complete perfect enlightenment—this is the fifth, buddhas’ supreme adornment of a smile, free from the delusion and confusion of the world. All buddhas have the reality-body, pure, unobstructed, with ultimate comprehension of all truths, abiding in the cosmos of reality, without bounds, though being in the world, not getting mixed up in the world, understanding the true nature of the world, acting on transmundane principles, beyond the power of speech, transcending the realms of matter and sense—this is the sixth, the buddhas’ supreme adornment of the reality-body. All buddhas have infinite constant subtle lights with untold colors of all kinds adorning them, forming a treasury of light producing infinite orbs of light illuminating the ten directions without obstruction—this is the seventh, buddhas’ supreme adornment of constant subtle light. All buddhas have boundless sublime forms, delightful sublime forms, pure sublime forms, sublime forms that appear in accordance with the mind, forms that outshine all in the realms of desire, form, and formlessness, unexcelled sublime forms arriving at the other shore—this is the eighth, buddhas’ supreme adornment of sublime forms. All buddhas are born in the family of the buddhas of past, present, and future, accumulate myriad treasures of virtue, ultimately pure, without fault, impeccable, being adorned by the most pure, refined acts among all things, fully accomplishing total knowledge and character beyond reproach—this is the ninth, buddhas’ supreme adornment of human character. All buddhas array themselves with the power of great compassion, ultimately pure, without any cravings, their physical actions forever at rest, their minds well liberated, so that none tire of seeing them, saving all worldly beings, the foremost fields of blessing, the most worthy recipients, mercifully helping all sentient beings to develop stores of unlimited virtue and knowledge—this is the tenth, buddhas’ supreme adornment of the qualities of great kindness and compassion.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po 'di dag ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos rnams te/ bcu gang zhe na/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos thams cad la mnga' ba dang / chos thams cad la snang bar mdzad pa'i mnga' bsgyur bas/ tshig dang yi ge mtha' yas pa la thogs pa mi mnga' ba'i spobs pa mnga' ba dang / chos thams cad ma lus par yongs su brjod pas mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos dang po'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can ji ltar yongs su smin pa dang / smon lam ji ltar btab pa'i tshul bzhin du 'dul ba la thogs pa mi mnga' bas mnga' che ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' ba sgyur ba'i chos gnyis pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad sems can gcig la'ang gnod pa med par rnam pa drug tu rab tu bskyod pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams rgyan rnam par bkod pa grangs med tshad med pa dang ldan pa/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa thams cad gcig nas gcig tu 'phang ba dang / gcig nas gcig tu gzhug pa dang / gcig nas gcig tu bsdu ba dang / gcig nas gcig tu bsre bas 'jig rten gyi khams gzhan dang / gzhan dag gzhan dang gzhan gyi phyogs su rab tu bzhag kyang / sems can gyi khams rnams 'khor zhing rmongs par mi 'gyur la the tshom du mi 'gyur bar mdzad pas mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos gsum pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad byin gyis rlob pa'i ye shes kyis 'jig rten gyi khams kyi rgyan phan tshun du byin gyis brlab pa dang / thugs skad cig gis 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rgyan yang dag par bstan pa dang / bskal pa grangs med par brjod kyang yi ge shin tu bstan pa zad mi shes pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad rgyan thams cad kyis rnam par brgyan pa dang / mi mthun pa med cing nye bar nyon mongs pa med pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi zhing gcig tu yongs su 'du bar sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnam par dag pa thams cad byin gyis brlab pa la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos bzhi pa'o; ;sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sangs rgyas kyis 'dul ba'i sems can gzigs na sems can gcig gi don du bskal pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med par skyil mo krung gcig gis bzhugs na yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la mi bde ba mi mnga' zhing thugs la mi bde ba mi mnga' ste/ gang zag de yang mi bsnyel bas 'dul ba'i dus las mi 'da' ba dang / gang zag gcig la ji lta ba de bzhin du rim pa rim pas 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i sku tshe la mnga' bar byin gyis brlabs te bzhugs kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams la skyo ba mi mnga' ba ste/ de ltar sems can gyi khams thams cad mthar gyis rim pas/ sangs rgyas kyis 'dul ba'i gang zag gi don du yongs su skyong ba mdzad pa la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos lnga pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni/ 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du yang dag par gzhol ba'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i bzhud pas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du bzhud pa la thag thogs mi mnga' ba dang / phyogs bcu'i chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad kyi 'jig rten gyi khams kyi rgyud rgya mtsho 'byams klas pa dang / phyogs kyi dra ba'i rgyud thams cad du thugs skad cig gcig dang ldan pas bzhud par byin gyis rlob cing chos kyi dbyings shin tu bstan pa khong du chud par bya bas/ chos kyi 'khor lo thogs pa med pa rab tu bskor ba la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos drug pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'dul ba'i sems can gyi khams thams cad kyi don du thugs skad cig re re la bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya bar mnga' che ba ste/ de la chos thams cad mngon par sangs rgyas pa gang yang med la/ gang gis mngon par sangs rgyas pa'ang med de/ mngon par 'tshang rgya bar 'gyur ba med kyang / slob pa'i sa la gnas shing mngon par 'tshang rgya bar yang mi brjod pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad kyang bsgribs pa med par rtogs par thugs su chud pas sems can thams cad 'dul ba'i don du ye shes tshad med pa'i tshul gyis / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa chen po'i yul yongs su rgyun mi gcod pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos bdun pa'o/ /

“Buddhas have ten kinds of mastery. What are they? All buddhas have command of all the teachings, clearly comprehend all kinds of bodies of expression and nuance, and explain all things with unhindered intellect—this is the first mastery of buddhas. All buddhas teach sentient beings without ever missing the appropriate timing, endlessly explaining the right teaching to them in accord with their states of mind, causing them all to become receptive to truth—this is the second mastery of buddhas. All buddhas are able to cause all worlds throughout space, arrayed in countless different ways, to quake in six ways, causing those worlds to rise or fall, to expand or contract, to combine or dissolve, without ever harming a single living being, the creatures in those worlds being unaware, not cognizant of this happening, not even suspecting it—this is the third mastery of buddhas. All buddhas are able to beautify and purify all worlds by means of spiritual powers, in the space of an instant manifesting the adornments of all worlds, these adornments beyond recounting even in countless eons, all free from defilement, incomparably pure; all the adornments and purities of all buddha-fields they cause to equally enter one field—this is the fourth mastery of buddhas. All buddhas, seeing a single sentient being capable of being taught, extend their lives indefinitely for that being, sitting without fatigue of body or mind, concentrating single-mindedly on that being, without ever becoming heedless or forgetful, guiding that being by appropriate means, with appropriate timing, and also do the same for all living beings as they do for one—this is the fifth mastery of buddhas. All buddhas can go to all worlds, to the realms of action of all enlightened ones, without ever leaving behind any phenomenal realms, the ten directions each different, there being in each direction incalculable oceans of worlds, there being in each ocean of worlds incalculable world systems; by spiritual powers buddhas reach all of them in a single instant, and turn the wheel of the unobstructed pure Teaching—this is the sixth mastery of buddhas. All buddhas, in order to civilize all sentient beings, attain unexcelled complete perfect enlightenment in each mental instant, yet in regard to all elements of buddhahood, they have not already cognized them, do not cognize them, and are not yet to cognize them, and also do not dwell in the stage of learning, yet they know them all, see them all, mastering them without hindrance; with immeasurable knowledge and freedom they teach and tame all sentient beings—this is buddhas’ seventh mastery.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das ni spyan gyi skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de snyan gyi skye mched kyis yongs su grub par mdzad do/ /snyan gyi skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de shangs kyi skye mched kyis yongs su grub par mdzad do/ /shangs kyi skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de ljags kyi skye mched kyis yongs su grub par mdzad do/ /ljags kyi skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de ni sku'i skye mched kyis yongs su grub par mdzad do/ /sku'i skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de thugs kyi skye mched kyis yongs su grub par mdzad do/ /thugs kyi skye mched kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gang bsgrub pa de 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad kyi dmigs pa 'jig rten pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa sna tshogs rnam par phye ba thams cad du grub par mdzad do/ /de bzhin du dmigs pa thams cad re re yang snrel zhing bsgrub pas; sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las bsgrub pa la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos brgyad pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni rang gi sku'i ba spu'i bu ga gcig gi nang du sems can gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad gzud par mdzad cing khongs su chud bar mdzad pa dang / sems can re re zhing yang lus sangs rgyas kyi zhing brjod du med pa tsam du yangs par mdzad kyang / sems can de dag la gnod pa dang / mi bde bar mi 'gyur ba dang; de dag du yang sems can re re zhing 'jig rten gyi khams gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pas bskal pa grangs med pa zad par gnas par bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med par gom pa gcig gis phyin pas 'jig rten gyi khams de dag tu sangs rgyas byung ba rnams kyi spyan sngar 'gro bar bya ba dang / sangs rgyas de dag byung ba'i tshe yang brjod du med pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi rgyud dang gling de dag na sems can gyi gtso bos brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar bya ba dang / ba spu'i bu ga de nas sangs rgyas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa 'byung bar bya ba dang / sems can gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa 'byung bar bya ba dang / chos kyi 'khor lo gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa bskor bar bya ba dang / chos kyi dbyings bstan pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa shin tu bstan par bya ba dang / 'das pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa dang / ma 'ongs pa gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa dang / da ltar byung ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa brjod du med pa yongs su brjod par bya ba dang / nam mkha'i dbyings mtha' dang dbus med par bstan pa kun tu mtshams med par sems can thams cad 'ong zhing 'gro ba dang / skye ba'i skye mched thams cad du 'dod pa'i longs spyod rgya chen po bgegs med pa thams cad 'byung bar bya ba la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' sgyur ba'i chos dgu pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad du pad+mo'i rgyan chen pos brgyan pa'i seng+ge'i khri pad+mo'i snying po can la de bzhin gshegs pa gcig gi chos kyi dbyings tshad med pa thams cad du khyab pa'i skus byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas te sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa thams cad yongs su bstan pa mdzad pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa gcig gi ji lta bar 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi sems can gyi gtso bo thams cad kyang de bzhin du dgongs pa skad cig ma re re'i byin gyis rlabs kyis brlabs pa dang / dgongs pa skad cig la ji lta ba bzhin du dgongs pa skad cig thams cad la'ang pad+mo'i rgyud kyis yongs su dag par mngon par 'tshang rgya bar bya ba dang / de bzhin du chos kyi dbyings thams cad ma lus pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing brjod du med pa rnam par dag pa rgyan sna tshogs dang ldan pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams su dmigs pa rnam pa sna tshogs dang ldan pa'i zhing rnam par dag pa 'byams klas pa brjod du med pa mtshan nyid tha dad pa rnam pa tha dad pa'i rgyud tshad med cing 'byams klas pa dus kyi rgyud grangs med pa dang ldan pa/ bstan pa ma 'dres pa dang ldan pa/ blo tshad med pa dang / mos pa shin tu yangs pa dang ldan pa/ mtshan nyid sna tshogs kyi gnas med pa/ mtshan nyid bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang ldan pa/ tshad med pa thams cad dgongs pa skad cig ma las dgongs pa skad cig ma gcig gis thams cad yongs su bstan kyang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ched du sgrub pa mi mdzad pa la mnga' che ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos bcu pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po de dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi mnga' chen pos mnga' bsgyur ba'i chos so/ /

All buddhas can do the buddha-work of the ears with their eyes, can do the buddha-work of the nose with the ears, can do the buddha-work of the tongue with the nose, can do the buddha-work of the body with the tongue, can do the buddha-work of the mind with the body, and with the mind can sojourn in all kinds of realms, mundane and transcendental, in all worlds, able to perform immeasurable great buddha-works in each realm—this is buddhas’ eighth mastery. All buddhas can contain all sentient beings in each pore of their bodies, each sentient being’s body equal to untold buddha-lands, yet there is no crowding; each sentient being can pass countless worlds with every step and go on for countless eons, seeing all the buddhas emerging in the world and edifying beings, turning the wheel of the pure Teaching, showing untold phenomena of past, future, and present, the embodiments of sentient beings in various realms of existence throughout space, their comings and goings and deportment, their needs all fully supplied, yet without any obstruction therein—this is buddhas’ ninth mastery. All buddhas, in the space of an instant, manifest as many buddhas as atoms in all worlds, each buddha attaining enlightenment in all universes, sitting on a lotus lion throne in a world of vast arrays of exquisite lotus blossoms, showing the miraculous powers of buddhas, and as in the world of vast arrays of exquisite lotus blossoms, so in untold worlds in all universes, variously arrayed, with various realms of objects, various shapes and forms, various manifestations, various numbers of ages, and as in one instant so in each instant of immeasurable, boundless, incalculable eons, all appearing in one instant, with infinite abodes in one instant, yet without using the slightest power of expedient means—this is buddhas’ tenth mastery.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po 'di dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su rdzogs pa tshad med pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnams te/ bcu gang zhe na/ mtshan re re zhing bsod nams brgya pa'i mtshan yongs su dag par 'gyur ba 'di ni yongs su rdzogs pa dang po ste/ des sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos rnams yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /yon tan thams cad kyi 'byung gnas phun sum tshogs pa'i spyod pa yongs su dag pa yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /sems can yongs su smin par bya ba dang / 'dul ba yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /sangs rgyas kyi mnga' 'gro ba thams cad kyis zil gyis gnon pa yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /zhing yongs su dag par bya ba yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /mtshan dang dpe byad bzang po dang / gzugs kyi sku blta na don yod par yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya'o/ /de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad dang mnyam pa nyid yongs su rdzogs pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya ste/ sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las thams cad yongs su rdzogs par mdzad nas/ yongs su mya ngan las 'da'o// kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po de dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi chos yongs su rdzogs pa tshad med pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa'o/ /

“Buddhas have ten kinds of measureless, inconceivable ways of fulfillment of buddhahood. What are they? The pure features of all buddhas each contain a hundred blessings. All buddhas accomplish all Buddha teachings. All buddhas perfect all roots of goodness. All buddhas perfect all virtuous qualities. All buddhas can teach all sentient beings. All buddhas can be leaders of sentient beings. All buddhas perfect pure buddha-lands. All buddhas achieve omniscient knowledge. All buddhas develop the physical marks and refinements of greatness; all who see them benefit, this effort is not in vain. All buddhas are imbued with the impartial reality of enlightened ones. All buddhas, after having done their buddha-work, manifest entry into nirvana.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po 'di dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi thabs mkhas pa ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos thams cad byin gyis brlabs pa med cing spros pa thams cad med par yang thugs su chud la/ dge ba'i sgo nas sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyang shin tu ston cing brjod de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa dang po'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos thams cad la gzigs pa med cing phan tshun du mkhyen pa med do/ /ma bcings ma gol ba dang / gzung ba med cing bsags pa med de/ yongs su rdzogs pa med par yang thugs su chud la sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la mnga' dam pa yang brnyes te/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams chos thams cad la mnga' bsgyur ba de yang yang dag pa de kho na nyid ma nor ba rnam pa gzhan du mi 'gyur ba dang / chos thams cad bdag gi med cing yongs su 'dzin pa med la de kho na nyid kyi mtha' las rnam par mi 'da' yang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni mnga' chen pos chos kyi dbyings thams cad snang ba la'ang rab tu mkhyen pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa gnyis pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni mtshan ma'i mtha' thams cad mi mnga' ste/ mtshan ma thams cad dang mi 'grogs shing / mtshan ma'i mngon par shes pa thams cad dang ma 'dres la/ de'i rang bzhin du ngo bo nyid med pa dang / ji ltar ngo bo nyid med pa'i sgra'i tshul thams cad thugs su chud kyang gzugs kyi mtshan ma'i sku gzugs rnam par dag pa grangs med pa dang / zhing gi mtshan ma dang / rnam par spyod pa'i mtshan ma zad mi shes pa rnam pa sna tshogs yang dag par bstan cing bshad pa'i ye shes kyi phung po mun pa med pa 'gro ba thams cad kyi sgron ma chen por gyur pas mun pa med pa'i snang ba ston pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa gsum pa'o/ /chags pa med pa'i mtha' ni sngon gyi mtha' yang ma yin/ phyi ma'i mtha' yang ma yin/ da ltar byung ba yang ma yin te/ chos kyi dbyings su gnas pa ni 'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba yang ma yin pas/ de bzhin nyid kyi mtshan nyid kyis 'byung ba med kyang sangs rgyas 'byung ba rnams kyi rigs tshad med pa'i phyir shin tu bstan pa brjod du med pas 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas pa skye ba yang rab tu brjod cing kun tu gzigs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi yul gyis de bzhin du gzigs pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa bzhi pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sku'i 'phrin las dang / gsung gi 'phrin las dang / thugs kyi 'phrin las kyi mngon par 'du mdzad pa yang mi mnga' la yongs su blang ba mi mnga' bas bzhugs shing rnam par phye ba med pa'i mthar thug pa ste/ dor ba med pa'i chos kyi gnas kyi pha rol tu phyin la bgrang ba'i tshul las rnam par 'das kyang tshul grangs med pa'i mdzod du gyur cing; bgrang ba dang mngon par sgrub pa mtha' yas pa dang / 'jig rten pa dang 'jig rten las 'das pa rnam pa sna tshogs tha dad pa'i grangs kyi tshul thugs su chud pa ye shes bsgrigs pa med pas gzigs pa rnams te/ chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad kyi sems can gdul ba rnam par dmigs pa la rdzu 'phrul sna tshogs tshad med mu med par mngon par sgrub pa mdzad pa 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa lnga pa'o/ /chos thams cad lta ba med pas tha mi dad pa dang / bye brag med pa dang / 'byung ba med pa dang / mtshan nyid med pa dang / sna tshogs med pa dang / blang ba med pa dang / dor ba med pa dang / rang bzhin med par rab tu mkhyen kyang chos kyi rgyud shin tu nges par yang dag par sgrub cing 'jig rten gyi tshul dang 'gal ba med pa dang / rang bzhin med pa yang yang dag par gzigs pas thams cad mkhyen pa/ thams cad gzigs pa/ mkhyen par bya ba thams cad ma lus par gzigs pas chos la mnga' bsgyur ba thams cad kyang rab tu ston la/ de bzhin nyid kyi rang bzhin las kyang mi nyams pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa drug pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni thugs su chud pa'i rnam pa gcig gis gzhan dang gzhan mkhyen par bya ba/ chos de'i skyon med pa las rnam par ma 'das pa gnas pa med pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par dag pa mnyam pa nyid kyi chos skyon med pas dus thams cad du gnas pa rab tu mkhyen te/ de la yang nyi ma gcig gam/ zla ba phyed dam/ lo gcig gam/ lo brg+ya'am/ bskal pa 'jig pa dang / 'du bas rjes su bsnyag pa dang / phyir phyogs pa mi mnga' bar dus tshad med pa dang / nyi ma gcig dang / yud tsam gcig gi dus dang / snga dro nas nyi ma phyed kyi dus dang / phyi dro nas snga dro'i dus dang / nyi ma gung nas phyi dro'i dus dang / nyi ma 'grangs pa'i dus dang / nyi ma bdun dang / zla ba phyed kyi dus dang; zla ba dang / lo dang / lo brgya'i dus dang / bskal pa gcig gi dus dang / tshad med grangs med pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i dus nas/ phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i dus su chos bstan pa dang / chos kyi 'khor lo thogs pa med cing phyir mi ldog /rgyun chad par mi 'gyur/ bral bar mi 'gyur/ bar chad par mi 'gyur/ med par mi 'gyur/ 'jig par mi 'gyur/ g.yo bar mi 'gyur/ ring du mi 'gyur/ 'khor de na gnas pa nyid du yang rgyun chad par mi 'gyur te/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa bdun pa'o; ;sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad du rtag tu dus la bab par bzhugs pa ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni mi 'jigs pa tshad med pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa grangs med pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa tshad med pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa zad mi shes pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa thogs pa med pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa mtha' yas pa mnga' ba'o/ /thun mong ma yin pa'i tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa mthar thug pa med pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa de kho na dang ldan pa mnga' ba'o/ /tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa tshig gi tshul thams cad rab tu rtogs pa mnga' ba'o/ /chos thams cad tha dad pa yang dag par mkhyen pa mnga' ba'o/ /bsam pa dang / mos pa dang / dbang po ji lta ba bzhin du chos kyi tshul dang / rnam grangs tshul ji ltar rnam par bkod pa bzhin dus mtshams med par ston te/ mdo sde bye ba khrag khrig brjod du med pa'i yang brjod pa med pa rnams mdo sde de dang de la thog ma dang / tha ma dang / dbus kyi tshul gyis yang dag par ston te/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa brgyad pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni ming med kyang / ming dang rigs su byung ba'i chos thams cad tshig dang / yi ges shin tu dbyangs pa'i dbyings mngon par sangs rgyas pa ste/ ming 'das pa ma yin pa dang / ming ma 'ongs pa ma yin pa dang / ming da ltar byung ba ma yin pa dang / ming sems can ma yin pa dang / ming zhing ma yin pa dang / ming chos ma yin pa dang / ming yon tan ma yin pa dang / ming byang chub sems dpa' ma yin pa dang / ming sangs rgyas ma yin pa dang / ming grangs ma yin pa dang / ming grangs med pa ma yin pa dang / ming skye ba ma yin pa dang; ming 'gag pa ma yin pa dang / ming med pa ma yin pa dang / ming yod pa ma yin pa dang / ming gcig pa ma yin pa dang / ming tha dad pa ma yin pa dang; ming thams cad ma yin pa dang / chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis brjod du med pa dang / phyogs med pa dang / brda med pa dang / tshig gi lam med pa dang / sgra dang bral ba; sgra'i rnam pa thams cad mi 'byung ba yongs su bsgrubs pa med pa/ byas pa dang rnam par byas pa med pa/ rnam pa gcig ma yin pa/ rnam pa mang po ma yin pa yang thugs su chud la brjod pa dang / spyod pa thams cad la yang pha rol tu phyin pa'i mchog brnyes pa dag ste/ rnam par rtog pa'i yul mi mnga' ba dag go /mngon par 'du mdzad pa med pa la rab tu brtson pa dag go /rtog pa dang / kun tu rtog pa dang / yongs su rtog pa 'gag pa dag go /spyod pa thams cad la mi gnas par spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa dgu pa'o/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni chos thams cad kyi gzugs ma skyes pa rab tu mkhyen pa ste/ tshor ba'i spros pa med pa dang / 'du shes kyi grangs med pa dang / 'du byed kun tu rgyu ba med pa dang / rnam par shes pa nye bar len pa med pa dang / rang bzhin gyis zhi bar rab tu mkhyen te/ chos thams cad skye mched kyi rgyud med pa dang / khams rnams mi dmigs pa dang / chos thams cad mi 'jigs pa dang / chos thams cad bskyod du med cing rang bzhin gyis nam mkha' lta bu dang / chos thams cad dben pa dang / las med pa dang / rnam par smin pa med pa dang / spyod pas 'byung ba med pa dang / ma grub pa dang / ma byung ba dang / grangs kyis mi brjod pa dang / yod pa ma yin pa dang / med pa ma yin pa dang / ma skyes pa dang / ma 'gags pa dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa med pa dang / rnam par byang ba med pa dang / skyon med pa dang; gnas med pa dang / yongs su gnas pa med pa dang / yongs su smin par byas pa med pa dang / rnam par btul ba med pa dang / sems can med pa dang / sems can med pa ma yin pa dang / srog med pa dang / srog med pa ma yin pa dang / rkyen med pa dang / rkyen med pa ma yin pa dang / rten pa med pa dang / rten pa med pa ma yin par chos thams cad thugs su chud kyang chos kyi dbyings thams cad shin tu bstan pa la pha rol tu phyin pa'i dam pa brnyes pa dag ste/ nges pa dang / ma nges pa dang / log par nges pa'i phung po gsum rnam par dgod pa rnams la stobs bcus thugs su chud pa'i ye shes mi 'jigs pa bzhis rnam par dag pa'i sangs rgyas kyi yul chen po dang ldan pas seng ge'i sgra sgrog pa 'di ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa bcu pa ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po de dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi thabs mkhas pa'o/ /

“Buddhas have ten kinds of skill in means. What are they? All buddhas know all things are beyond idle philosophizing, yet can demonstrate the roots of goodness of all buddhas. All buddhas know all things have no vision and are unknown to each other, have no bondage or release, no reception or assembly, and no consummation, and independently ultimately reach the other shore; meanwhile they know the true reality of all things is unvarying, not different, and they attain freedom, selflessly, without grasping, not destroying ultimate truth; having already reached the state of great freedom, they always observe all realms of reality. All buddhas are forever aloof from all appearances; their minds do not dwell on anything, yet they know all appearances without confusion or error; while they know all appearances have no intrinsic nature of their own, yet they are able to perceive them all in accord with their essence and also manifest the infinite appearances of the various adornments of innumerable physical bodies and pure buddha-lands, gather lamps of knowledge and wisdom, and destroy the delusions of sentient beings. All buddhas abide in the realm of reality; they do not dwell in the past, future, or present, because in Thusness as such there are no marks of the three time frames of past, future, or present; yet they can speak about the emergence in the world of the innumerable buddhas of past, future, and present, causing those who hear to see the realms of all the buddhas. All buddhas, in their physical, verbal, and mental actions, do not create anything, have no coming or going, and no abiding; beyond all categories, they reach the other shore of all things, yet are treasuries of all truths, imbued with immeasurable knowledge, comprehending all kinds of mundane and transmundane things, their knowledge and wisdom unhindered, manifesting immeasurable autonomous spiritual powers, edifying the sentient beings of all realms. All buddhas know that all things cannot be seen, are neither one nor different, are neither finite nor infinite, are not coming or going, all being without inherent nature of their own, yet they do not contravene the phenomena of the world; the all-knowers see all things in the midst of nonexistence of own-being or inherent nature; being independent of things, they extensively explain things while always abiding steadily in the real nature of True Thusness. All buddhas know all times in one time; endowed with pure virtues, they enter the absolute state, yet without any attachment to it; in regard to time frames such as day, month, year, eon, becoming, and decomposition, they neither remain within them nor abandon them, yet they are able to show day or night, beginning, middle, and end, one day, one week, a fortnight, a month, a year, a century, an eon, many eons, inconceivable eons, inexpressible eons, as far as all the eons throughout the future, always turning the wheel of the sublime Teaching for the sake of sentient beings, without interruption, without retreating, without pause. All buddhas always remain in the realm of reality, develop the infinite fearlessness of the buddhas, as well as their countless, measureless, inexhaustible, ceaseless, boundless, unique, endless, and true intellectual powers, appropriately demonstrating explanation of all expressions and explanation of all principles, delivering untold millions of discourses using various doctrines adapted to faculties and natures, inclinations and understandings, all ultimately good in the beginning, the middle, and the end. All buddhas, abiding in the pure realm of reality, know all things originally have no names, there being no name of past, present, or future, no name of sentient beings, no name of inanimate beings, no name of country or land, no name of noncountry, no name of law or nonlaw, no name of virtue or nonvirtue, no name of enlightening being, no name of Buddha, no names of sets, no names of nonsets, no name of birth, no name of extinction, no name of existence, no name of nonexistence, no name of unity, no name of variety, because the essential nature of things is inexpressible—all things are without location or position, cannot be explained as assembling or dispersing, as one or as many, no verbalization can reach them, all words fail; though the buddhas speak in various ways according to conventional usage, they do not cling to anything as mental objects, do not make anything up, and avoid all false conceptual attachments: in this way they ultimately reach the other shore. All buddhas know the fundamental nature of all things is null: because it has no birth, it is not form; because it has no manifestation it is not sensation; because it has no names or categories it is not conception; because it has no action it is not conditioning; because it has no grasping it is not consciousness; because it has no access it is not sense mediums; because it apprehends nothing it is not sense elements—yet it does not destroy things, because the original nature has no origination, is like space. All phenomena are empty and quiescent; there is no action or effect, no cultivation, no accomplishment, no production. They are not in sets, yet not out of order; not existent or nonexistent; not born or annihilated, not defiled or pure; not entering or existing; not abiding, not transitory; not edifying, not unedifying; not beings, not not beings; not living, not lifeless; not caused, not causeless. While knowing this, the buddhas know all sentient beings, whether they are rightly stabilized, wrongly stabilized, or not stabilized, and teach them the subtle truth to enable them to reach the other shore, attain the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, be able to roar the lion’s roar, be imbued with universal knowledge, and abide in the realm of buddhahood. These are the ten kinds of skill in means achieved by buddhas.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bcu po 'di dag ni/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgya chen po tshad med pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnams te/ de dag ni sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs ma gtogs par lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten dang / 'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyis 'jug par mi nus pa'o/ /bcu gang zhe na/ phyogs bcu'i nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa'i chos kyi dbyings thams cad kyi 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du dga' ldan du skye ba bstan pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mu med pa dag la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ kha dog tshad med pa / gzi brjid tshad med pa/ snang ba tshad med pa/ dbyangs tshad med pa/ dbyangs kyi yan lag rnam par dag pa tshad med pa/ gsung brjod pas rnam par dmigs pa tshad med pa/ ting nge 'dzin tshad med pa la spyod pa/ shes rab dang / ye shes yul tshad med pa mnga' ba rnams lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten la phan 'dogs pa mdzad de/ bdud dang bcas pa; tshangs pa dang bcas pa/ dge sbyong dang bram ze'i skye dgu dang bcas pa/ lha dang mi dang lha ma yin du bcas pa'i 'jig rten la phan 'dogs pa mdzad do/ /byams pa chen po'i spyod yul thogs pa med pa dang / thabs thugs rje chen po'i sgo'i mthar thug pas sems can la phan 'dogs pa mdzad do/ /bsod nams kyi stobs dang / mnga' phun sum tshogs pa dang / dbang po rnam par sbyang ba dang / cang shes kyi sems yongs su dag pas kyang sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa mdzad do/ /theg pa sna tshogs rnam par dag pas kyang sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa mdzad do/ /theg pa chen po yongs su rdzogs par bya bas kyang sems can rnams la phan 'dogs par mdzad do/ /'gro ba thams cad gdon pas kyang sems can rnams la phan 'dogs pa mdzad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las dang po'o/ /

“Buddhas have ten kinds of great buddha-work, immeasurable, boundless, inconceivable, unknowable to all celestial and human worldlings, unknowable even to the past, future, and present Buddhist disciples and self-enlightened ones, except by the spiritual power of the buddhas. What are they? All buddhas appear to be born in the heavens of contentment in all worlds throughout the cosmos, carry out enlightening practices, and perform great buddha-works in the spheres of operation of infinite forms, infinite powers, infinite lights, infinite sounds, infinite verbal expressions, infinite concentrations, and infinite knowledge, taking in all humans, celestials, demons, monks, priests, titans, and so on, their great kindness uninhibited, their great compassion ultimate, impartially aiding and benefiting all living beings, enabling them to be born in heaven or in the human realm, or purifying their senses, or tuning their minds, sometimes explaining three different vehicles of salvation for them, sometimes explaining the complete, full unitary vehicle for them, saving and liberating all, enabling them to get out of birth and death — this is the first great buddha-work.

dga' ldan gyi pho brang nas 'phos pa med kyang yum gyi skur gshegs shing / byang chub sems dpa'i sku tha ma skye bar bstan pa/ sgyu ma lta bur yongs su spyod pa/ sprul pa lta bu'i ting nge 'dzin gyi mthar thug pa/ mig yor lta bur rnam par dmigs pa/ nam mkha'i yul tshad med par khyab pa/ bzhed pa bzhin du skye yang chags pa mi mnga' ba/ smig rgyu ba lta bur bstan pa/ nyon mongs pa med pa'i chos la yang dag par gzhol ba/ gnas med pa'i ye shes la gnas pa/ rang bzhin gyis 'dod chags dang bral bas rnam par dag pa/ rgyan shin tu rgya che ba'i mdzod kyis sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /khang pa brtsegs pa rin po che las byas pa'i pho brang chen po rin po che'i rgyan mang po ldan pa na bzhugs pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /rdzu 'phrul gyis kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /yid la bya ba byin gyi rlabs chen pos kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /rnam par 'phrul ba'i mdzod chen po yang dag par bstan pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /ye shes kyi nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor chen pos kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /yum sku skyed pa'i sku na bzhugs pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do; ;sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi spyod yul chen po brnyes pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sangs rgyas kyi byin gyis 'jig rten byin du brlabs pa mtha' yas pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /ting nge 'dzin chen po grangs med pa la rnam par spyod cing snyoms par 'jug pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /ting nge 'dzin las bzhengs pa de dang de dag gis kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /spyod pa'i thog ma la yongs su mya ngan las 'das pa chen po'i mthar thug pa'i bar du thog ma dang / dbus dang / tha ma'i tshul gyis kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sa 'di la gnyis su med pa thams cad mthar phyin par byas nas tha mar 'jig rten gyi grangs kyis skye ba yongs su ston te/ skye bas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /gzhon nur gyur pas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /byang chub sems dpar gyur pas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /mngon par 'byung bas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /mngon par 'tshang rgya bas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bas kyang 'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /thabs mkhas pa sna tshogs kyis kyang 'jig rten sna tshogs/ 'jig rten tshad med pa/ 'jig rten kun tu mtha' yas pa phyogs kyi dra ba'i rgyud dang / rigs thams cad kyi 'jig rten ma lus pa thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /zhing gi rgyud ma lus pa'i 'jig rten du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /las kyi rnam par smin pa ma lus pa'i 'jig rten du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sems can gyi rgyud ma lus pa'i 'jig rten du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /skye ba dang shi 'pho ba'i rgyud ma lus pa'i 'jig rten du sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sprul pa chen po'i rgyud dang / sangs rgyas kyi rigs dang / chos dran pa'i sgo'i 'khor los kyang / sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ 'di na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gnyis pa'o/ /

“All buddhas descend spiritually from the heaven of contentment into the mother’s womb; by means of ultimate concentration they observe the phenomenon of taking on life as like an illusion, like a phantom, like a reflection, like space, like a mirage, and they take on life however they wish, without bound, without hindrance. Entering the state of noncontention, they develop knowledge without attachment; free from desire, clear and pure, they develop a vast treasury of wondrous adornments, take on their final embodiment, live in a great jewel-adorned mansion and perform buddha-work. They may do buddha-work by spiritual powers, or by right recollection, or by showing miracles, or by manifesting the sun of knowledge, or by revealing the enormous spheres of buddhahood, or by showing the immeasurable lights of the buddhas, or by entering countless great concentrations, or by manifesting emergence from concentration. The buddhas, at that time, in the mother’s womb, wishing to benefit all worldlings, show all kinds of appearances to do buddha-work. They may appear to be born, or appear as children, or appear as princes, or appear as leaving home, or they may show the appearance of atttaining true enlightenment, or show the appearance of turning the wheel of the Teaching, or show the appearance of entering final extinction. In this way all of them, by various means, perform buddha-work in all regions, all networks, all circles, all systems, in all worlds. This is the second great buddha-work.

dge bar spyod pa'i las rnam par dag cing / gdung rabs thams cad du ye shes kyi tshul rnam par dag pas sku tshe'i rgyud kyi tshul dang ldan pa/ sems can thams cad gdul ba thugs su chud pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad yongs su rdzogs par mdzad cing btsun mo'i 'khor gyi nang na bzhugs pa ston kyang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi 'dod chags dang bral ba'i tshul gyi gnas la bzhugs pa rnams sgra dang / tshig thams cad dang bral bar brtags pas dngos po thams cad dngos po med pa las byung bar khong du chud par bya ba dang / dngos po thams cad shes pa la gzud par bya ba dang / tshul khrims thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi mthar thug par yongs su rdzogs par bya ba dang / snying rje chen pos 'gro ba mu med pa la rnam par blta bar bya ba dang / byams pa chen pos sems can med pa'i yul la rab tu rtog par bya ba dang / dga' ba chen pos 'jig rten brjod du med par khong du chud par bya ba dang / btang snyoms chen pos sems la dbang sgyur ba la gnas par bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i yon tan gyis rang yongs su rgyas par byed par bya ba dang / chos kyi dbyings kyi lus ma lus par mngon par bsgrub par bya ba dang / thams cad du gnas med pa'i lus yongs su rdzogs par byed par bya ba dang / 'khor thams cad rnam par dag par nan tan du byed par bya ba dang / chos bstan pa rnam par brjod pa rab tu brjod par bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi dngos po la smod par bya ba dang / 'gro ba thams cad kyi nyes pa la rtog par bya ba mdzad cing spyod pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa bar rnam par smin pa yang dag par bstan pa dang / ji ltar bkod pa'i tshul du sems can gdul ba dang / yongs su ma smin pa'i sems can yongs su smin par bya ba dang / yongs su smin pa rnams tshul bzhin du gdul ba dang / grangs med pa'i thabs mkhas pa mngon par sgrub pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las phyir mi ldog pa yongs su bstan pa dang / sgo sna tshogs nas chos kyi spyod pa rab tu brjod pa dang / sems can rnams kyi bsam pa sna tshogs rnam par sbyang ba dang / thugs rje chen po las byung ba'i chos kyi sprin gyis mngon par spang ba dang / thams cad la skyob pa'i byams pa chen po bskyed pa'i cho 'phrul gsum gyis yongs su brlan pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad mthong ba dang / rnam par dmigs pa'i btsun mo'i 'khor gyi nang du bstan pa yan chad du 'jig rten mtha' dang dbus med par sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las yongs su bstan pa mdzad cing / ye shes kyi mthu chen po thogs pa med pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi mngon par mkhyen pa bsgribs pa med par bsgrubs pa dang / chos rnam pa gsum gyis thabs mkhas pa dang ldan pa'i 'phrin las kyi mtha' dang / sku'i 'phrin las kyi mtha' shin tu rnam par dag pa dang / gsung gi 'phrin las ye shes nyams pa med pas rnam par dag pa dang / thugs kyi 'phrin las kyi mtha' zab cing chags pa med pa'i mthar thug pa'i thabs la mkhas pas sems can rnams kyi don mdzad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gsum pa'o// //

“All good works of all buddhas are already pure, and their knowledge of all life is clear and immaculate: so by birth they lead and guide the deluded, causing them to open up in understanding and practice all that is good. For the sake of sentient beings they appear to be born in a royal palace. All buddhas have already abandoned all materialistic desires for palaces and pleasure; they have no craving or obsession, and always reflect upon the emptiness and essencelessness of all existents, that all comforts and delights are not truly real. Keeping the pure precepts of buddhas, ultimately fulfilling them, observing the palace ladies and attendants, they develop great compassion; observing that all sentient beings are unreal, they develop great kindness; observing that there is nothing enjoyable in the world, they develop great joy; their minds gaining freedom in the midst of all things, they develop great relinquishment. Imbued with the qualities of buddhahood, they manifest birth in the phenomenal realm, their physical features perfect, their associates pure, yet they have no attachment to anything. With voices adapting to types, they explain the truth to the masses, causing them to become disillusioned with worldly things; they point out to them the results of what they are doing. Also they use expedient means to teach in accord with needs, causing the immature to develop maturity, causing the mature to attain liberation, doing buddha-work for them to cause them not to regress. Also, by virtue of a heart of universal love and compassion they continually explain all kinds of principles to sentient beings and also manifest the powers of diagnosis, prescription, and occult influence for them, to enable them to awaken and attain purity of mind. Though the buddhas be in the inner palace, seen by all the people, yet they are performing buddha-work in all worlds. By means of great knowledge and great energy they manifest the various spiritual powers of buddhas, unhindered, inexhaustible. They always continue three kinds of skillfull, expedient action—that is, their physical activity is ultimately pure, their verbal activity is always carried out in accord with knowledge, and their mental activity is exceedingly profound and has no blockage or inhibition; by these means they benefit living beings. This is the third great buddha-work.
bam po drug cu lnga pa/

rnam par rgyal ba chen po mnga' ba rnams ni btsun mo'i 'khor rgyan rnam par skye ba tshad med pa dang ldan pa yid du 'ong ba spangs te/ mngon par 'byung ba'i spyod pa yongs su bstan pas sems can rnams 'jig rten gyi gnas las bskyod pa dang / 'jig rten gyi mngon par zhen pa rnam par bzlog pa dang / 'jig rten du gtogs pa thams cad mi rtag par shes par bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi tshul la mngon par zhen pa rnam par bzlog pa dang 'jig rten gyi dga' ba la sred pa yongs su bcad pa dang / 'jig rten gyi nyon mongs pa byang zhing nub pa la yang dag par spyod par bya ba dang / sems can gyi don rjes su dran par bya ba'i phyir/ mngon par 'byung ba'i don la rab tu gzhol ba dang / khyim pa'i tshul yongs su spang ba bstan pa dang / nyon mongs pa med pa'i chos kyi sbyor ba la yang dag par gnas par bya ba dang; sngon gyi smon lam yongs su rdzogs par bya ba dang / yon tan gyi dkyil 'khor tshad med pa yongs su snang bar bya ba dang / ye shes kyi dkyil 'khor chen po brnyes pas sems can rnams kyi mi shes pa'i sgrib pa rab tu bsal ba dang / bdag nyid bsod nams kyi zhing bla na med par gyur par 'gro ba thams cad la bstan pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad sangs rgyas la bskyed pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba'i nang du 'dus par 'gro ba thams cad la yang dag par brjod pa dang / bdag nyid kyis ye shes kyi don gzigs par bstan pa dang / sems can rnams rnam par dag pa'i sgor brjod pa dang / sems can rnams kha na ma tho ba med pa'i sgor sgrub pa dang / 'jig rten thams cad du 'byung ba'i sgo rab tu bstan pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi rgyal mtshan yang dag par bsgreng ba mdzad cing mngon par 'byung ba ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las bzhi pa'o/ /

“All buddhas show analytic examination and disenchantment while living in a palace of all kinds of adornments, thereupon giving it up and leaving home, wishing to let sentient beings realize that things of the world are all illusions, impermanent, and perishable, and become deeply disillusioned, avoid creating attachments, forever cut off the affliction of worldly craving, cultivate purifying practices, and benefit living beings. When the buddhas leave home, they give up conventional manners, abide in noncontention, and fulfill the immeasurable virtues of their fundamental vow. By the light of great knowledge they destroy the darkness of delusion of the world and become unexcelled fields of blessings for all beings. They always extol the virtues of buddhas for the benefit of sentient beings, causing them to plant roots of goodness with the buddhas. They see truth with the eye of wisdom. They also extol renunciation for the benefit of sentient beings, its purity and blamelessness. They are eternally emancipated and are forever lofty paragons of wisdom for the world. This is the fourth great buddha-work.

don gcig ma yin pa mkhyen pa dang ldan pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi mthar thug pa rnams ni/ chos thams cad mngon par 'tshang rgya bar bya'o zhes byang chub kyi shing drung du byon te/ byang chub tu mngon par 'tshang rgya bas kyang bdud kyi dpung thams cad rab tu gzhom pa dang / sku'i byin gyi rlabs kyi mdzod kyi chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad du rgyas par dgang ba'i phyir; byin gyi rlabs zad mi shes pa'i mthar thug pas mtha' rnam par spangs pa spyod pa tshad med pa rab tu brnyes pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i yul gyis rnam par rol pa'i ye shes kyi don dang ldan pa/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i yon tan yang dag par sgrub pa yongs su rdzogs pa/ 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du gdan rnam par bkram pas yongs su rgyas pa/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing ma lus pa thams cad du byang chub sems dpa' rnam par dmigs pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dam pa thob pa rnams kyis zhal du blta ba/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi rnam pa dang / smon lam khyad par can dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad kyis yang dag par bsam pa'i chos kyi 'khor lo zab mo rab tu bskor ba/ sangs rgyas kyi yul tshad med pa brtsams pas/ byang chub sems dpa' brjod du med pa'i 'byung gnas su gyur pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa sna tshogs spyod pa la yang dag par gzhol ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor rnam par dag pa mnga' ba/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad sangs rgyas kyi byin gyis byin du rlob pa'i yul mnga' ba/ dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed pa'i sems can gyis rnam par dmigs pa dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad tha mi dad pa dang ldan pa 'byung ba'i sa byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mtha' yas pa'i mthu'i gnas la yon tan gyi khyad par thams cad rab tu brnyes nas bzhugs pa 'jig rten gyi rnam pa thams cad ma lus pa'i mthar thug pa/ sems can gyi rnam pa thams cad dang / zhing gi rnam pa thams cad dang / chos kyi rnam pa thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa'i rnam pa thams cad dang / yongs su smin par bya ba'i rnam pa thams cad dang / dus kyi rnam pa thams cad dang / 'dul ba'i rnam pa thams cad dang / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul ba'i rnam pa thams cad ma lus par mthar thug pa rnams 'gro ba ma lus pa thams cad du mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du rnam par 'tshang rgya bas sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las lnga pa'o/ /

“All buddhas have omniscience and already know and see infinite realities. Attaining perfect true enlightenment under the tree of enlightenment, vanquishing all demons, their majesty supreme, their bodies fill all worlds. Their deeds of spiritual power are boundless and inexhaustible. They attain mastery of all meanings in the sphere of omniscience. They have cultivated virtues to consummation. Their seats of enlightenment are fully adorned and pervade all worlds in the ten directions; the buddhas sit on them and turn the wheel of the sublime Teaching, explaining all the undertakings of enlightening beings, revealing the infinite realms of the buddhas, causing the enlightening beings to awaken to and enter into them. They carry out all kinds of pure practices and are able to direct and guide all living beings, cause them to plant roots of goodness, be born in the ground of equality of the enlightened, continue in the boundless good practices of enlightening beings, and develop all the most excellent qualities. The buddhas know perfectly all worlds, all beings, all buddha-lands, all phenomena, all enlightening beings, all teachings, all pasts, presents, and futures, all disciplines, all mystic transformations, and the inclinations of all sentient beings’ minds, and based on this knowledge perform buddha-work. This is the fifth great buddha-work.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba mdzad pa phyir mi ldog pa'i tshul gyis phyir mi ldog pa'i 'khor lo dang / 'jig rten thams cad kyis khong du chud par 'gyur ba'i tshul gyis tshad med pa'i 'khor lo dang / mi 'jigs pa'i seng+ge'i nga ro chen po'i tshul gyis thams cad ma lus par mngon par sangs rgyas pa'i 'khor lo dang / chos kyi mdzod mun pa med pa'i sgos snang bar byed pa'i tshul gyis chos thams cad mkhyen pa'i mdzod kyi 'khor lo dang / ye shes nam mkha'i dbyings ltar tshad med pa'i tshul gyis chags pa med pa'i 'khor lo dang / chos thams cad kyi dngos po med pa'i rang bzhin rab tu rtogs par bya ba'i tshul gyis bsgribs pa med pa'i 'khor lo dang / sems can thams cad kyi chos kyi mig rnam par sbyong ba'i tshul gyis 'jig rten thams cad kyi sgron ma'i 'khor lo dang / 'jig rten thams cad du rgyas par 'gengs pa'i tshul gyis thams cad mkhyen pa'i chos brjod pa'i 'khor lo dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad dang mi 'gal ba'i tshul gyis/ sangs rgyas thams cad 'dab 'dres par gyur pa'i 'khor lo dang / de dag la sogs pa rnam pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong du chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bas sems can thams cad kyi sems dang spyod pa'i rnam pa la chos kyi 'khor lo bskor te/ de ltar chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bas kyang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las bsam gyis mi khyab pa mdzad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las drug pa'o/ /

“All buddhas turn the irreversible wheel of the Teaching, to cause the enlightening beings not to backslide; they turn the immeasurable wheel of the Teaching, to cause all worldlings to know; they turn the wheel of Teaching, awakening all, because they can fearlessly roar the lion’s roar; they turn the wheel of Teaching, which is a treasury of knowledge of all truths, to open the door of the treasury of truth and remove the obstacle of obscurity; they turn the unobstructed wheel of the Teaching, being equal to space; they turn the wheel of Teaching of nonattachment, because they see that all things are neither existent nor nonexistent; they turn the world-illuminating wheel of Teaching, to cause all sentient beings to purify their vision of reality; they turn the wheel of Teaching revealing all knowledge, pervading all things in all times; they turn the wheel of Teaching, which is the same one of all buddhas, because all Buddha teachings are not mutually opposed or contradictory. All buddhas, by means of measureless, countless hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of such wheels of Teaching, perform buddha-work inconceivably according to the differences in mental patterns of sentient beings. This is the sixth great buddha-work.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni/ grong dang / grong khyer dang / grong rdal dang / rgyal po'i gnas su gshegs pas kyang sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ mi'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / lha'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / klu'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / gnod sbyin gyi rgyal po'i gnas dang / dri za'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / lha ma yin gyi rgyal po'i gnas dang / nam mkha' lding gi rgyal po'i gnas dang / mi'am ci'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / lto 'phye chen po'i rgyal po'i gnas dang / srin po'i rgyal po'i gnas dang; sha za'i rgyal po'i gnas dag tu gshegs pas kyang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ 'di lta ste/ grong khyer gyi khrod byon na/ sa g.yo ba dang / 'od zer snang ba dang / long ba rnams mig 'thob pa dang / 'on pa rnams sgra thos par 'gyur ba dang / smyos pa rnams dran pa 'thob par 'gyur ba dang / gos med pa rnams gos 'thob par 'gyur ba dang / sdug bsngal ba rnams bde ba 'thob pa dang / rol mo'i cha spyad ma dkrol ma brdungs par sgra yid du 'ong ba rang 'byin pa dang / rgyan snod na 'dug pa dang / gnas nas ma phog pa dang / ma bskyod ma dkrol bar bskyod cing dkrol ba'i sgra 'byung ba dang / bya sna tshogs mang po'i sgra skad yid du 'ong ba 'byung ba dang / blta na gtang mi bra zhing mi mthun pa med pa'i sku mthong bas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /mtshan dang dpe byad bzang po bstan pas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ yongs su gzigs pa dang / rnam par gzigs pa dang / brkyang ba dang bskum pas kyang sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /gshegs pa dang / slar bzhud pa dang / bzhengs pa dang / 'chag pa dang / bzhugs pa dang / gzims pas kyang sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /chos bstan pa dang / mi gsung bar bzhugs pas kyang sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /rdzu 'phrul gyi cho 'phrul dang / yongs su bstan pa'i cho 'phrul dang / rjes su bstan pa'i cho 'phrul gyis kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams 'jig rten gyi khams kyi yul sems can bsam pa sna tshogs rgya mtsho dang ldan pa/ 'jig rten gyi spyod pa thams cad rgyu zhing 'byung ba dang ldan pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba chen pos shin tu bstan pa/ sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa dang ldan pa/ sngon 'grogs 'grogs pa'i byang chub sems dpa' dang gnas pa'i sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams ni sku gzugs blta na mi ngoms pa'o zhes bya bar gzhol ba dang / sangs rgyas rnams skye bar dkon no zhes bya bar yid ches par byed pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong zhing / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung thos pa ni bsod nams kyi chos dkar po'i 'byung gnas su gyur pa'o zhes sangs rgyas kyi spyod pa yid la byed pa dang / 'jig rten thams cad rnam par dag pa ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa skye ba yin no zhes bya bar khong du chud par byed pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi yon tan bsngags pa ni mtha' yas pa'o zhes bya bar yang dag par lta ba dang / ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas 'byung ba'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs yang dag par sgrub pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / mos pa'i tshul thams cad kyis sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams mnyes par byed pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams ni yon tan mtha' yas pa'o zhes khong du chud par byed pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa ni sems can thams cad la mngon du gyur par rtog pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa ni sems can gyi rigs bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i gnas su gyur bar sems pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa ni zhing thams cad na snang bar khong du chud pa dang / de lta bu'i dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad 'byung bas/ 'jig rten thams cad na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /dad par byas pa dang / phyag 'tshal ba dang / thal mo sbyar ba byas pa dang / rjes su bstod pa dang / spyan drangs pa dang / mchod pa dang / mngon du mthong ba dang / 'dzum pa byas pa dang / sangs rgyas la dga' ba'i sems kyis mos par bya ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba'i sgo nas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sangs rgyas rjes su dran par gyur pas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /sangs rgyas mthong bar 'dod par bya bas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku kha dog dang dbyibs kyi rnam pa tshad med pa bstan pas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad do/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung thos par bya bas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ de dag la sogs pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad pa rnam pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong brjod du med pa dag 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa dang / mthu dang 'dul ba ji lta ba'i tshul las mi 'da' bar 'byung ngo/ /de ltar sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las 'jig rten thams cad kyi sems can kun gyi sems dang / spyod pa dang / bsam pa la gnas pa dge ba rgya che ba tshad med pa dag phyir mi ldog pa'i yul dang / snying rje chen pos rab tu bskul ba dang / sngon gyi smon lam gyis yongs su skyo ba med pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mkhyen pa'i stobs dang shugs kyis 'jig rten thams cad du 'byung ste/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las bdun pa'o/ /

“All buddhas enter into all capital cities and perform buddha-work for the beings. That is, they enter human capitals, celestial capitals, capitals of water spirits, monsters, cherubim, titans, birds, hobgoblins, serpents, goblins, demons, and so on. When they enter the gates of the city, the earth trembles, light shines everywhere, the blind gain vision, the deaf are able to hear, the insane regain their sanity, the naked are clothed, the troubled and suffering all gain peace and happiness; all musical instruments spontaneously play, all adornments, used or not, emit marvelous sounds that delight all hearers. The buddhas’ physical forms are pure and clean, fully endowed with the marks and refinements of greatness, so that none ever tire of seeing them. They are able to do buddha-work for the benefit of sentient beings—whether looking, examining, moving, stretching, walking or standing still, sitting or reclining, silent or speaking, whether manifesting occult powers, or explaining principles, or giving instructions—in all these they are performing buddha-work for the benefit of sentient beings. All buddhas, in all the countless worlds, in the midst of the oceans of mental inclinations of all kinds of sentient beings, urge them to remembrance the buddhas, always diligently considering and planting roots of goodness, cultivating the practices of enlightening beings, lauding the subtlety and supremacy of the buddhas’ appearance, which is hard for any living being to get to meet; if beings see buddhas and are inspired with faith, then they produce all the immeasurable good qualities and amass the virtues of buddhas, all pure. Thus, having extolled the virtues of buddhas, they multiply their bodies to go to all worlds in the ten directions to let the sentient beings behold them, meditate on them and contemplate them, attend and serve them, plant roots of goodness, gain the good graces of the buddhas, and increase the family of buddhas, all being certain to attain buddhahood. By these actions they perform buddha-work, sometimes manifesting physical bodies for sentient beings, sometimes making sublime utterances, sometimes just smiling, causing them to believe, honor, praise, and behave courteously. All buddhas, by means of innumerable, untold, inconceivable such buddha-works of all kinds, in all worlds, according to the inclinations of sentient beings’ minds, teach them expediently, by the power of their original vows, the power of great love and compassion, and the power of omniscience, causing them all to be civilized. This is the seventh great buddha-work.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni dgon pa la bzhugs sam/ zhi bar bzhugs sam/ dben par bzhugs sam; sangs rgyas kyi rnam par spyod pa la bzhugs sam/ /ting nge 'dzin chen po'i gnas la bzhugs sam/ gcig pu dgyes par bzhugs sam/ sku mi snang bar bzhugs sam/ ye shes zab mo'i gnas la bzhugs sam/ sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi stobs tshad med pa la bzhugs sam/ sku'i yongs su spyod pa mi mthong bar bzhugs kyang rung ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las gzhan gyis mi tshugs pa'i ye shes dang / smon lam gyi tshul gyis mos pa bzhin du 'dul ba'i sems can rnams la rgyun mi 'chad par 'byung ste/ sangs rgyas lha yongs su tshol bas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /sangs rgyas klu yongs su tshol bas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do; ;sangs rgyas gnod sbyin yongs su tshol ba dang / sangs rgyas mi'am ci yongs su tshol ba dang / sangs rgyas lto 'phye chen po yongs su tshol ba dang / sangs rgyas srin po yongs su tshol ba dang / sangs rgyas mi dang mi ma yin pa yongs su tshol ba dang / sangs rgyas nyan thos dang / sangs rgyas rang sangs rgyas dang / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' yongs su tshol bas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /chos ston pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /sangs rgyas gcig brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /sangs rgyas thams cad brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa'i khyad par dang / smon lam thams cad gcig tu brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa gcig rnam par phye ste/ spyod pa tha dad pa brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /'jig rten gyi yul sangs rgyas kyi yul du brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /sangs rgyas kyi yul 'jig rten gyi yul du brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /yul ma yin pa sangs rgyas kyi yul du brjod pas kyang sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad do/ /nyin mtshan dang / yud du yan man dang / zla ba dang / lo 'grangs par bzhugs pa dang / yongs su bzhugs pa nas de bzhin du bskal pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa'i bar du bzhugs pa dang / yongs su bzhugs pas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams sems can rnams la sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las mdzad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las brgyad pa'o/ /

“All buddhas may do buddha-work while dwelling in forest retreats, or in quiet places, or in desolate places, or in buddhas’ dwelling places; or they may do buddha-work while in trance, or while alone in a grove, or while concealing themselves from view, or while abiding in knowledge of the ultimate profundity, or while dwelling in the incomparable realm of the buddhas; or they may do buddha-work while carrying on various imperceptible physical actions, adapting to sentient beings’ mentalities, predilections, and understandings to teach them as is expedient, without cease. Or they may do buddha-work seeking omniscience in the form of celestial beings, or they may do buddha-work seeking omniscience in the form of water spirits, goblins, cherubim, titans, birds, serpents, humans, subhumans, and so on. They may also do buddha-work by seeking omniscience in the form of listeners, solitary illuminates, or enlightening beings. Sometimes they preach, sometimes they are silent in doing buddha-work. Sometimes they do buddha-work saying there is one Buddha, sometimes saying there are many buddhas. Sometimes they do buddha-work saying all practices and all vows of enlightening beings are one practice and vow; sometimes they do buddha-work saying one practice and one vow of enlightening beings are infinite practices and vows. Sometimes they do buddha-work saying the realm of buddhahood is the world, sometimes they do buddha-work saying the world is the realm of buddhahood. Sometimes they do buddha-work saying the realm of buddhahood is not the world. Sometimes they remain for a day, or a night, or a fortnight, or a month, or a year, up to untold eons, to do buddha-work for the benefit of sentient beings. This is the eighth great buddha-work.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams la 'byung gnas lta bu sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa kun la rnam par sbyong ba lta bu/ sangs rgyas rnams la dad pa lta bu/ sems khong du chud par bya ba la shin tu mos pa lta bu/ dbang po rnams la sgrub pa lta bu/ sems can skye dgu thams cad la 'dul ba lta bu/ 'gro ba thams cad la mos pa lta bu/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la 'byung ba lta bu/ byang chub tu zhugs pa rnams la bskul ba lta bu/ gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog pa rnams la ye shes kyi snang ba lta bu dag ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'jig rten mi rtag par ston pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad par brjod pa dang / 'phrin las mdzad pa'i mthar thug par bstan pa dang / chos kyi rgyud nyams pa med pa'i dngos por brjod pa dang / srid pa'i tshul rtsa ba nas chad par brjod pa dang / sems can thams cad skyo bar bya bar bstan pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi rjes su 'gro ba'i sems su mthun par bya ba dang / sku tshe'i mtha' lta bur sems can rnams kyis shes par bya ba dang / sems can rnams kyis 'jig rten thams cad du dga' bar bya ba med par bstan pa dang / sems can rnams la ma byon pa'i sangs rgyas gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa mnyes par gyis shig par bstan pa dang / sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba bstan tu mi rung bar khong du chud par bya ba dang / 'jig rten rnams kyi rtsol ba bskyed pa dang / sangs rgyas la dmigs par brtson pa'i sems la dgod pa dang / yun du dran pa rnam par dag pas de bzhin gshegs pa mthong ba'i rnam par rtog pa bskyed pa dang / skyo ba'i dbang po phyir bzlog cing / yongs su dag par mdzad pa dang / sangs rgyas la mos pa bskyed pa dang / skyo bar gyur ba'i sems can rnams la byin gyis brlab par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas la dmigs pa'i rkyen 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du phyin par dgongs pa mdzad pa dang / sku thams cad bshig ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gdung gis sems can rnams yongs su gzung ba mdzad pa dang / 'jig rten rnam par 'khrugs pa dang / dregs shing myos pa'i sems can rnams sdom pa la dgod pa mdzad cing yongs su mya ngan las 'da' bar ston pas kyang / sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las rgyun mi 'chad de/ 'di ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las dgu pa'o/ /

“All buddhas are mines that produce pure roots of goodness, causing sentient beings to engender pure faith and resolution in the buddha-teachings, so their faculties are tamed and they forever detach from the world. They cause enlightening beings to be full of knowledge, wisdom, and clarity in regard to the way of enlightenment and not depend on another for understanding. Sometimes they do buddha-work manifesting nirvana, sometimes they do buddha-work showing the evanescence of all in the world, sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the buddha-bodies, sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the accomplishment of all that is to be done, sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the flawless fulfillment of virtuous qualities, sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the extirpation of the root of all existences. Sometimes they do buddha-work causing sentient beings to turn away from the world to follow the buddha-mind; sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the inevitable ending of life; sometimes they do buddha-work explaining that there is nothing enjoyable in the world. Sometimes they do buddha-work preaching the eternal service of buddhas; sometimes they do buddha-work explaining the buddhas’ turning of the wheel of pure Teaching, causing the hearers to become very joyful. Sometimes they do buddha-work expounding the sphere of buddhahood, inspiring people to cultivate spiritual practices. Sometimes they do buddha-work expounding concentration on remembrance of Buddha, inspiring people to always delight in visions of Buddha. Sometimes they do buddha-work expounding the purification of the senses, diligent search for the Buddha Way with unflagging spirit. Sometimes they do buddha-work visiting all buddha-lands and observing the various causes and conditions of their environments. Sometimes they do buddha-work uniting all bodies of living beings into a buddha-body, causing all lazy and self-indulgent sentient beings to abide by the pure precepts of the enlightened. This is the ninth great buddha-work.

de bzhin gshegs pa rnams mya ngan las 'da' ba'i tshe; 'jig rten thams cad na sems can rnams smre sngags 'don cing ngu ba dang mya ngan byed pa dang / mchi ma 'byin pa dang / yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas zhe'am/ thugs rje chen po zhe'am/ ded dpon chen po zhe'am/ phan par bzhed pa thugs brtse ba can zhe'am/ lha dang bcas pa'i 'jig rten gyi sems can thams cad kyi skyabs su gyur pa/ mgon du gyur pa/ rten du gyur pa/ bla na med pa bsod nams kyi zhing nub par gyur to/ /zhe'am/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni 'byung bar dka'o zhes rnam pa de lta bur smre sngags 'don pa dang / mya ngan byed pa dang / sangs rgyas mthong ba rjes su dran pa'i sems can rnams kyi bsam pa dang / yid la bya ba de dang de dag gi sgor sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las tshad med pa rgyun mi 'chad do/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams yongs su mya ngan las 'da' ba'i tshe/ 'di lta ste/ sems can rnams kyi sems dad par bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams dad pas mchod par bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams lhag pa'i bsam pa rnam par sbyong bar bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams yongs su smin par bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams yongs su sbyang bar bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams 'dul ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams bsod nams kyi tshogs yongs su rdzogs par bya ba'i dbang dang / sems can rnams de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pas dmigs par bya ba'i dbang dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten dam pa sna tshogs su brgyan pas/ phyogs dang yul sna tshogs su sems can rnams kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba bsags par bya ba'i dbang gis sems can rnams kyi bsam pa dang / mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du sku gdung dang / ring bsrel byin gyis rlob ste/ lha dang / klu dang / gnod sbyin dang / dri za dang / lha ma yin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po dang / mi'i gnas thams cad du 'dul pa dang / mos pa'i tshul ji lta ba bzhin du sku gdung dang / ring bsrel byin gyis rlob bo/ /rang gi sku rnam par phye ste/ sku gdung dang ring bsrel tshad med pa grangs med pa/ dpag tu med pa/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa brjod du med pa'i yang brjod du med pa byin gyis rlob bo/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i mchod rten gyis sangs rgyas kyi sku gdung 'jig rten thams cad du rnam par phye ba de'i yul dang / phyogs kyi klu'i gnas dang / gnod sbyin dang / dri za dang / lha ma yin dang / nam mkha' lding dang / mi'am ci dang / lto 'phye chen po'i gnas dang / mi'i gnas pa dang / srin po'i gnas dag tu sku gdung dang ring bsrel mchod par byed par 'gyur bas/ sku gdung gi ring bsrel dang / dbu dang phyag sen gyi mchod rten dang / sangs rgyas bzhugs pa'i mchod rten la 'gro ba thams cad nges par sangs rgyas dran par 'gyur te/ chos la rab tu rten par 'gyur ro/ /dge 'dun la dad pa rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /yul dang phyogs kyi gnas de dang de dag tu 'ang rgyun mi 'chad par sangs rgyas mchod pa la brtson pa'i bsam pas sbyin pa yongs su gtong bar 'gyur ro/ /bsod nams byed par 'gyur ro/ /mtho ris de dang de yongs su dag pa rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /rigs dang rgyud kyi bdag nyid che ba rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /longs spyod chen po dang 'khor rnam par dag pa rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /lha dang mi'i phun sum tshogs pa nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro/ /log par ltung ba med pa'i lam yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ /sangs rgyas 'byung ba don yod pa rab tu sgrub par 'gyur ro/ /chos dkar po la gnas pa yongs su rdzogs par byed par 'gyur ro/ /khams gsum pa las 'byung ba'i lam yongs su sbyong bar 'gyur ro/ /theg pa gang la dad pa'i smon lam gyis nges par 'byung / bar 'gyur ro/ /de bzhin gshegs pa de dang de dag la drin du gzo ba rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams la brten pa dang / skyabs btsal ba dang / mgon btsal ba dang / dpung gnyen btsal ba'i sems bskyed par 'gyur te/ de ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni yongs su mya ngan las 'das kyang yon bsam gyis mi khyab pa
