de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhabs kyi mthil gyi 'khor lo rtsibs stong dang ldan pa la kun tu snang zhing mdzes pa'i 'od zer yod de/ de la 'od 'dzin pa dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i dpe byad bzang po'i 'od yod do/ /de las 'od zer bzhi bcu 'byung ste/ de'i nang nas 'od zer gcig cig yon tan yongs su dag pa'i 'od ces bya ste/ de ni 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing bye ba khrag khrig gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed snang bar byed do/ /yul ji lta ba dang / bsam pa ji lta ba dang / yongs su smin pa'i khyad par ji lta ba bzhin du/ mnar med pa'i sems can dmyal ba chen po'i sems can rnams kyang snang bar byed de/ de dag de nas shi 'phos nas dga' ldan gyi lha dang skal ba mnyam par skye'o/ /de dag der skyes nas kyang lha'i rnga'i sgra las/ kye btsun pa lha'i sras po dag /legs kyi/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad de nyid la phyag 'tshol cig /byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad ni 'di yin te/ dri ma dang bral ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag cing bzhugs so zhes bya ba'i sgra thos par 'gyur ro/ /de nas lha'i bu de dag rnga des bskul ba dang / yid du 'ong ba'i sgra 'di lta bu gang nas byung zhes ngo mtshar du 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /de nas yang rnga de nyid las sgra 'di skad du 'byung bar 'gyur te/ lha'i sras po dag /bdag ni lha'i rnga zhes bya ba ste/ dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs dang / shugs kyis grub pa'o/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ lha'i rnga kho bo ni bdag ces bya ba'i sgra brjod kyang bdag la bdag tu bya ba rgyu ba med do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyang / nga ni sangs rgyas zhes gsungs te/ de dag la bdag tu bya ba mi mnga'o/ /bdag gir bya ba mi mnga'o/ / lha'i sras po dag /

“The thousand-spoked wheels on the soles of my feet as an enlightening being were called king of universal light. They had an embellishment, called the foremost sphere, always emanating forty kinds of light, among them a light called pure virtue, illumining as many worlds as atoms in a hundred trillion buddha-lands, causing all sentient beings to develop maturity according to their various actions and inclinations. Sentient beings in excruciating pain in uninterrupted hell, encountering this light, were born in Tushita heaven after their lives ended. When they were born in heaven, they heard the sound of the celestial drum declare to them, ‘Very good! Godlings, the enlightening being Vairocana has entered undefiled concentration; you should pay respects.’ Then the godlings, hearing this exhortation from the sound of the celestial drum, thought, ‘How wonderful—what is the cause of this subtle sound?’ Then the drum answered, ‘The sound I make is produced by the power of roots of goodness. Godlings, just as I speak of myself without attachment to self or to what is mine, so too do the buddhas say they are buddhas, yet have no attachment to “I” or “mine.”

'di lta ste/ dper na/ bdag gi sgra ni shar phyogs nas kyang ma 'ongs/ lho phyogs nas kyang ma yin/ nub phyogs nas kyang ma yin/ byang phyogs nas kyang ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi 'phrin las rnam par smin pa yang / shar phyogs nas ma 'ongs/ lho phyogs nas ma yin/ nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ khyed kyi sngon gyi mtha'i sems can dmyal ba rnams ni/ shar phyogs nas ma 'ongs/ lho phyogs nas ma yin/ nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs pa med do/ /'on kyang phyin ci log gi las byed pa gti mug gi dra ba can rnams la lus su snang ba mi 'byung ba'ang ma yin te/ de dag kyang rtsa ba med cing gnas med pa'o/ /byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad kyi mthus snang ba chen po 'byung ba'i 'od zer de dag kyang shar phyogs nas ma 'ongs/ lho phyogs nas ma yin/ nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du bdag kyang lha'i rnga ting nge 'dzin dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa dbyangs rnam par dag pa'i mthus byung ba ste; cho 'phrul gyi rnam pa 'di 'dra ba dag ston to/ /

Just as my sound does not come from the east or from the west, the south, the north, or the intermediate directions or the zenith or nadir, in the same way the achievement of buddhahood as a consequence of actions does not come from any of the ten directions. It is as when you were in hell before: the hell and your bodies did not come from any of the ten directions; it was only due to your deluded evil deeds and bondage by folly that you were incarnated in hell—this has no basis, it does not come from anywhere. The enlightening being Vairocana, by spiritual power, emanated great light, yet this light did not come from any of the ten directions; in the same way, my sound does not come from any of the ten directions—it is just the power of good roots of concentration and by the spiritual power of transcendent wisdom that produces this pure sound and manifests these various abilities.

lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ ri'i rgyal po ri rab 'di ni shar phyogs nas ma 'ongs/ lho phyogs nas ma yin/ nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'on kyang sum cu rtsa gsum pa'i lha rnams longs spyod pa dang / yongs su spyod pa dang / bde ba'i rim gro'i phyir rnam pa 'di lta bus nye bar gnas so/ /lha'i sras po dag /bdag kyang lha'i rnga ste/ de bzhin du mkhyen par mdzod cig /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing bye ba khrag khrig gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed cig thams cad rdul shin tu phra mor blags te/ rdul phra mo ji snyed byung ba de snyed kyi sems can zhig yongs su brtag pa nye bar bzung ste/ tshogs shing 'dus par gyur kyang / bdag ni de dag thams cad bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du legs par bshad pas tshim par byed de/ bdag la skyo ba'am/ nyam chung bar 'gyur ba'am/ dregs pa'am/ rlom pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad dri ma dang bral ba'i ting nge 'dzin la bzhugs pa'i phyag g.yas pa'i mthil gyi dpe byad bzang po gcig las/ 'od zer gcig byung ba yang / de snyed du rnam par 'phrul zhing 'byung ste/ de ni nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas rnams kyis kyang shes par dka' na/ sems can rnams kyis lta ci smos/ lha'i sras po dag /legs so/ /legs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' blta ba'i don du bzhud cig /nye bar bzhud cig /bsnyen bkur mdzod cig /bsten par mdzod cig /dge ba'i rtsa ba dag gi bar chad du gyur ta re/

Just as Sumeru, the polar mountain, has thirty-three celestial palaces of exalted splendor, with various appurtenances that do not come from any of the ten directions, likewise my sound does not come from any of the ten directions. Just as I teach as many sentient beings as there are atoms in a trillion worlds, each in accord with their inclinations, causing them great joy, yet do not get tired of them or shrink from them, and I do not become proud or heedless, so also does the enlightening being Vairocana do the same, while abiding in undefiled concentration. From one embellishment on his right palm he emanates one ray of light that manifests innumerable magical powers such as even individually liberated ones cannot know, much less sentient beings. You should go to that enlightening being and attend and serve him. Do not indulge in the pleasures of the senses anymore — attachment to sensual desires obstructs roots of goodness.

lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na; bskal pa'i me byung ba'i tshe/ ri'i rgyal po ri rab lta bu yang rmeg med par mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du 'dod chags kyis kun nas 'khor ba'i sems su gyur na; sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa rnam par dgod pa tsam yang med par 'gyur gyi de'i phyir/ lha'i sras po dag /khyed kyis drin du gzo bar mdzod la drin du mi gzo ba med par mdzod cig/ lha'i bu byas pa mi dran pa dag ni/ lha ma yin gyi g.yul du phal cher gzhan gyis bsad cing 'chi bar 'gyur te/ 'di nas shi 'phos nas kyang drin du mi gzo ba'i sems can de dag ni/ phal cher sems can dmyal bar 'dong bar 'gyur ro/ /lha'i sras po dag /khyed 'od zer chen po snang ba gang gi mthus sems can dmyal ba de dag nas shi 'phos te 'dir skyes par gyur pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba de nyid rgya cher yongs su bsngo ba mdzod cig /lha'i sras po dag /lha'i rnga bdag ni bud med ma yin/ skyes pa ma yin te/ bsod nams kyi spyod pa brgya phrag 'di snyed kyang yongs su brjod do/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di na lha'i bu dang / lha'i bu mo dag gi longs spyod gzhal med khang gi longs spyod dam/ bza' shing gi ra ba'i longs spyod gang yod pa de dag kyang mtshan nyid de lta bur blta'o/ /lha'i sras po dag /ji ltar bdag ma skyes ma 'gags pa de bzhin du/ gzugs dang / tshor ba dang / 'du shes dang / 'du byed dang / rnam par shes pa dag kyang ma skyes ma 'gags par mkhyen par mdzod cig /lha'i sras po dag / 'di ni ting nge 'dzin gnas med pa'i phyag rgya zhes bya ba la 'jug par rtogs par mdzod cig /de nas lha'i bu de dag ngo mtshar dang rmad du gyur te/ me tog gi sprin stong phrag bcu dang / spos kyi sprin stong phrag bcu dang / rol mo'i sprin stong phrag bcu dang / rgyal mtshan gyi sprin stong phrag bcu dang / gdugs kyi sprin stong phrag bcu dang / bstod pa'i sprin stong phrag bcu dag mngon par sprul te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad kyi gzhal med khang gang na bar der dong ste phyin nas kyang / gzhal med khang la phyag 'tshal zhing / gnas par gyur kyang byang chub sems dpa' de ma mthong ba dang / lha'i bu la la 'di skad ces zer te/ kye grogs po dag /byang chub sems dpa' de ni lha yul 'di nas shi 'phos te/ mi'i 'jig rten du rgyal po zas gtsang ma'i khyim du lha mo sgyu ma'i sku na tsan dan gyi khang pa brtsegs pa yod par brdzus te skyes kyi/ lha'i bu dag /lha'i mig gis legs par ltos shig ces nas/ de dag gis bltas pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' de tshangs pa'i ris kyi lha'i bu rnams dang / de bzhin du 'dod pa la spyod pa'i lha'i bu thams cad kyis mchod cing rim gror byas te/ de na 'dug pa mthong ngo/ /
de nas lha'i bu de dag 'di snyam du gyur te/ bdag cag gis byang chub sems dpa' de ma mthong ngam/ de dang ma smras te/ bag dbab pa ma tho ba na/ sems skad cig tu yang dga' ldan gyi gnas na 'khod par dga' ba'i sems bskyed pa'i mi cha'i/ /'dzam bu'i gling du mi 'dong du mi rung ngo zhes nas/ lha'i bu de dag re re zhing yang lha'i bu mo bye ba phrag bcu'i 'khor dang bcas te 'dong bar byas pa dang / lha'i bu de dag gis de ltar 'dod pa'i sems bskyed ma thag tu lha'i rnga de las sgra 'byung ba/ lha'i sras po dag /byang chub sems dpa' de ni skye ba'ang med/ shi 'pho ba'ang med de/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po dag ni/ shi 'pho ba med pa'i mngon par shes pa dang ldan pa dag ste/ de dag ni sems can rnams kyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du/ mig lam du snang bar 'gyur ro/ /

Just as the world-ending holocaust completely burns away the polar mountain, so also does craving bind up the mind and prevent it from developing the will to remember Buddha. You should be grateful for your blessings and requite the favor you have received. Many ingrates meet untimely deaths and are reborn in hell. You were formerly in hell, when your bodies were illumined with light and you left there and were reborn here. You should now quickly rededicate and increase your roots of goodness. Just as I, the heavenly drum, am not male or female, yet can produce measureless, boundless, inconceivable things, so too you gods and goddesses are not male or female yet are able to enjoy all kinds of sublime palaces and groves. Just as my heavenly drum is not born and does not perish, the same is true of material form, sensation, perception, action, and consciousness. If you can understand this, know that you will then enter the concentration defined by independence.’
“The godlings, having heard this message, realized unprecedented wonder. Then they all magically produced myriad clouds of flowers, fragrances, music, banners, parasols, and eulogies, and went together to the palace where the enlightening being Vairocana was staying. Joining their palms in respect, they stood to one side and wished to behold him, but they could not see him. The godlings then said, ‘The enlightening being Vairocana has already passed away from here and been born in the human world, in the house of King Shuddhodana. He has mounted the sandalwood bower and is in the womb of Lady Maya.’
Then the godlings, by means of the celestial eye, saw the body of the enlightening being in the family of the king Shuddhodana in the human realm, being attended by gods of the Brahma heavens and heavens of desire. The godlings then thought, ‘If we do not go to the enlightening being and pay our respects, and should give rise to even a single thought of attachment to these celestial palaces, that would not be right.’
“Then each of the godlings, with a retinue of a hundred million, was going to go down to earth. At that point the celestial drum produced a voice telling them, ‘The great enlightening being has not ended his life here and been reborn there: it is just that he has, by spiritual power, caused sentient beings to perceive him according to their psychological needs.

lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ bdag ni khyed kyi mig gi lam gyis mi mthong ste/ mig gi lam las 'das kyang lha'i sras po khyed la sgra brjod do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du byang chub sems dpa'i ting nge 'dzin dri ma dang bral ba la mnyam par bzhag pa ni mig gis snang ba ma yin yang / skye ba'i skye mched thams cad du snang ste/ 'on kyang byang chub sems dpa' la rtog pa med do/ /rnam par rtog pa med do/ /g.yo ba med do/ /sems pa med do/ /de bas na/ lha'i sras po dag /khyed kyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed la bsam pa yongs su sbyong ste/ spyod pa la mnos la las kyi sgrib pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa dang / rnam par smin pa'i sgrib pa dang / lta ba'i sgrib pa bshags par gyis te/ lus kyi las dang / ngag gi las dang / yid kyi las kun tu bzang po chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pas sems can gyi khams su ming dang lus byin gyis rlobs shig ;sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i lus kyis/ sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i mgo byin gyis rlobs shig /sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i mgos sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i lce byin gyis rlobs shig /sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i lces sgrib pa de dag nyes pa la nyes par shogs shig /de skad ces brjod pa dang / lha'i bu de dag ngo mtshar dang rmad du gyur te/ rab tu dga' zhing sems bde bar gyur nas/ yang lha'i rnga de la byang chub sems dpa' rnams sdig pa 'chags pa'i rnam pa ji lta bu zhig yod ces phyir 'dri'o/ /
de nas lha'i rnga de byang chub sems dpa' de'i ting nge 'dzin gyi byin rlabs dang / lha'i bu de dag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs dang / byin gyi rlabs kyis rnam pa 'di lta bu'i sgra 'byin to/ /lha'i sras po dag /las ni shar phyogs nas 'ongs te/ sems la gnas pa ma yin/ 'dug pa ma yin/ tshogs su bsags pa ma yin/ phung por gyur pa ma yin te/ lho phyogs nas ma yin/ nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin/ las de ni phyogs bcu kun nas kyang 'ongs te gnas pa ma yin no/ /de ltar de ni byang chub sems dpas phyin ci log las byung ba ste/ gnas med par yang dag par shes pas de'i phyir de la 'gyod pa med do/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ lha'i rnga bdag ni las kyi rnam par smin pa ji lta ba dang; spyod pa ji lta ba dang / tshul khrims ji lta ba dang / dga' ba ji lta ba dang / shin tu byang ba ji lta ba dang / ting nge 'dzin ji lta ba bzhin du bdag ces brjod do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams dang / byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyang bdag ces bya ba'am/ bdag gi zhes bya ba'am/ sems can zhes bya bar gsung brjod cing / 'dod chags dang / zhe sdang dang / gti mug dang / las dang / bya ba'i gsung yang brjod de/ lha'i sras po dag /bdag ces bya ba med do/ /bdag med par bdag gi zhes bya ba mi dmigs so; ;de dag gi las kyi rnam pa lam gyi rgyud drug tu rnam par smin par 'gyur bar byas pa de dag kyang shar phyogs nas mi dmigs so/ /lho phyogs nas ma yin; nub phyogs nas ma yin/ byang phyogs nas ma yin te/ phyogs bcu kun nas kyang dmigs par mi rung ngo/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ bdag gi sgra ni lha'i bu yongs su ma dag pa rnams kyi rna lam du mi 'gro bas/ sems can dmyal ba rnams bskul kyang thos par mi 'gyur te/ sgra de ni ma skyes ma 'gags pa'o/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du las thams cad kyang ma skyes ma 'gags pa ste/ ji ltar yongs su sbyangs pa dang / ji ltar bsags pa'i tshul du 'bras bu'ang rnam par smin par byed de/ lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ bdag gi sgra ni bskal pa khrag khrig tu brjod kyang rnam par rtog pa med pas zad pa med do/ /thug pa med do/ /'gro ba med do/ /'ong ba med do/ /lha'i sras po dag /gang la 'gro ba dang / 'ong ba yod pa de dag la ni rtag pa'am chad pa dag kyang yod par snang ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni ldem po ngag gis sems can smin par mdzad pa'i don du ston pa ma gtogs par rtag pa'am chad pa'i chos ston pa mi mdzad do/ /

Just as I now am not visible to the eye, yet can produce a voice, so also the great enlighening being, in undefiled concentration, is not visible to the eye, yet can appear to be born anywhere, without vain discrimination, free from conceit, without attachments. You should arouse the determination for unexcelled, complete perfect enlightenment, purify your minds, lead well-behaved lives, and repent of and get rid of all obstructions due to past actions, obstructions due to afflictions, obstructions due to retribution, and obstructions due to views; with bodies as many as beings in the cosmos, with tongues as many as beings in the cosmos, with good deeds of body, speech, and mind as many as beings in the cosmos, repent of and get rid of all obstructions and faults.’
“The godlings, hearing this, attained unprecedented wonder and were very joyful. They asked, ‘How does the great enlightening being repent of and get rid of all faults?’ The celestial drum, by the power of roots of goodness of concentration of the enlightening being, said, ‘The enlightening being knows that conditioning acts do not come from any particular location, yet they accumulate and dwell in the mind. They come only from delusion and have no abode. The enlightening being clearly sees this with certainty and has no doubt or confusion. Just as I, the celestial drum, speak of actions and consequences, of practice and discipline, of joy and peace, and of various concentrations, so do buddhas and enlightening beings speak of “I” and “mine,” speak of sentient beings, of covetousness, wrath, and delusion and their various actions, yet there really is no self or possession—all actions performed, the resulting consequences of the six paths of transmigration, cannot be found wherever you may seek. Just as my voice is not born and does not perish, while the celestials who do evil do not hear my voice but the voice waking them up by means of hell, so also are all actions neither born nor perishing, while according to their practice and accumulation their consequences are experienced. My drum sound is eternally inexhaustible and uninterrupted, and neither coming nor going can be apprehended in it; if there were coming or going, there would be extinction and permanence—the buddhas never say there is extinction or permanence, except as an expedient to develop sentient beings.

lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ sgra de ni bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams tshad med par dbyangs kyis go bar byed do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyang sems can rnams kyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du mngon du ston pa mdzad do/ /lha'i sras po dag / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ shel gyi me long gi dkyil 'khor sgron ma zhes bya ba/ 'jig rten gyi khams bcu'i chad dang mnyam pa dag cing gsal la mdog shin tu bzang ba yod de/ de la 'jig rten gyi khams tshad med pa dag nas kyang / ri thams cad kyi gzugs brnyan dang / sems can de dag thams cad kyi gzugs brnyan yang rab tu snang na/ lha'i sras po dag/ de la ji snyam du sems/ de ltar me long gi dkyil 'khor de la/ sems can dmyal ba pa dang / byol song gi skye gnas pa dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten pa'i sems can mang po snang bas yongs su ma dag par mi 'gyur ram/ lus shin tu mi sdug par gnas pa de dag kyang / me long de la 'phos pa'am/ gnas pa'am/ sems dang ldan par gyur pa yod dam med/ smras pa/ de lta bu ni med do/ /smras pa/ lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du las rnams kyang 'pho ba yang med/ 'gro ba yang med/ gnas pa yang med de/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par smin pa yang mi snang ba ma yin no/ / 'di lta ste/ dper na/ sgyu mas ni mig bslu ba byed do/ /lha'i sras po dag /de bzhin du gang gis las rnams shes te/ mthong ba dang / khong du chud pa de dag gi sdig pa bshags pa ni shin tu rnam par dag par 'gyur ro/ /shin tu bstan pa 'di bstan pa'i tshe/ 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi dga' ldan gnas kyi lha'i bu de dag thams cad mi skye ba'i chos la bzod pa rab tu thob par gyur to/ /'dod pa la spyod pa'i lha'i ris drug gi lha'i bu tshad med grangs med bsam gyis mi khyab pa dag gis kyang / bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed do/ /'dod pa la spyod pa'i lha'i ris drug po de dag gi lha'i bu mo rnams kyang bud med kyi lus de las gyur te/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu nges par gyur to/ /de nas lha'i bu de dag gis kun tu bzang po'i yongs su bsngo bas rgya cher bshags te/ sa bcu 'thob pa dang / ting nge 'dzin stobs kyi rgyan yongs su 'thob pa'i don du/ sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i lus kyi las dang / ngag gi las dang; yid kyi las kyi rgya cher bshags pa byas nas/ de dag las kyi sgrib pa rnam par dag pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong / rin po che sna bdun gyi pad+mo rdul shin tu phra ba snyed las 'khod cing 'od chen po rab tu gtong ba mthong bar gyur te/ de dag gi dpe byad bzang po re re nas kyang sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i 'od zer mang po byung ste; 'od zer de dag la yang sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa bzhugs shing / sems can rnams la bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du chos ston pa mthong bar gyur kyang / de tsam gyis ting nge 'dzin dri ma dang bral ba'i spyod yul gyi cha shas tsam yang legs par mthong bar ma gyur to/ /de nas lha'i bu de dag gis me tog gi sprin la sogs pa snga ma de dag dang / ba spu'i bu ga re re nas kyang sems can gyi khams dang mnyam pa'i me tog gi sprin mngon par sprul te/ byang chub sems dpa' rnam par snang mdzad dang / de de bzhin gshegs pa mtha' yas pa la mchod pa byed par gyur to/ /me tog ji snyed cig gtor ba de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku gzugs su gnas par gyur to/ /spos kyi sprin gyi char rab tu phab pa de dag gis 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing tshad med pa'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed du sems can gang gis lus la bab pa de dag kyang /

Just as my sound makes itself available to beings in infinite worlds according to their mentalities, so do all buddhas make themselves visible according to the mentalities of beings. Suppose there is a glass mirror called “reflector,” clearly reflecting, equal in size to ten worlds, with the images of all the mountains and rivers, and all the sentient beings, including in the hells, the animals and ghosts, all reflected therein—what do you think, can you say those images enter and exit the mirror?’ The godlings answered, ‘No.’ ‘All actions are also like this; though they can produce resulting consequences, there is no place they come or go. Just as a magician deceives people’s eyes by illusion, so do actions also do the same. If you know this, this is true repentance of all evils so that all are cleared.’
“When this teaching was spoken, the Tushita godlings in worlds as numerous as atoms in ten quintillion buddha-lands attained acceptance of the nonorigination of all things; immeasurable, inconceivable infinities of godlings of the six heavens of the realm of desire were inspired to seek unexcelled, complete perfect enlightenment; all the goddesses of the heavens of the desire realm relinquished the female body and became determined to attain supreme enlightenment. Then the godlings, because of attaining the ten stages on hearing the tremendous dedication of Universal Good told, because of attaining concentration adorned by various powers, and because of repenting of and clearing away all serious hindrances by means of pure physical, verbal, and mental actions equal in number to living beings, thereupon saw lotus blossoms made of all precious substances, as many blossoms as atoms in ten quintillion buddha-lands, with an enlightening being sitting on each blossom emanating great beams of light; in those beams of light were as many buddhas as there are living beings, sitting in the lotus posture expounding the teaching in accordance with the mentalities of sentient beings—yet still not even a little of the power of undefiled concentration was as yet manifested.
“Then the godlings, by means of the flowers and other things they had produced before, again magically produced in each pore of their bodies as many clouds of fine flowers and so on as there are living beings, to offer to the realized one Vairocana, and took them and scattered them on the Buddha; all of them hovered over the Buddha’s body while the fragrant clouds rained over worlds as many as atoms in countless buddha-lands. Any sentient beings who were enveloped in that fragrance became physically peaceful and blissful,

like a mendicant who has entered the fourth stage of meditation, in whom all obstructions due to past actions vanish. Sentient beings have five hundred internal afflictions and five hundred external afflictions relating to form, sound, smell, flavor, and tactile feeling; those rife with covetousness have 21,000, those rife with anger have 21,000, those rife with delusion have 21,000, and those equally habituated to all three also have 21,000 — but if they smell this fragrance, they realize that all these are unreal. Once they realize this, they develop pure roots of goodness with the light of mystic power, like clouds of fragrant banners.
“Those who see the canopies produced by the enlightening beings plant the innumerable roots of goodness of universal monarchs of the pure gold net of the tenth stage of enlightening. When enlightening beings are in this status of universal monarch, they edify beings in worlds as numerous as atoms in ten quintillion buddha-lands. In the case of the buddha called Knowledge Like the Moon, of the world called Clear Mirror, there are always monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, and others from countless worlds who project their bodies to come listen to the Teaching; that buddha, without a moment’s pause, relates to them the events of former lives. Any sentient beings who hear the name of the buddha will surely be reborn in the land of the Buddha. That case of enlighening beings in the rank of universal monarch with the pure golden net is also like this: any who encounter their light will surely attain the tenth stage of enlightening beings, because of the power of roots of goodness previously cultivated. When one has attained the first meditation, though one’s life has not yet ended, one can see the palaces in the Brahma heaven and can experience the bliss of the Brahma world; likewise those who attain the other stages of meditation. The great enlightening beings in the rank of universal monarch with the pure golden net radiate pure light such that any beings who are touched by it all gain the tenth stage of enlightening and attain immeasurable light of knowledge, acquire ten kinds of pure eyes, ten kinds of pure ears, noses, tongues, bodies, and ten kinds of pure intellects; they accomplish immeasurable profound concentrations and achieve such a pure physical eye.
“Suppose someone took ten trillion buddha-lands and reduced them to atoms, and then reduced to atoms as many buddha-lands as those atoms, then put all those atoms in his left hand and carried them past an equal number of worlds to the east, and then put down one atom, and continued this way to the east until all the atoms were exhausted, and did the same in the other nine directions: if all the worlds in the ten directions, both those in which he had deposited an atom and those in which he had not, were all assembled to form a single buddha-land, do you think that the immeasurable vastness of this buddha-land would be conceivable or not?”
Jewel Hand said, “It would not be conceivable. The enormous size of such a land would be immeasurable, extraordinary, inconceivable. If any sentient beings heard this comparison and believed and understood it, that would be even more extraordinary.”

bka' stsal pa/ lag na rin po che/ de de bzhin no/ /de de bzhin te/ lag na rin po che khyod kyis ji skad du smras pa bzhin no/ /lag na rin po che/ rigs kyi bu dang / rigs kyi bu mo de dag ni ngas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu lung bstan pa de lta bu dag ni/ sangs rgyas kyi ye shes thob par 'gyur to/ /red do/ /'gyur ro/ /

The Buddha said, “This is so, Jewel Hand. It is as you say. If any good man or woman should hear this example and believe in it, I would give them the prediction that they will certainly attain unexcelled, complete perfect enlightenment and will acquire the unsurpassed knowledge of buddhas.

lag na rin po che/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing bye ba phrag stong gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing ji snyed pa de snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing gi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing dper rnam par bkod pa de dag thams cad kyang / rdul shin tu phra bar blags la/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing re re zhing yang sangs rgyas kyi zhing de dag na/ rdul shin tu phra ba ji snyed yod pa de snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing zhig yod par gyur te/ zhing de dag na ji lta ba de bzhin du zhing thams cad na'ang de snyed cig yod par gyur ba/ rdul de dag thams cad kyang tshul de bzhin du bkod de/ rnam grangs 'di 'dra bar rdul shin tu phra bar dgod pa'i tshul gyis lan brgyad cur bsgres te/ rdul gyi 'bru re re la yang zhing thams cad kyi rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi 'bras bu mngon par grub par gyur kyang / de dag thams cad byang chub sems dpa'i sha'i mig gis bsgribs pa med par mthong ste/ lag na rin po che/ byang chub sems dpa'i sha'i mig las kyi rnam par smin pas yongs su grub pa des ni/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing khrag khrig brgya'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi de bzhin gshegs pa sems skad cig gis mthong ste/ de ni 'jig rten gyi khams bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi 'jig rten gyi khams la dbang sgyur zhing 'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal po'i sa gser gyi dra bas dag pa thob pa'i bsod nams rnam par smin pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / ting nge 'dzin gyis yongs su grub pa'i shel gyi me long sgron ma zhes bya ba mdog dag ste/ bzang zhing gsal ba bzhin no/ /

“Suppose again, Jewel Hand, that someone reduced to atoms as many enormous buddha-lands of the magnitude described above as atoms in a hundred billion buddha-lands, and deposited each of these atoms, as in the foregoing example, and all of these worlds, those on which an atom was deposited as well as those in between, were united in a single buddha-land. Then again suppose this buddha-land were reduced to atoms, and so on, repeating this process eighty times: the enlightening being’s pure physical eye, a consequence of action, can clearly see in a single instant every particle in all those immense buddha-lands, and also see buddhas as numerous as atoms in ten billion immense buddha-lands, just as the pure light of the crystal mirror reflects as many worlds as atoms in ten buddha-lands. Jewel Hand, all this is accomplished by the virtues of the most profound concentration of the universal monarch of the pure gold net.”
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ dpe byad bzang po'i 'od zer bstan pa'i le'u ste/ bzhi bcu rtsa gcig pa'o// //
[42. kun tu bzang po'i spyod pa bstan pa'i le'u]
BOOK THIRTY-SIX. The Practice of Universal Good
bam po drug cu dgu pa/

de nas yang byang chub sems dpa' kun tu bzang pos/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag la smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ni sems can gyi snod ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la dmigs te/ rdul tsam zhig brjod du zad do/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /sems can mi mkhas pa 'gyod pas kun nas non pa/ bdag dang bdag gir bya ba la mngon par zhen pa/ 'jig tshogs la shin tu chags pa/ phyin ci log la rab tu rten pa/ the tshom la rab tu gzhol ba/ log par lta ba yongs su rtog pas byung ba/ rmongs pas bsgrubs pa/ 'khor ba'i rgyud du gzhol ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i lam dang mi ldan pa rnams kyi don du sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams 'jig rten du 'byung ngo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / 'di lta ste/ byang chub sems dpa'i gzhan la zhe sdang bskyed pa tsam du kha na ma tho ba che ba'i chos ni 'ga' tsam yang bdag gis ma mthong ste/

AT THAT TIME the great enlightening being Universal Good also said to the great congregation of enlightening beings, “Offspring of Buddha, what has been expounded up till now is just a brief exposition of a little bit of the realm of buddhas, adapted so as to be appropriate to the faculties and capacities of sentient beings. Why? The buddhas emerge in the world because sentient beings are ignorant and do what is bad, they conceive of self and possessions, they cling to the body, they are deluded and confused, they discriminate on the basis of false views and are always in bondage, following the flow of birth and death away from the path of enlightenment.
“I do not see anything that is a bigger mistake than for enlightening beings to become angry at other enlightening beings.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /gzhan la khong khro ba bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni sgrib pa'i chos kyi sgo brgya stong phrag bcu po 'di dag yongs su 'dzin par 'gyur te/ brgya stong phrag bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ byang chub sems dpa' mi mthong ba 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /chos mi thos pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /'jig rten gyi khams kun nas nyon mongs par skye ba 'dzin par 'gyur 'gyur ro/ /byang chub sems dpa'i brtson 'grus chen po las mi ldog par bya ba la zhum pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /ting nge 'dzin mi 'thob pa'i 'khrug pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin sems dpa'i ye shes la rnam par mi dpyod pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /byang chub sems dpa'i chos kyis 'byung ba khong du mi chud pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /byang chub sems dpa'i mig 'byams klas pa bcu mi 'grub pa'i dmus long lta bu 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /sgrib pa med pa'i chos kyi rgyud mngon par sgrub pa la glen zhing lkugs pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /dbang po gzhan dang nor ba'i dbang po 'dzin pas sna yongs su /byang chub sems dpa'i ye shes kyi sgo snang ba rgyun 'chad pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /dran pa'i stobs dang shugs nyam chung ba 'dzin par 'gyur ro; ;de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan ba yongs su mi 'dzin pa sangs rgyas kyi skyon med pa yid kyis mchod pa 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i byang chub sems dpa'i tshul dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs dang ring ba 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar byang chub sems dpa' gcig la gcig ngan sems bskyed pa ni/ de dag la sogs pa sgrib pa'i chos kyi sgo brgya stong phrag bcu rnams 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /

Why? Because if enlightening beings become angry at other enlightening beings, that creates a million obstacles. What are those million obstacles? They are the obstacle of not seeing enlightenment, the obstacle of not hearing the true Teaching, the obstacle of being born in an impure world, the obstacle of being born in miserable states, the obstacle of being born in places where it is difficult to become enlightened, the obstacle of sickliness, the obstacle of being the object of much slander, the obstacle of being born stupid, the obstacle of loss of right mindfulness and recollection, the obstacle of lack of intelligence, obstacles of eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind, the obstacle of bad advisers, the obstacle of bad companions, the obstacle of inclination toward practice of individualistic liberation, the obstacle of inclination toward associating with the vulgar, the obstacle of not believing in people of great spiritual power, the obstacle of living with people who have strayed from correct perception, the obstacle of being born in a family of heretics, the obstacle of dwelling in the realm of demons, the obstacle of being estranged from the right Teaching of Buddha, the obstacle of not seeing good companions, the obstacle of blockage of roots of goodness, the obstacle of increase of bad conditions, the obstacle of meanness, the obstacle of being born in a remote area, the obstacle of being born in a family of evil people, the obstacle of being born among evil spirits, evil ghosts, hobgoblins, demons, titans, vipers, and so on, the obstacle of not caring for the Buddha teachings, the obstacle of habituation to infantile behavior, the obstacle of clinging to the small vehicle of individual salvation, the obstacle of not liking the Great Vehicle of universal salvation, the obstacle of fearfulness, the obstacle of anxiety, the obstacle of clinging to mundane routines, the obstacle of not concentrating on the way to enlightenment, the obstacle of not liking to see or hear of the spiritual powers of Buddha, the obstacle of not acquiring the faculties of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not applying the purifying practices of enlightening beings, the obstacle of shrinking from the determination of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not making the great vow of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not developing the determination for omniscience, the obstacle of slacking off from the practice of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not being able to purify acts, the obstacle of not being able to incorporate great virtues, the obstacle of the power of knowledge not being clear and keen, the obstacle of shutting off great wisdom and knowledge, the obstacle of not preserving the practices of enlightening beings, the obstacle of inclination to repudiate all words of wisdom, the obstacle of estrangement from the enlightenment of the buddhas, the obstacle of inclination to abide in the realms of demons, the obstacle of not concentrating on cultivating the realm of buddhahood, the obstacle of not definitively making the universal commitment of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not liking to live with enlightening beings, the obstacle of not seeking the roots of goodness of enlightening beings, the obstacle of being opinionated and suspicious, the obstacle of the continual befuddlement of the mind, the obstacle of being unwilling to give because of inability to practice the impartial generosity of enlightening beings, the obstacle of transgression of precepts by being unable to maintain the precepts of the Buddha, the obstacle of foolish malevolence and anger due to inability to achieve tolerance and forbearance, the obstacle of the defilement of laziness due to inability to act with the great vigor of enlightening beings, the obstacle of distraction and confusion due to inability to attain concentration, the obstacle of misused intellect due to failure to cultivate transcendent wisdom, the obstacle of lack of familiarity with what is so and what is not so, the obstacle of having no means to liberate beings, the obstacle of inability to contemplate the knowlege of enlightening beings, the obstacle of not knowing enlightening beings’ means of emancipation, the obstacle of failure to develop the ten great eyes of enlightening beings and therefore being as if blind, the obstacle of being dumb as an animal due to not hearing the teaching of nonobstruction, the obstacle of destruction of the nose due to not having the marks and embellishments of buddhahood, the obstacle of inability to understand speech and the consequent inability to speak, the obstacle of physical problems due to demeaning sentient beings, the obstacle of mental problems due to lack of control of mind, the obstacle of physical actions due to not keeping the precepts, the obstacle of verbal actions due to continually committing faults of speech, the obstacle of mental actions due to conceiving much covetousness, anger, and erroneous views, the obstacle of seeking the teaching with a thieving mind, the obstacle of cutting off the perspective of enlightening beings, the obstacle of shrinking from the effort of enlightening beings, the obstacle of laziness of mind on the enlightening beings’ way to emancipation, the obstacle of the mind stopping at the entry of the light of knowledge of enlightening beings, the obstacle of becoming weak-minded and incapable of the recollective power of enlightening beings, the obstacle of being unable to retain the teachings of the buddhas, the obstacle of being unable to approach enlightening beings’ path of detachment from birth, the obstacle of inability to cultivate the incorruptible path of enlightening beings, the obstacle of following the absolute state of one-sided detachment, the obstacle of estrangement from the family of the buddhas and enlightening beings of all times.
“If an enlightening being conceives a single feeling of anger toward enlightening beings, that produces a million obstacles such as these.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa la zhugs pa rnams ni/ phan tshun du ngan sems kyi sems bskyed pa lta bur kha na ma tho ba che ba'i chos 'ga' tsam yang ma mthong ngo/ /de bas na/ rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa myur du rdzogs par bya bar 'dod pa'i byang chub sems dpas chos bcu la brtson par bya'o/ /bcu gang zhe na/ sems can thams cad yongs su mi gtong ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la ston pa'i sems su bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad mi spang ba dang / zhing thams cad la mi zad pa'i ye shes kyis 'jug pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa thams cad la mos pa dang / dad pa chen po dang / nam mkha'i dbyings kyis klas pa'i chos kyi dbyings mnyam pa nyid rnam par bsgoms pa'i byang chub kyi sems mi gtang ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i stobs la 'jug pas sangs rgyas kyi byang chub la rnam par dpyad pa dang / tha dad pa yang dag par shes pa la brtson par bya ba dang / sems can thams cad yongs su smin par bya bas yongs su mi skyo ba dang / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gnas pa la mngon par chags pa med pa ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpas chos bcu po de dag la mngon par brtson par bya'o/ /de chos bcu po de dag la gnas pas rnam par dag par byed ba'i chos bcu rab tu 'thob ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ chos zab mo la 'jug pa rnam par dag pa dang / dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang 'grogs pa rnam par dag pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa yongs su bzung ba rnam par dag pa dang / nam mkha'i dbyings rnam par sgom pa rnam par dag pa dang / chos kyi dbyings la 'jug pa rnam par dag pa dang / mtha' dang dbus med pa'i sems rnam par dpyad pa rnam par dag pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyis grogs bya ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par dag pa dang / bskal pa thams cad la mngon par chags pa med pa rnam par dag pa dang / dus gsum thams cad rab tu brtags pa rnam par dag pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rigs su nan tan du bya ba rnam par dag pa ste/ rnam par dag par byed pa'i chos bcu po de dag rab tu 'dzin to/ /de de lta bu'i chos bcu po de dag la gnas pas/ ye shes 'byams klas pa bcu la 'jug par 'gyur te/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sems can thams cad kyi sems dang spyod pa la 'jug pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad kyi las kyi rnam par smin pa rab tu phye ba la 'jug pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad la ye shes snang bas 'jug pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi tshul dang ldem po dag la ye shes kyis 'jug pa dang / gzungs kyi sgo thams cad la ye shes kyis 'jug pa dang / yi ge thams cad la spobs pa'i ye shes kyis 'jug pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi skad dang / tha snyad dang / tshig la mkhas pa'i ye shes la 'jug pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du lus bstan pa'i ye shes la 'jug pa dang / 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad du gzugs brnyan 'byung ba bstan pa'i ye shes la 'jug pa dang / skye mched thams cad du thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes la 'jug pa ste/ ye shes 'byams klas pa bcu po de dag rab tu 'dzin to/ /de de ltar ye shes 'byams klas pa bcu la rab tu gnas pas yang dag par gzud pa la 'jug pa bcu 'thob ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad skra'i sbubs su gzud pa la 'jug cing / skra'i sbubs gcig 'jig rten gyi khams bsam gyis mi khyab par mngon par sgrub pa la 'jug pa dang / sems can thams cad kyi lus sems can gcig gi lus su bsdu zhing / sems can gcig gi lus brjod du med pa'i lus su mngon par bsgrub pa la 'jug pa dang / bskal pa brjod du med pa sems kyi skad cig tu gzud pa la 'jug cing / sems kyi skad cig brjod du med pa'i bskal par 'jug pa bstan pa dang / chos gcig sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad du yang dag par gzhol ba la 'jug cing / sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad chos gcig tu gzud pa la 'jug pa dang / skye mched gcig brjod du med pa'i skye mched du bya ste/ brjod du med pa'i skye mched du bya ba la 'jug cing / skye mched brjod du med pa skye mched gcig tu bstan pa la 'jug pa dang / dbang po gcig brjod du med pa'i dbang por bya ba la 'jug cing / dbang po brjod du med pa dbang po gcig tu gzud pa la 'jug pa dang / dbang po thams cad dbang po med pa dang / tha mi dad par 'jug cing / dbang po med pa dbang por bya ba la 'jug pa dang / 'du shes thams cad 'du shes gcig tu byin gyis brlab pa la 'jug cing / 'du shes gcig 'du shes thams cad du byin gyis brlab pa la 'jug pa dang / tshig gcig rnam par brjod pa tshig brjod du med pa rnam par brjod pa bya ba la 'jug cing / tshig rnam par brjod pa thams cad sgra gcig gi dbyangs su byin gyis brlab pa la 'jug pa dang / dus gsum thams cad bsam gtan gcig tu bsdu ste/ bsam gtan gcig po dus thams cad du kun tu spro bar bstan pa la 'jug pa ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /yang dag par gzud pa bcu po de dag sems kyi bsam pa bcu la gnas te/ rnam par dpyad par bya'o/ /bcu gang zhe na/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi spyod pa la mi spyod pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad kyi 'du shes dang / yid la byed pa la mi gnas pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa nam mkha'i dbyings kyis klas pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / chos kyi dbyings mtha' dang dbus med pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi dgongs pa la mkhas pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / chos zab mo tha mi dad pa la mkhas pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / dogs pa thams cad la lan med par bya ba'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / dus thams cad tha mi dad cing mnyam pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas thams cad mnyam pa nyid kyi sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa dang / sangs rgyas thams cad kyi stobs tshad med pa'i sems kyi bsam pa la gnas pa ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /sems kyi bsam pa bcu po de dag la gnas te; byang chub sems dpas yang dag par gzud pa bcu po de dag rnam par dpyad par bya'o/ /de sems kyi bsam pa bcu po de dag la gnas pas/ sangs rgyas kyi chos la mkhas pa'i snang ba bcu 'thob bo/ /bcu gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sangs rgyas kyi chos zab mo snang ba la mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos yangs pa mngon par sgrub pa la mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos sna tshogs shin tu bstan pa la mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos mnyam pa nyid la 'jug pa la mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos tha dad pa'i snang ba la 'jug par mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos tha mi dad pa la 'jug par mkhas pa rab tu 'thob po/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi rgyan la 'jug par mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi tshul gcig pa'i mos pa la 'jug par mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos mtha' yas pa'i tshul la 'jug par mkhas pa rab tu 'thob bo/ /sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad rang gi sems la rag lus pas rang gi stobs dang mthu phyir mi ldog pa la mkhas pa rab tu 'thob ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /sangs rgyas kyi chos la mkhas pa'i snang ba bcu po de dag rab tu 'thob bo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de bas na byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos chos de dag thos nas/ rim gro dang / zhe sa chen po'i bsam pas gzung bar bya'o/ /

Why? I do not see anything that is as big a mistake as for enlightening beings to become angry at other enlightening beings. Therefore, if great enlightening beings want to quickly fulfill the practices of enlightening beings, they should diligently practice ten principles: in their minds they should not abandon sentient beings; they should think of enlightening beings as buddhas; they should never slander any teachings of the buddhas, they should know that there is no end to different lands; they should be profoundly devoted to enlightening practices; they should not give up the cosmic, spacelike, impartial mind of enlightenment; they should contemplate enlightenment and enter the power of buddhas; they should cultivate unobstructed intellectual and expository powers; they should teach and enlighten beings tirelessly; they should live in all worlds without attachment in their minds.
“When great enlightening beings are living by these ten principles, they are able to embody ten kinds of purity. What are these ten? Purity of comprehension of the most profound truth; purity of association with good associates; purity of preserving the Buddha teachings; purity of comprehension of the realm of space; purity of profound penetration of the realm of reality; purity of observation of infinite minds; purity of having the same roots of goodness as all enlightening beings; purity of nonattachment to the various ages; purity of observation of past, present, and future; purity of practice of all enlightening teachings.
“When great enlightening beings persist in these ten things, they become imbued with ten kinds of broad knowledge: that is, knowledge of all sentient beings’ mental behavior; knowledge of the consequences of actions of all sentient beings; knowledge of all Buddha teachings; knowledge of the profound, occult import of all Buddha teachings; knowledge of all methods of concentration spells; knowledge of interpretation of all writings; knowledge of the language and speech of all sentient beings; knowledge of manifestation of their bodies in all worlds, knowledge of manifestation of their reflections in all assemblies; knowledge of embodying omniscience in all realms of being.
“Once great enlightening beings are established in this knowledge, they realize ten kinds of universal entry: all worlds enter one point, one point enters all worlds; all beings’ bodies enter one body, one body enters all beings’ bodies; untold eons enter one instant, one instant enters untold eons; all Buddhist principles enter one principle, one principle enters all Buddhist principles; untold places enter one place, one place enters all places; untold faculties enter one faculty, one faculty enters untold faculties; all faculties enter nonfaculty, nonfaculty enters all faculties; all perceptions enter one perception, one perception enters all perceptions; one utterance enters all utterances, all utterances enter one utterance; all pasts, presents, and futures enter one time frame, one time frame enters all pasts, presents, and futures.
“Once great enlightening beings have contemplated in this way, they abide in ten kinds of sublime mind: the sublime mind in which none of the perceptions and thoughts of sentient beings can abide; the sublime mind of the ultimate realm of space; the sublime mind of the boundless cosmos; the sublime mind of all the profound esoteric principles of buddhahood; the sublime mind of the extremely profound state of nondifferentiation; the sublime mind annihilating all doubt and confusion; the sublime mind of the nondifferentiated equality of all worlds; the sublime mind of the equality of all buddhas of past, present, and future; the sublime mind of the infinity of the power of all buddhas.
“Once great enlightening beings abide in these ten kinds of sublime mind, they acquire ten kinds of technical knowlege of the Buddha teachings: technical knowledge comprehending the most profound Buddha teaching; technical knowledge of the production of far-reaching Buddha teachings; technical knowledge of exposition of all kinds of Buddha teachings; technical knowledge of realizing the Buddha teaching of equality; technical knowledge of understanding the Buddha teaching of differentiation; technical knowledge of understanding the Buddha teaching of nondifferentiation; technical knowledge of profound penetration of the Buddha teaching of adornment; technical knowledge of penetrating the Buddha teachings by one means; technical knowledge of penetrating the Buddha teachings by innumerable means; technical knowledge of nondifference of the boundless Buddha teachings; technical knowledge of nonregression in the Buddha teachings by one’s own mind and one’s own power.
“When great enlightening beings have heard this teaching, they should all be inspired and respectfully accept and hold it.

de ci'i phyir zhe na/ byang chub sems dpa' chos 'di la gnas pa la ni/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyang dkon pa ma yin te/ las gron chung ngus sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yang dag par 'grub pa'i byin gyi rlabs rab tu 'thob bo/ /'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das dang mnyam pa nyid du yang 'jug par 'gyur ro/ /de nas de'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi mthus/ 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing brjod du med pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed rnam pa drug tu rab tu g.yos so/ /sangs rgyas kyi mthu dang chos nyid rab tu thob pas lha rdzas las 'das pa'i me tog gi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas las 'das pa'i spos kyi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /gzhung de bzhin du phye ma dang / na bza' dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang; gdugs dang / nor bu rin po che dang / sprul gyi snying po'i tsan dan dang / rgyan dang lhab lhub thams cad kyi sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rol mo dkrol ba'i sprin dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rol mo brdung ba'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas las 'das pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i mchod pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas las 'das pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i yon tan gyi rnam par brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas las 'das pa'i de bzhin gshegs pas legs so zhes gsungs pa'i rnam par brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /lha rdzas la 'das shing chos kyi dbyings su rgyas par khyab pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung gi dbyangs mngon par brjod pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dag pa rnam par brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /byang chub nye bar brtan pa'i rnam par brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /'od zer snang ba'i rnam pa brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab bo/ /shin tu bstan pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyi char rnam pa brjod du med pa'i sprin gyi char mngon par bab ste/ ji ltar 'jig rten gyi khams 'di'i gling bzhi par/ de bzhin gshegs pa byang chub kyi shing drung du de bzhin gshegs pa mngon par 'tshang rgya ba'i snying po byang chub la byang chub sems dpa'i pho brang na bzhugs par snang ba de bzhin du/ phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa rgyas par gang bar bzhugs te/ chos bstan pa 'di'ang thams cad du byung ngo/ /sangs rgyas kyi mthu dang / phyogs bcur de bzhin gshegs pa mngon par sangs rgyas pa'i chos nyid rab tu thob pas/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing brjod du med pa phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing 'das pa'i pha rol nas/ byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyang 'ongs par gyur te/ phyogs bcu bkang nas de dag 'di skad zer ro/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i smon lam lung bstan pa'i chos nyid brjod pa legs so/ /legs so; ; kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bdag cag kyang thams cad kun tu bzang po zhes bya bar ming mthun par sha stag ste/ 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu dpal zhes bya ba dag nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan kun tu dpal gyi dbang phyug ces bya ba sha stag gi drung nas 'dir phyin te/ thams cad na yang chos bstan pa 'di nyid sangs rgyas kyi byin gyis 'khor gyi rnam pa 'di lta bu dag tu tshig 'di dag dang / yi ge 'di dag dang / go bar bya ba 'di dag dang / brjod pa 'di dag gis lhag chad med par byung bar gyur te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bdag cag kyang dbang du gyur pa sha stag; sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis 'khor 'dir phyin to/ /ji ltar bdag cag 'khor 'dir phyin pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa kun gyi de bzhin gshegs pa mngon par 'tshang rgya ba'i gzhir byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyis phyogs bcu bkang ste phyin par gyur to/ /de nas byang chub sems dpa' kun tu bzang pos phyogs bcur blta ste/ chos kyi dbyings la rnam par bltas nas byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rab tu brjod pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mngon par 'tshang rgya ba'i dbyings yongs su brtod pa dang / smon lam chen po'i dbyings kun tu grags par bya ba dang / 'jig rten gyi khams dang / bskal pa thams cad kyi grangs yongs su brjod pa dang / dus ji lta ba bzhin du sangs rgyas 'byung ba bstan pa dang / sems can gyi khams dang dbang po ji ltar yongs su smin pa'i tshul bzhin du sangs rgyas byung ba mnyes par bya ba brjod pa dang / byin gyis brlabs pa'i tshul bzhin du sangs rgyas 'byung ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyod pa don yod pa yongs su brjod par bya ba dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba ji ltar bskyed pa bzhin du gsal bar bya ba yang dag par bstan pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' mang po'i mthu chen po bstan pa dang / sems can thams cad la rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi sgras skul bar byed cing / dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs dang / shugs dang / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /

Why? Great enlightening beings who hold this teaching quickly attain unexcelled, complete perfect enlightenment with a minimum of effort, and all are enabled to embody all qualities of buddhahood, equal to the qualities of the buddhas of all times.”
Then, by the spiritual power of the Buddha as well as by natural law, in each of the ten directions as many worlds as atoms in ten unspeakable numbers of tens of quintillions of buddha-lands all quaked in six ways and rained showers from clouds of all flowers surpassing those of the heavens, as well as clouds of perfumes, incenses, robes, canopies, banners, pennants, jewels, and all kinds of decorations; there rained clouds of music, clouds of enlightening beings, clouds of physical forms of untold buddhas, clouds of infinite praises of the buddhas, clouds of voices of buddhas filling all universes, untold clouds of magically arrayed worlds, untold clouds developing enlightenment, untold clouds of light shining, and untold clouds of mystic manifestations expounding the Teaching.
As in this world, at the site of enlightenment, under the tree of enlightenment, in the palace of the enlightening being, the Buddha, the Completely Enlightened One, was seen expounding this teaching, so it was in all worlds in the ten directions.
Then, owing to the spiritual power of the Buddha as well as by natural law, there came to this land as many great enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands from each of the ten directions, from beyond as many worlds as atoms in ten infinities of buddha-lands. Filling the ten directions, they spoke these words to Universal Good: “It is very good, Offspring of Buddha, that you can explain this profound teaching of the giving of the prophecy of enlightenment, the greatest promise of the buddhas. We are all named Universal Good, the same as you, and each have come to this land from a world called Universal Excellence, from the company of buddhas called Freedom Representative of Universality. All, by the spiritual power of Buddha, expound this teaching, with such assemblies and such utterances, all equal, with neither increase nor decrease. We have all come to this enlightenment site by the Buddha’s spiritual power to be witnesses for you. As we innumerable enlightening beings serve as witnesses at this site of enlightenment, the same is so in all worlds in the ten directions.”
Then the great enlightening being Universal Good, by the spiritual power of the Buddha and by the power of his own roots of goodness, looked over the ten directions, throughout the cosmos; wishing to elucidate the practice of enlightening beings, to tell of the realm of enlightenment of the buddhas, to explain the realm of great vows, to explain the reckoning of ages of all worlds, to clarify the timely appearance of the buddhas, to explain how the buddhas develop beings according to their faculties, appearing to let them attend them, to make it clear that the effort of the buddhas’ appearance in the world is not wasted, to make it clear that roots of goodness that are planted will surely bear fruit, and to clarify how enlightening beings of great spiritual power manifest forms for all sentient beings to teach and enlighten them, spoke these verses:

thams cad shin tu dad sems kyis/ / sgrib pa ma lus thams cad rnam par bsal gyis la/ / yon tan 'byung gnas 'jig rten gtso bo yi/ / smon lam dam pa bshad kyi mnyan par gyis/ /
mkhas mchog skyes bu seng ge dag / spyad pa ci 'dra sngon spyad spyod par 'gyur ba'i rnams/ / byang chub sems dpa' gtso rnams kyi/ / spyod pa thams cad rim gyis brjod par bya/ /
'di la dpe med mchog rnams kyi/ / bskal pa'i grangs dang 'jig rten grangs dang chos bstan dang / / rgyal ba rnams kyi 'byung ba dag / yongs su brjod kyi dang ba'i yid kyis nyon/ /
de dag sngon chad smon lam gyis/ / sems can ji ltar sdug bsngal rnams las dgrol bya zhes/ / sems can rnams la phan pa'i phyir/ / 'jig rten sgron ma skye ba rnams kyang mthong / /
spyod pa ji ltar shes gyur te/ / gsung gi mchog rnams kun la mchod pa byas pas na/ / sangs rgyas mnyam pa nyid rnyed de/ / thams cad mkhyen nyid rab la mngon sangs rgyas/ /
sngon gyi mi yi seng ge rnams/ / sangs rgyas phyogs bcur 'od snang rab tu 'bar mdzad cing / / 'od zer dra ba rab 'gyed pas/ / phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten snang mdzad mthong gyur nas/ /
bdag cag rgyal ba'i yon tan gyis/ / brgyan pa'i 'jig rten sgron ma'i dam par 'gyur bas te/ / stobs bcu mnga' ba kun mkhyen par/ / mi yi seng ger bya zhes smon lam 'debs/ /
nged kyis sems can thams cad kyi/ / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug rab tu 'bar gyur pa'i/ / sdug bsngal rnams las rab bkrol te/ / ngan song thams cad yongs su gcad bya zhes/ /
'di 'dra'i smon lam rdzogs byas te/ / de nas dpa' ba chen po spyod pa rab la spyod/ / blo brtan phyir ldog mi 'gyur ba/ / stobs bcu rnams kyi chags med rab tu 'thob/ /
skyes bu seng ge gang rnams kyis; ; 'di 'dra'i smon lam sngar btab phyir ldog mi 'gyur bar/ / 'jig rten rnams na spyod mdzad pa/ / de dag don yod spyod pa brjod par bya/ /
bskal pa bzang po gcig la yang / / sangs rgyas stong grangs tshang bar kun kyang 'byung 'gyur te/ / kun tu gzigs pa gang brjod pa/ / de dag rim gyis bshad pa 'di 'dra'o/ /

You should rejoice, Get rid of all veils, And single-mindedly listen with respect To the vows and acts of enlightening beings.
The enlightening beings of the past Were supreme lions of humanity; The practices they carried out I shall tell in order.
I will also tell the numbers of ages The worlds and acts And the peerless honored ones Who emerged therein.
As for those past buddhas Who appeared in the world by their vows, How did they destroy afflictions For all sentient beings?
All the lions of philosophy Continue practice to fulfillment, Attaining the state of equality of buddhas, The realm of omniscience.
Seeing all the human lions Of past ages Emanating great networks of lights Illumining the worlds of the ten directions,
They reflected and made their vows: “I should be a lamp for the world Replete with the virtues of buddhahood, Their ten powers, their omniscience.
All sentient beings Burn with greed, anger, and folly; I should save and free them, Have them extinguish the pains of the states of woe.”
They make such vows, Steadfast, unregressing, To cultivate all enlightening practices And gain the unimpeded ten powers.
Having made such vows, They cultivate practice without shrinking back. None of their actions are in vain, Thus they are called lions of philosophy.
In one eon of virtue A thousand buddhas emerged in the world: Their universal eyes I will explain in order.

bskal pa bzang po gcig bzhin du/ / brjod du med pa'i bskal pa khrag khrig de bzhin te/ / sangs rgyas ma byon de dag gi / bzang po'i spyod pa bdag gis bstan par bya/ /
zhing rgyud gcig po ji bzhin du/ / brjod du med pa'i zhing rnams thams cad kun bzung ste/ / ma byon stobs bcu'i skyon med pa'i/ / spyod pa thams cad de bzhin bshad par bya/ /
rgyal ba gang 'og gang 'byung dang / / ci mtshan de yi smon lam rnam pa ci 'dra dang / / rgyal ba gang gis gang gi lung / / bstan mdzad mkhas pa'i sku tshe ji tsam dang / /
chos kyi rnam pa dge ba ni/ / gang gis bsgrubs te dam pa brnyes par gyur pa dang / / 'jig rten ji ltar btul ba dang / / rgyal ba rnams kyi dam chos cir gnas dang; ;
rnam dag zhing yang ci 'dra dang / / sems can rnam par dag dang chos kyi 'khor lo dang / / bstan pa'i dus dang dus min dang / / de las gang zag rnam par dag 'gyur dang / /
sems can rnams kyi las gang dang / / spyod pa gang dang rnam grol ci 'drar 'gyur ba dang / / dbang po rno rtul bar ma dang / / spyod mchog sems can 'dul ba'ang bstan par bya/ /
'di 'dra'i shes par 'jug pa la/ / spyod pa'i dam pa rnams kyis rab tu zhugs gyur cing / / bzang po'i 'byung gnas spyod pa dang / / 'gro kun ye shes 'khor lo spyod zhugs pa/ /
lus kyi las la chags med cing / / ngag la chags med sgra dbyangs thams cad rnam dag la/ / sems spyod chags pa med pa yis/ / dus gsum ma lus rgyas par khyab par byed/ /
'dri 'dra kun tu bzang po yi/ / spyod pa'i mchog la pha rol phyin pa thob gyur pa/ / brjod du med pa'i dkyil 'khor rnams/ / chos dbyings kun tu rab tu rjod par byed/ /
ma 'ongs dus kyi bskal pa dang / / 'byams klas zhing rnams brjod du med pa thams cad kyang / / skad cig sems kyis rab tu shes/ / chos nyid de la rnam par rtog pa med/ /

As in one eon of virtue So too in measureless eons; Those future buddhas’ practices I will explain distinctly.
As in one type of buddha-land, So in numberless lands; The practices of future buddhas I will now explain.
Buddhas’ successive emergence in the world, What were their vows, what their names, What were the prophecies they received, What were their life spans,
What were the true principles they practiced Solely seeking the unobstructed path, Who were the beings they taught, How long their right teaching remained in the world,
What were the buddha-lands they purified, The sentient beings there and the cycles of teaching, Their explanation of proper and improper timing, Progressively purifying beings,
What were the actions of the beings, Their patterns and inclinations, High, middling, low, not the same, How they influenced them to practice—
Penetrating such knowledge, The future buddhas cultivated the supreme practice, Always doing the work of Universal Good, Widely freeing the living.
Physical actions unimpeded, Verbal actions all pure, Mental actions also thus, Always like this at all times—
Enlightening beings acting thus Consummate the path of Universal Good, Producing the sun of pure knowledge Illuminating the cosmos.
The lands of future eons Are unspeakably many in number; They know them all in an instant Without discrimination among them.

gang rnams spyod pa'i sa 'di la/ / spyod pa'i dam pas rjes su zhugs par gyur pa rnams/ / byang chub sems dpa' mchog rnams kyi; ; yon tan spyod pa phyogs tsam bshad par bya/ /
mtha' dang dbus med ye shes can/ / stobs bcu rnams kyi spyod yul mchog la zhugs gyur pa/ / thams cad shes byed mkhas pa'i rnams/ / mi ldog spyod pas rab tu zhugs gyur cing / /
'od byed blo gros dam pa dang / / kun tu bzang po'i smon lam mchog la zhugs gyur pa; ; dpe zla med pa de dag gi / ye shes tshul dang spyod pa brjod par bya/ /
rdul phran gcig gi cha shas la/ / 'jig rten khams rnams ji snyed de dag shes pa dang / / spyod pa rgya che thos gyur na/ / 'jig rten de dag thams cad mos par 'gyur/ /
rdul phran gcig la ji lta ba/ / de bzhin rdul phran thams cad ma lus gzung bya ste/ / ye shes bzang po de dag ni/ / 'jig rten khams la 'jug pa bsam mi khyab/ /
de dag dus kyi rnam pa la'ang / / rdul phran gcig gi khyon gyi cha la yang dag 'jug / rdul phran gcig la de bzhin du/ / zhing yangs rnam pa tha dad kun la 'jug /
rdul phran thams cad re re la/ / zhing rnams brjod du med pa mang po 'dzud pa byed/ / rnam pa tha dad du ma dang / / gcig dang tshad med de bzhin rab tu shes/ /
ji snyed ci yang ma lus pa'i/ / chos dbyings gzung ba thams cad yang dag gzung byed cing / / mtshan nyid tha dad sna tshogs te/ / sems can grangs kyi bskal pa rgyud mi mnyam/ /
'jig rten phra bar 'jug pa la/ / phra la shin tu gzhol bas phra bar 'jug bya ste; ; brjod du med pa rab bstan pa'i/ / bskal pa thams cad ma lus 'dzud pa byed/ /
de dag ring dang thung ba dang / / dus kyi skad cig sems la bskal pa mi mthun shes/ / shes spyod mi mnyam ma yin pa'i/ / shes pas de dag thams cad khong du chud/ /

Those who practice can enter into Such a supreme state: Of these principles of enlightening beings I shall tell a little.
Knowledge and wisdom boundless, They realize the scope of buddhahood; Entering completely therein, Their practice does not regress.
Replete with Universally Good wisdom, They fulfill Universally Good vows And enter the peerless knowledge; I shall tell of their practice.
In a single atom They see all worlds; If sentient beings should hear of this, They’d go mad in confusion.
As in one atom, So in all atoms; All worlds enter therein— So inconceivable is it.
In every single atom Are all things of all places and times; The states and lands, innumerable, The enlightening discern and know.
In every single atom Are countless kinds of buddha-lands, And each kind is also countless; They know all in one.
All the various different features That there are in the cosmos, The types of beings, each different, They can discern and know.
Deeply entering subtle knowledge, They distinguish the worlds; The becoming and decay of all ages They can clearly explain.
They know the length and brevity of all ages, And that past, present, and future are one moment: The sameness and difference of myriad practices They all distinctly know.

yangs dang yangs min mkhas pas na/ / 'jig rten zab mo rnams la rab tu 'jug par byed/ / lus la zhing rnams de shes te/ / zhing la'ang de bzhin gcig min lus 'dzud do/ /
phyogs rnams bcu po thams cad du/ / phyogs rnams kun la 'jug cing skad cig du ma dang / / 'jig rten khams rnams 'byams klas la/ / tshad med gzi brjid ldan pa rab tu 'jug /
gang yang zhing rnams mtha' yas shing / / dbus med gzung ba byas shing dus kyi dbyings su 'dzud/ / zhing gi rgyud la mkhas pa'i rnams/ / shes dang ldan pas ye shes rab tu 'byung / /
bzang po'i yon tan ldan pa'i rnams/ / phyogs dang 'jig rten khams kyi rgyud du gyur pa dag / ji snyed yod pa der 'jug ste/ / brjod du med pa de dag rab tu shes/ /
zhing dang zhing gis rnams kyi/ / brjod du med pa'i zhing rnams kun kyang rab tu 'thob/ / de dag tshul yang rab tu shes; ; las rnams gang gis sbyangs pa'ang khong du chud/ /
gang yang zhing rnams du ma dag / las rnams khrag khrig kun gyis kun nas nyon mongs par/ / 'gro ba kun du bsgrub byas pa/ / de dag thams cad rgyud kyang ci 'dra shes/ /
brjod du med pa yangs pa'i rnams/ / zhing gcig bstan pas de dag yongs su shes par gyur/ / de 'dra'i zhing la 'jug pa dang; ; gang la grangs med de dag kun la 'jug /
'jig rten khams ni gcig la yang / / 'jig rten khams rnams thams cad yang dag 'dzud pa byed/ / 'jig rten gcig tu bsgongs mi 'gyur/ / 'jig rten khams rnams de bzhin 'dres mi 'gyur/ /
spyi'u tshugs rnams dang gong ma'i rnams/ / bla dang 'og gis rnams yongs su gzung bya ste/ / 'gro ba'i rnam par ming thogs pa/ / 'jig rten kun la 'jug cing rab tu shes/ /
snrel zhing rgyu ba'i rgyud rnams dang / / zhing rnams mtha' yas mtha' dang dbus yod ma yin pa/ / sna tshogs yangs pa rab tu shes/ / rnam pa gcig shes rnam pa tha dad shes/ /

They penetrate all worlds, Vast and small, One body countless lands, One land, countless bodies.
The innumerable features Of the worlds of different species In the ten directions They know entirely.
Those of most profound knowledge Comprehend the becoming and decay Of the numberless lands Of past, present, and future.
Of the worlds in the ten directions, Some are forming, some decaying: Infinite though they be, The virtuous comprehend them all.
There are some lands With variously adorned ground, And the beings are also adorned— This is due to purity of action.
Then again some lands Have countless kinds of pollution; This is due to beings experiencing everything According to their acts.
Infinite, boundless worlds, The enlightening know are one land; Thus do they enter all lands, Whose number cannot be known.
All worlds Enter one land: The worlds do not become one, Yet there is no mixup.
Worlds are inverted and upright, Some high, some low— All are the perceptions of beings: The enlightening discern them all.
The wide worlds Are infinite, boundless; They know all kinds are one And know that one is various.

zhing gi grangs rnams rab tu shes/ / ye shes chags med mtha' ldan kun gyi grangs rnams kyang / / bzang po'i theg pa spyod pa yis/ / rgyal sras kun du bzang rnams rab tu shes/ /
'jig rten thams cad sprul pa dang / / sems can rnam par sprul dang de bzhin zhing sprul dang / / chos rnams sprul pa'i tshul shes pa/ / sangs rgyas sprul pa'i pha rol phyin pa rnams/ /
'jig rten phra zhing zab pa dang / / yangs shing sna tshogs yangs pas cho ma cho dgu'i rnams/ / sna tshogs tha dad rnam bsags pa/ / las kyi rnam smin gnas pa'i 'jig rten rnams/ /
rdzu 'phrul rnam par 'phrul pa yis/ / chos dbyings 'jug par bya la shin tu bslabs pa yi/ / rgyal sras mtha' dang dbus med pa/ / phyogs bcu thams cad ma lus 'gengs par byed/ /
'jig rten khams rnams de dag gi / ming ni bskal pa sems can snyed kyis mthar thug cing / / zad par brjod par mi nus te/ / ming bshad gal te sangs rgyas gsung na gsung / /
'jig rten mgon po rnams kyi yang / / mtshan rnams mtshan nyid mi mthun rnam pa sna tshogs mtshan/ / bskal pa brjod med zad byas kyang / / mtshan rnams gcig nas gcig brgyud mthar thug med/ /
'on kyang dma' ba'i sems med par/ / mkhas pa rnams ni dus gsum bde gshegs sangs rgyas phyir/ / chos kyi dbyings la byung ba ste/ / sangs rgyas ye shes sa la'ang rab tu zhugs/ /
dran pas chags med dag pa ste/ / chags med yid dang ldan zhing blo gros mtha' yas pas/ / ye shes blo gros mchog ldan pa/ / chos dbyings bshad la pha rol phyin pa thob/ /
gang gis 'jig rten khams kyi rnams/ / yangs dang phra ba rnam pa sna tshogs shes gyur cing; ; der ni 'das pa'i dus rnams la/ / sems gcig bskyed pas rab tu 'jug pa byed/ /
mi yi seng ge de dag tu/ / sangs rgyas spyod pa sna tshogs rnam pas chags med par/ / byang chub mchog tu sangs rgyas shing / / rnam par 'phrul pa thams cad ston pa mdzad/ /

The Universally Good offspring of Buddha Can, by Universally Good knowledge, Know the number of lands, Though the number is boundless.
They know the projections of worlds, The projections of lands and beings, The projections of teachings and buddhas— All to the ultimate point.
All worlds, Micro- and macrocosmic, Various different arrays— All arise from action.
Infinite enlightening beings Learn to enter the reality realm; Their spiritual powers free, They reach everywhere in the ten directions.
If the names of those worlds were spoken For eons as many as beings, They still could not be all told— Only Buddha can reveal them.
The various names Of the worlds and buddhas Could not be fully told Even in countless eons.
The most excellent wisdom, The teachings of buddhas of all times, Are born from the realm of reality And fill the state of enlightenment.
With pure, unobstructed mindfulness, Boundless, unimpeded wisdom, They analyze the reality realm To reach the other shore.
The worlds of the past, Great and small, The arrangements they have developed, Buddhas know in an instant.
The human lions therein Cultivate the various practices of buddhas, Attain to true awakening, And manifest their freedoms.

de bzhin ma 'ongs dus rnams kyi/ / rjes su gang byon de yi bskal pa ci 'dra dang / / de la mi yi seng ge gang; ; skye bar 'gyur ba de dag kun kyang shes/ /
smon lam spyod pa ci 'dra dang / / spyod yul gang rnams bsgom pa gang gis grub gyur cing / / bsgrub pa'i rnam pa ci 'dra bas/ / bskal pa gang la byang chub 'tshang rgya dang / /
de dag 'khor kyang khong du chud/ / sku tshe'i tshad dang sems can 'dul ba ci 'dra dang / / chos kyi sgo mo gang zhig gis/ / 'gro bar chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba shes/ /
de ltar kun tu bzang po yi/ / ye shes mchog gis bsgrubs pa'i spyod pa'i sa gnas shing / / de dag thams cad rab tu shes/ / de ni 'gro gtso kun gyi 'byung gnas yin/ /
de ltar byung ba gzung byas shing / / 'jig rten khams rnams thams cad 'dab chags ma lus par/ / 'jig rten khams la rab tu 'jug / de bzhin chos kyi dbyings rnams rab tu shes/ /
des ni mi yi gtso bo rnams/ / dgra las rgyal zhing thams cad gzigs pa ji snyed pa/ / mi thub rgol ba dpa' bo'i rnams/ / chos kyi mnga' la pha rol phyin brnyes pa/ /
de dag 'khor kyang rab tu shes/ / sems can 'dul dang zhing rnams rnam par dag pa dang / / rgyal ba'i rnam par 'phrul pa'i rnams/ / sems pas bskal pa yangs pa zad par byed/ /
skyes bu'i mchog rnams 'dul mdzad cing / / 'jig rten mchog tu phyin pa'i byin rlabs dam pa la/ / mi zad mdzod kyi shes yangs pas/ / ye shes tshul la mkhas pa rab tu 'jug /
chags med mig gis blta ba dang / / chags med rna ba mngon par bsgrub pa sgrub byed cing / / chags pa med pa'i lus yangs dang / / yangs pa'i lces kyang 'jig rten tshim par byed/ /
dam pa'i sems la chags med de/ / bsam pa kun tu rnam yangs rnam par dag dang ldan/ / ye shes 'byung gnas bdag nyid che/ / dus gsum sems rnams ma lus des khyab bo/ /

Enlightening beings know all Such buddhas of the future, The most noble of humans In boundless ages to come,
All their undertakings, All their various states, How they strive in practice, And therein attain enlightenment.
They know their congregations, Their life spans, and the beings they teach, By what means they teach, Turning the wheel of truth for the masses.
Knowing this, enlightening beings Abide in the stage of Universally Good practice, Their knowledge and wisdom, thoroughly clear, Giving birth to all the buddhas.
They enter deeply Into all the buddha-lands There are in the present And arrive at the reality realm.
All the present buddhas In all those worlds Are masters of teaching, Unhindered in discourse.
They also know their congregations, Pure lands, and adaptive powers; For countless million eons They always ponder these things.
The awesome psychic powers And endless stores of knowledge Of the noble Tamers of the World, The enlightening beings know all.
Producing unobstructed eyes, Unobstructed ears, noses, bodies, And unobstructed universal tongues, They can gladden sentient beings.
Their supreme, unobstructed minds Are broad and totally pure; Their knowledge pervading all, They know all things of all times.

sprul pa'i pha rol phyin thob cing / / zhing rnams sprul pa'i bslab par bya ba bslab pa'i rnams/ / sems can sprul la mkhas pa dag / sprul pa sprul pas 'jig rten 'dul ba byed/ /
'du shes rnam pa du ma ste/ / des ni 'jig rten sna tshogs ma lus rnam par bris/ / de dag thams cad rab tu shes/ / sangs rgyas ye shes tshul la rab tu 'jug /
'khor rnams brjod du med pa dag / sangs rgyas sku rnams re re dag la yod pa'i rnams/ / kun la 'jug cing mthong bar byed/ / sems can rnam par 'dul ba'i mtha' yang med/ /
ye shes zab mo mthong bas na/ / ye shes nyi ma shin tu gsal ba shar gyur pa'i/ / phyir mi ldog pa'i spyod pa la/ / 'jig rten 'byams klas kun tu 'jug par byed/ /
