Of these four, one is called stability, the second permanence, the third ultimacy, and the fourth firmness. These four atmospheres can sustain the sphere of water; the sphere of water can sustain the earth and prevent it from falling apart—therefore it is said that the sphere of earth rests on the sphere of water, the sphere of water rests on the atmosphere, the atmosphere rests on space, and space does not rest on anything; but though space does not rest on anything, it enables the universe to abide. The manifestation of Buddha is also like this, producing Buddha’s four kinds of atmosphere of great knowledge based on the unimpeded light of wisdom, able to sustain the roots of goodness of all sentient beings. What are those four? The atmosphere of great knowledge taking care of all sentient beings and inspiring joy in them; the atmosphere of great knowledge setting up right teaching and causing sentient beings to take to it; the atmosphere of great knowledge preserving all sentient beings’ roots of goodness; the atmosphere of great knowledge containing all appropriate means, arriving at the realm where there are no taints or contaminations. The buddhas benevolently rescue all living beings, compassionately liberate all living beings, their great benevolence and compassion universally aiding all: however, great benevolence and great compassion rest on great skill in means; great skill in means rests on the manifestation of Buddha; the manifestation of Buddha rests on the light of unimpeded wisdom; the light of unimpeded wisdom does not rest on anything. This is the ninth characteristic of the manifestation of Buddha—great enlightening beings should know it as such.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'grub pa ni/ tshad med pa'i sems can rnams yongs su spyod pa rnam pa tha dad pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin te/ 'di ltar chu la gnas pa'i sems can rnams kyang gnas kyis nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ sems can sa'i steng na 'khod pa rnams kyang sa'i steng na yod pa'i rnam pa tshad med pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ gzhal med khang na gnas pa rnams kyang gzhal med khang gis nye bar 'tsho yin/ nam mkha' la gnas pa rnams kyang bar snang gi gnas kyis nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par grub pa yang rnam pa tshad med pas 'gro ba thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba yin te/ 'di ltar mthong bar dga' ba dang / dad cing mos par gyur pa'i sems can rnams kyang sangs rgyas mthong bas nye bar 'tsho ba yin; tshul khrims kyi stobs kyi mthu la gnas pa rnams kyang / sangs rgyas kyi tshul khrims kyis nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ bsam gtan dang / tshad med pa la gnas pa rnams kyang / 'phags pa 'jig rten las 'das pa'i mngon par shes pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ chos kyi sgo snang ba la gnas pa rnams kyang rgyu chud mi za bas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ snang ba med pa la gnas pa rnams kyang; chos 'byams klas pa chud mi za bas nye bar 'tsho ba yin pas/ de'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par grub pa ni/ 'gro ba thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba yin zhes bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo rnam pa bcu pa 'dis kyang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi skye ba 'byung ba khong du chud par bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos/ de bzhin gshegs pa skye ba 'byung ba bstan pa ni de lta bur shes par bya ste/ spyod pa yongs su bsgrubs pa tshad med pas na/ tshad med par shes par bya'o/ /phyogs bcu thams cad rgyas par 'gengs pas na/ shin tu yangs par shes par bya'o/ /skye ba dang 'jig pa'i gnas dang bral bas na/ len pa med cing 'dor ba med par shes par bya'o/ /sems dang / yid dang / rnam par shes pa dang bral bas na/ rgyu ba med cing rgyu ba dang bral bar shes par bya'o/ /nam mkha'i rang bzhin lta bu yin pas na/ lus med par shes par bya'o/ /sems can thams cad la bdag med pas na/ mnyam par shes par bya'o/ /sems can thams cad la zad mi shes pa'i zhing du gyur pas na/ mi zad par shes par bya'o/ /phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug par rgyun mi 'chad pas na/ phyir mi ldog par shes par bya'o/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la gnyen po med pas na/ mi 'phrogs par shes par bya'o/ /'dus byas dang / 'dus ma byas mnyam pa nyid du thugs su chud pas na/ mi gnyis par shes par bya'o/ /sngon yongs su smin par byas pa'i sems can gyi bsam pa'i khyad par yongs su rdzogs par mdzad pas na 'gro ba thams cad nye bar 'tsho bar shes par bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de dag la sogs pa rnam par byang ba rnam pa tha dad pa tshad med pa shin tu bstan pa'i sgos kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos/ de bzhin gshegs pa 'byung zhing yang dag par 'grub pa bstan pa shes par bya'o/ /

“Furthermore, once the billion-world universe has formed, it benefits countless various sentient beings—the water creatures receive the benefits of the water, the land creatures receive the benefit of the land, the sky creatures receive the benefit of the sky. In the same way the manifestation of Buddha variously benefits all kinds of beings—those who become joyful on seeing Buddha gain the benefit of joy, those who abide by the pure precepts gain the benefit of pure conduct, those who abide in the meditations, concentrations, and immeasurable minds gain the benefit of transmundane spiritual powers of saints, those who abide in the lights of the ways of entry into the Teaching gain the benefit of the nondissolution of cause and effect, those who abide in the light of nonexistence gain the benefit of nondissolution of all truths. Therefore we say the manifestation of Buddha benefits all sentient beings. This is the tenth characteristic of the manifestation of Buddha—great enlightening beings should know it as such.
“When great enlightening beings know the manifestation of Buddha, they know it is infinite because they know it consummates infinite practices; then they know it is immensely vast because they know it pervades the ten directions; then they know it has no coming or going because they know it is apart from birth, subsistence, and extinction, then they know it has no action and nothing acted upon because they know it is beyond mind, intellect, and consciousness; then they know it is impartial because they know all sentient beings have no self; then they know it is endless because they know it pervades all lands without end, then they know it is unreceding because they know it will never be stopped in the future; then they know it has no decay because the Buddha’s knowledge has no counterpart; then they know it is nondual because they know Buddha equally observes the conditional and the unconditional; then they know all sentient beings gain benefit because the dedication of Buddha’s original vows are freely fulfilled.”
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos don 'di nyid yang brtag par bya ba'i phyir/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the great enlightening being Universally Good, wishing to restate his point, spoke these verses:

'jig rten kun las 'das shing stobs bcur mngar gyur te/ / mi mnyam mnyam dang mnyam zhing bar snang mkha' mnyam pa'i/ / mgon po rnams kyi spyod yul mtshungs med mtha' yas nyon/ / de dag 'jig rten kun na yon tan mtshungs pa med/ /
stobs bcu yon tan tshad med mnga' ba thams cad kyi/ / mthu la sems dang yid kyi tshul gyis mi bsam ste/ / skyes bu seng ge rnams ni 'jig rten thams cad kyis/ / sgo rnams re rer bskal pa bye bar mi rtogs so/ /
phyogs bcu kun na zhing rnams ji snyed yod pa rnams/ / skyes bu la las bshig ste rdul phran bgrang nus kyang / / des ni stobs bcu mnga' ba'i spu gcig yon tan yang / / bskal pa khrag khrig brgyas kyang tshad gzung mi nus so/ /
skyes bu la la nam mkha'i dbyings la 'jal byed cing / / de ltar la las rtsis 'go bzung ste bgrang byas kyang / / gzhal bar mi nus mtha' yang rnyed par mi rung ba/ / de bzhin bde gshegs rnams kyi spyod yul tshad kyang med/ /
dus gsum sems can rnams kyi rigs rgyud ji snyed dang / / de dag dus gsum spyod pa sems can 'ga' zhig gis/ / sems kyi skad cig yid kyis shes kyang 'gro snyed kyi/ / bskal pas thams cad zil gnon rang bzhin shes mi nus/ /
ji ltar chos kyi dbyings ni kun tu mtha' yas shing / / kun yin thams cad ma yin mi snang gzung du med/ / de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba'i spyod yul tshad med de/ / thams cad yin yang kun min chos dbyings rang bzhin yin/ /
de bzhin nyid ni de bzhin nyid du mi rtog cing / / kun nas 'byung pa med cing nam yang nub pa med/ / de bzhin 'jig rten kun 'das de dag spyod yul te/ / de bzhin nyid dang tshul mtshungs 'phel dang 'grib pa spangs/ /
yang dag mtha' ni mtha' med mtha' la gnas pa ste/ / dus gsum kun dang rnam pa kun tu rnam par bral/ / de bzhin mgon po phan mdzad kun gyi spyod yul te/ / dus gsum rgyas mdzad rnam pa kun tu chags mi mnga'/ /
rang bzhin byas pa med pas rnam par 'gyur ba med/ / rang bzhin mkha' 'dra dri med nyon mongs med pa ste/ / de bzhin rgyal ba rnams kyi rang bzhin kun tu dag / rang bzhin 'gyur dang bral zhing yod dang med ba min/ /
sgra dang tshig las rnam grol dbyangs rnams thams cad med/ / 'gro dang 'ong bral rnam rtog med pas mya ngan 'das/ / de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba'i spyod yul rang bzhin med/ / tshig gi rang bzhin kun gyis brjod par mi nus so/ /
de ltar chos kun rang bzhin zhi ba mkhyen gyur pas/ / ji ltar nam mkha'i rlung dang bya rjes 'dra ba ste/ / sngon chad smon lam mdzad pas gzugs kyi skur yang snang / / stobs bcu mnga' ba rnams kyi cho 'phrul ci 'dra ltos/ /
rgyal ba'i spyod yul 'di la 'jug par su 'dod pa/ / des ni nam mkha' 'dra bar bsam pa yongs su sbyongs/ / rtog dang rnam par rtog dang 'du shes 'dzin spong ste/ / nam mkha' lta bu'i yid kyis de la 'jug par gyis/ /

The Ten-Powered Great Hero is supreme, Incomparable as space, With a sphere so vast it cannot be measured, Virtues most eminent, beyond the world.
The virtues of the ten powers are boundless, Unreachable by thought: A single teaching of the human lion No sentient beings can know in a hundred million eons.
If the lands of the ten directions were reduced to dust, Those motes of dust might be counted, But the virtues in a single hair of Buddha Could not be told in a trillion eons.
If someone took a ruler to measure space And someone followed to keep the account, The bounds of space could not be found— So it is with the realm of Buddha.
If someone could know in an instant The minds of the beings of all times, Even over eons as many as beings, Such a one could know the essence of one thought of Buddha.
Just as the reality realm pervades all Yet cannot be perceived as being all, So also is the realm of the Ten-Powered: It pervades all yet is not all.
True Thusness, free of falsehood, is ever silent; Birthless, deathless, it is all-pervasive. The realm of the buddhas is also thus; Essentially equal, not increasing or decreasing.
Just as ultimate reality has no limit. Is in all times yet is not therein, So is the realm of the Guide, Pervading all times without obstruction.
The nature of things is uncreate, unchanging, Fundamentally pure, like space: So also is the purity of nature of buddhas— Their fundamental nature is not a nature, is beyond being and nonbeing.
The nature of things is not in discussion, It is speechless, beyond speech, eternally quiescent. The nature of the realm of the Ten-Powered is also thus; No words can explain it.
Buddha knows the nature of things is null, Like birds flying through the sky without a trace; By the power of past vows he manifests a body, Showing the great spiritual transfiguration of Buddha.
Any who wish to know the realm of Buddha Should make their minds clean as space, Getting rid of false notions and graspings, Making the mind unhindered wherever it turns.

de bas bde gshegs sras rnams mgon po'i spyod yul rnams/ / bdag gis dpe tsam chung shas bshad kyi mnyan par gyis/ / stobs bcu mnga' ba'i yon tan mthar phyin mi nus kyang / / shas tsam shes par bya ba'i don du cung zad brjod/ /
de dag sku yi 'phrin las ji ltar 'byung ba dang / / mgon po rnams kyi gsung dang thugs kyi spyod yul dang / / stobs bcu rnams kyi yul dang 'khor lo bskor ba dang / / mya ngan 'da' dang dge rtsa thams cad bshad kyi nyon/ /
'jig rten 'di dag ma lus skye zhing 'byung ba'i tshe/ / de la rgyu yi rnam grangs gcig ces bgrang med kyi/ / rgyu dang tshul gyi rnam pa khrag khrig brgya mang gis/ / 'jig rten stong gsum kun nas gnas pa'i grangs su 'gro/ /
de bzhin skyes bu'i mchog rnams skye bar 'gyur ba'i tshe/ / de dag yon tan 'di snyed yin zhes bgrang pa med/ / rdul dang rdul phran bgrang nus sems can kun bsam nus/ / stobs bcu mnga' ba rnams kyi 'byung ba rnams la min/ /
ji ltar sprin dang dus kyi char la rten byas shing / / char chen 'babs byed rlung rnams bzhi po de bzhin te/ / dge rtsa kun dang byang chub sems dpa'i mthus/ / 'jig rten stong gsum kun nas gnas pa'i grangs su 'gro/ /
de bzhin stobs bcu rnams kyi chos sprin rgyur byas shing / / bsam pa rnam dag byed pa'i ye shes rlung ldang ste/ / sngon gyi dge ba rkyen gyis rigs par yongs bsngos pas/ / stobs bcu mgon po rnams ni 'byung zhing skye bar 'gyur/ /
steng gi mkha' yi dbyings las sprin chen char brugs pa/ / stong gsum stong chen 'jig rten kun nas 'jig 'gyur tshe/ / mkha' dbyings rgya chen dag pa'i rlung langs ma gtogs par/ / sa phyogs gzhan gyis bzung zhing gzung bar mi nus so/ /
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i tshe/ / phyogs bcu kun gyi chos dbyings yongs su rgyas bkang zhing / / chos tshul char chen 'bab bar gyur la lhag pa'i sems/ / rnam par dag pa ma gtogs gzhan gyis 'dzin mi nus/ /
nam mkha'i dbyings las sprin chen char pa 'bab gyur pa/ / de la 'gro dang 'ong ba nam yang yod pa min/ / de la byed pa med de tshor ba po yang med/ / de dag chos nyid thob 'byung rnam pa gzhan gyis min; ;
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba'i chos sprin char 'bab pa/ / de dag 'pho dang 'ong ba yod pa ma yin yang / / byang chub sems dpa'i mthu dang legs par spyad pa'i rgyus/ / byang chub sems dpa'i chos kyi rang bzhin sprin kyang 'byung / /

Therefore offspring of Buddha should listen well As I illustrate the realm of Buddha with a few examples; The virtues of the Ten-Powered cannot be measured, But to enlighten all beings I summarize them.
The vistas exposed by the Guide In acts of body, speech, and mind, Their teaching and final extinction, All roots of goodness I now will tell.
Just as the establishment of worlds Cannot be achieved by one cause or condition, And countless appropriate causes and conditions Form this billion-world universe,
The manifestation of Buddha is also like this, Only accomplished through infinite virtues; The atoms of lands and thoughts of minds may be known, But the productive causes of the Ten-Powered none can measure.
Just as clouds pour rain at the start of one eon And create four great atmospheres, And the roots of goodness of sentient beings and the power of enlightening beings Establish the billion worlds securely,
So do the clouds of teaching of the Ten-Powered Produce atmospheres of knowledge, pure minds, Guiding beings to which they were previously dedicated To fulfillment of the highest reward.
Just as there is a great deluge Which no place can contain Except the great wind force in pure space At the beginning of the universe,
So also is the Buddha’s manifestation, Showering rain of truths filling the cosmos Which the weak-minded cannot bear, Only those of pure and broad minds.
Just as the downpour of rain in the sky Comes from nowhere and goes nowhere, With no producer or receiver, Naturally filling all with moisture thus,
The rain of teaching of Buddha is also thus, Without coming or going, uncreate; Based on past practice, with the power of enlightening beings, All the great-minded hear and accept it.

sprin gyi char bkye char thigs yongs su bgrang nus pa'i/ / sems can de 'dra khams gsum 'di ni yod pa min/ / stong gsum dbang po'i dbang phyug de ni ma gtogs te/ / dbang bsgyur de ni sngon gyi smon lam 'bras bus bgrang / /
de bzhin bde gshegs char chen 'bab pa ma lus par/ / sems can kun gyis bgrang bsam gzhal par sla ba min/ / 'jig rten kun na 'gro ba'i mchog gyur dbang phyug rnams/ / de dag sprin chen char mkhyen rin chen lag bkod ltar/ /
rab tu zhi byed zhi byed 'byung ba 'byung bar byed/ / gzhan yang yongs su gcod pa de ni yongs su gcod/ / sgrub pa de bzhin gzhan te de ni rin chen sgrub/ / rnam par 'byed pa stong gsum thams cad rnam par 'byed/ /
stobs bcu mnga' ba'i zhi sprin nyon mongs kun zhir byed/ / 'byung ba dge stong brgya 'grangs kun nas 'byung bar byed/ / yongs su gcod pa lta ba'i rnam pa yongs gcod de/ / rgyal ba'i rin chen sgrub cing bsam pa rnam par 'byed/ /
bar snang mkha' las char 'bab ci ltar ro gcig kyang / / gnas kyi khyad kyis yongs su 'gyur ba sna tshogs mang / / 'on kyang chu la rtog med rnam par rtog pa med/ / tha dad rnam pa 'grangs pa de dag chos nyid tshul/ /
de bzhin chos kyang gcig min tha dad ma yin te/ / ro gcig zhi zhing rtog med rnam par rtog med de/ / 'on kyang sangs rgyas chos 'grangs mu med 'byung bar 'gyur/ / de ni rdul bral rnams kyi chos nyid tshul yin no/ /
ji ltar thog mar gzugs khams gzhal med khang pa 'byung / / de nas 'dod khams gzhal med khang rnams rnam par 'god/ / de nas sa steng mi yi gnas rnams rnam bkod de/ / de nas klu dang dri za 'gro ba kun gyi gnas/ /
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba de dag 'byung ba'i tshe/ / thog mar byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mu med 'byung / / de nas zhi dga' rang rgyal theg la gnas pa rnams; ; de nas dbang du gyur pa'i de nas 'gro kun gyi/ /
ji ltar pad+mo sangs rgyas skye ba'i ltas gyur pas/ / sngon chad sangs rgyas mthong ba'i lha rnams dga' 'gyur zhing / / chu las brten cing 'od gsal gzhal med khang yang 'byung / / rlung langs 'jig rten ras ris cha char 'god pa byed/ /
sangs rgyas sngon gyi dge ba'i 'od gsal ltas yin te/ / des ni sangs rgyas rgyal sras kun gyi thugs chud 'gyur/ / ye shes yongs dag dkyil 'khor mkha' ltar rnam dag pa'i/ / stobs bcu tha dad ji snyed sangs rgyas chos 'byung mkhyen/ /
rlung ni chu phung ma lus kun gyi gnas yin te/ / de phyir sa steng gnas rnams 'jig par mi 'gyur ro/ / sa yang shing dang gel pa sman gyi gnas yin te/ / mkha' la gnas su bya ba gang yang med pa yin/ /
mgon po rnams kyang shes rab ye shes gzhi la bzhugs/ / ye shes thugs rje byams pa thabs kyis yongs su bzung / / rgyal ba'i chos rnams ji snyed de dag thabs su 'dus/ / rdul med shes rab de ni gnas med lus kyang med/ /
'jig rten byung nas tshad med mang po kun kyang 'tsho/ / sa la gnas dang chu la gnas pa thams cad dang / / nam mkha'i lha rdzas gzhal med khang la gnas pa dang / / rkang gnyis rkang bzhi sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho/ /
de bzhin skyes mchog dbang po chos kyi rgyal skyes pa/ / 'gro ba ma lus thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ / mthong zhing thos par gyur dang mchod pas de bzhin te/ / nyon mongs bsal bas sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho/ /
'byung ba mthar thug med pas 'jig rten mgo rmongs 'gyur/ / 'on kyang 'gro la phan 'don sems can shes bya'i phyir/ / mi mkhas 'gro ba bstan phyir ye shes bstan don du/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi don rab dpe med dpes brjod do// //

As the clouds in the sky shower rain, And no one can count the drops, Except the lord of the universe Whose power is able to comprehend them,
So also is the rain of teaching of the Felicitous; No sentient beings can measure it, Except people who are free in the world, Who see it as clearly as a jewel in the hand.
Just as the rain pouring from the clouds in the sky Can extinguish, can produce, and can stop, Can make all jewels And distinguish all in the universe,
The rain of Buddha’s teaching is also thus, Extinguishing delusion, producing good, stopping views, Making all jewels of knowledge, Distinguishing beings’ inclinations.
The one flavor of the rain in the sky Is different according to the places it rains— It is not that the rain has any distinction, But it is naturally thus according to the differences in things.
The rain of teaching of Buddha is not one or varied: Impartial, quiescent, it is free from discrimination, Yet according to the various differences of those taught It naturally has unlimited aspects.
When the world is first formed, First are formed the palaces of the form-realm heavens, Then the desire heavens, then human abodes, And last the gandharva palaces;
The manifestation of Buddha is also like this, First producing boundless enlightening beings’ practices, Then teaching those aware of conditioning, who like tranquillity, Then the listeners, then finally sentient beings.
When the gods first see the lotus blossom open They know buddhas will appear and are glad; Water, based on the power of wind, produces the world, Dwellings, mountains, and rivers are all set up.
The great light of the developed goodness of Buddha Skillfully distinguishes enlightening beings and gives them predictions; The spheres of knowledge, all pure, Can each reveal the ways to buddhahood.
The forest exists dependent on the earth, The earth remains solid based on water, Water depends on wind, wind on space, While space does not depend on anything.
All Buddha teachings depend on compassion, And compassion is established depending on means; Means depend on knowledge, knowledge on wisdom, While the body of unimpeded wisdom does not depend on anything.
Once the world comes to be, All beings receive its benefits— Living on the earth, in the water, in the sky, Two-legged, four-legged, all receive benefit.
The manifestation of the spiritual sovereign is also thus— All beings gain its benefits; If any see, hear, or associate with Buddha, It will cause all confusions and afflictions to be removed.
The elements of Buddha’s manifestation are boundless; The deluded of the world cannot know them. Out of desire to enlighten all conscious beings Similes are told where there is no comparison.
bam po bdun cu rtsa gcig pa/

de skad ces smras pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su byung ba'i dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi sku bltar yod pa ji lta bur khong du chud par bya/ de skad ces smras pa dang /
“How should great enlightening beings see the body of Buddha?

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su byung ba'i dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa ni/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos tshad med pa'i rjes su 'gro bas khong du chud par bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa ni/ byang chub sems dpas chos gcig gam/ rnam pa gcig gam/ sku gcig gam/ zhing gcig gam/ sems can gcig gis khong du chud par bya ba ma yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa ni/ thams cad du rjes su song bar byang chub sems dpas khong du chud par bya'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nam mkha'i dbyings ni thams cad kyi rjes su song ba ste/ 'dod pa dang / gzugs yod pa dang / gzugs med pa'i gnas thams cad du khyab pa yin yang gang du'ang song ba med cing / rjes su song ba med par shes par bya'o/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni nam mkha' la gzugs med pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku yang thams cad kyi rjes su song ba ste; sems can thams cad dang / chos thams cad dang / zhing thams cad kun tu khyab par shes par bya'o/ /'on kyang gar yang gshegs pa med cing rjes su bzhud pa med de/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la lus med pa'i phyir te/ sems can rnam par dmigs pa yod pa'i phyir skur bstan pa yang yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo dang po 'dis/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

They should see the body of Buddha in infinite places. Why? They should not see Buddha in just one thing, one phenomenon, one body, one land, one being—they should see Buddha everywhere.
Just as space is omnipresent, in all places, material or immaterial, yet without either arriving or not arriving there, because space is incorporeal, in the same way Buddha is omnipresent, in all places, in all beings, in all things, in all lands, yet neither arriving nor not arriving there, because Buddha’s body is incorporeal, manifesting a body for the sake of sentient beings. This is the first characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste; dper na/ nam mkha' gzugs med de/ yangs shing rgya che ba'i phyir/ sems can thams cad kyi bya ba snang zhing yod par gyur te/ nam mkha' la rtog pa med do/ /spros pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku ye shes kyi 'od snang ba la brten cing / sems can thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i las 'jig rten pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa rnams yod cing snang bar gyur kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la rnam par rtog pa mi mnga' ste/ spros pa mi mnga'o/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku ni thogs ma nas spros pa thams cad yang dag par chad pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo gnyis pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“Furthermore, just as space is wide open, is not a form yet can reveal all forms, yet space is without discrimination or false description, so also is the body of Buddha like this, causing all beings’ mundane and transmundane good works to be accomplished by illumining all with the light of knowledge, yet without discrimination or false descriptions, having originally terminated all attachments and false descriptions. This is the second characteristic of the body of Buddha—great enlightening beings should see it this way.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ 'dzam bu'i gling du nyi ma shar ba ni 'od kyis tshad med par khyab pas/ sems can rnams tshad med pa'i rnam pas nye bar 'tsho ste/ 'di ltar ri la bab cing dang nags tshal skye bar byed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin; mun pa'i mun nag yongs su sel zhing snang bar byed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ sa la bab cing 'dam rdzab yongs su skem pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ lo tog la bab cing yongs su smin par byed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ nags tshal dang / gel ba dang / sman la bab cing skye ba dang rnam par 'phel bar byed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin; nam mkha' la bab kyang bar snang la spyod pa'i sems can rnams nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ pad+mo'i nags tshal la bab kyang kha 'bye zhing rgyas par byed pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ grong dang / grong khyer dang / ljongs dang / pho brang 'khor dang / rgyal po'i gnas la bab kyang gzugs sna tshogs gsal bar ston pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ chu la bab kyang chu la gnas pa'i sems can yongs su longs spyod pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ las kyi rnam pa sna tshogs la bab kyang dgos pa brtsams pa yongs su grub par byed pas nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi 'od zer tshad med pa bkye ba'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa'i nyi ma yang / rnam pa tshad med pas sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba yin te/ 'di ltar dge ba'i las yongs su skyed cing sdig pa'i las rnam par zlog pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ shes rab kyi 'od snang ba mdzad cing gti mug gi mun pa rnam par sel bas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ 'gro ba thams cad yongs su skyob cing / byams pa chen po dang ldan pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ 'gro ba thams cad yongs su 'grel cing / thugs rje chen po dang ldan pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ dbang po dang / stobs dang / byang chub kyi yan lag 'phel bar mdzad cing / chos kyi lo tog la bab pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ sems can gyi rnyog pa yongs su sel bas dad pa bskyed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ rgyu dang 'bras bu rnam par chud mi za bas mthong ba don yod pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ skye ba dang / 'pho ba yang dag par ston cing / gzugs snang bar mdzad pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par chud mi gzon cing khong khro ba mi mnga' bas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ slob ma'i yon tan pad+mo kha phye zhing rgyas par mdzad de/ sems can rnams la ye shes kyi 'od zer tshad med pa rab tu gtong bas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ spyad pa brtsams pa yongs su grub pa mdzad cing / byang chub sems dpa'i spro ba bskyed pas kyang nye bar 'tsho ba yin/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'i nyi ma ni/ ye shes kyi 'od zer gyi dkyil 'khor tshad med pa dang ldan pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo gsum pa 'dis kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“When the sun comes out, infinite living beings all receive its benefits—it disperses the darkness and gives light, dries up moisture, causes plants and trees to grow, matures crops, permeates the sky, causes lotuses to bloom, allows travelers to see the road, allows people to do their work—because the orb of the sun radiates infinite beams of light everywhere. The sun of knowledge of Buddha is also like this, benefiting sentient beings everywhere by infinite works—destroying evil and producing good, breaking down ignorance and creating knowledge, benevolently saving, compassionately liberating, causing growth of faculties, powers, and elements of enlightenment, causing beings to develop profound faith, enabling them to see inevitable cause and effect, fostering in them the celestial eye to see where beings die and are born, causing their minds to be unimpeded and not destroy roots of goodness, causing them to cultivate illumination by knowledge and open the flower of awakening, causing them to determine to fulfill their fundamental task. Why? Because Buddha’s immense sun-body of knowledge and wisdom radiates infinite light, illumining everywhere. This is the third characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor de nyid 'dzam bu'i gling du 'char ba'i tshe/ thog ma nyid du ri'i rgyal po chen po 'di lta ste/ ri rab ri'i rgyal po la snang bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu de ma yin pa'i ri chen po gzhan la snang bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu ri nag po dag la'ang snang bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu sa phyogs mthon po rnams su snang bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu 'dzam bu'i gling 'di'i sa phyogs dma' ba dag kyang snang bar byed de/ 'on kyang nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor la/ 'dir ni thog ma nyid du 'od zer dgye'o zhe'am/ 'dir ni thog mar snang bar bya'o zhes bya ba'i rnam par rtog pa med de/ spros pa med kyang nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor 'od mnyam du gtong zhing 'char ba ni med pa ma yin te/ sa mthon dman gyi khyad par gyis mtho mtho la sngar 'char ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor yang; chos kyi dbyings mtha' dang dbus med pa'i ris su 'char bar 'gyur ba'i tshe/ rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par thogs pa med pa'i ye shes kyi 'od zer snang ba 'gyed de/ de yongs su bkye ba'i tshe yang thog ma nyid du lhag pa'i bsam pa/ ri'i rgyal po chen po lta bu dang ldan pa'i skyes bu dam pa rnams la/ chos kyi snang ba chen po yang dag par ston pa'i tshul du 'char bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi theg par zhugs pa rnams la 'char bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu dge ba'i rtsa ba nges pa dang ldan pa'i sems can rnams la bsam pa'i snod ji lta ba bzhin du ye shes kyi snang ba chen po yang dag par bstan pa'i tshul gyis 'char bar 'gyur ro/ /de'i 'og tu chung ngu na log par nges pa'i sems can yan chad sems can thams cad la'ang de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi 'od zer chen po 'char bar 'gyur ro/ /de ltar shar nas kyang sems can rnams la shin tu phan par 'gyur te/ ma 'ongs pa'i rgyu'ang yongs su smin par mdzad cing / dge ba'i chos kyis rnam par 'phel bar mdzad kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i 'od zer de dag ni/ sems can 'di rnams la bdag cag gis thog ma nyid du theg pa chen pos snang bar byas te/ de'i 'og tu bsam pa 'bring dang ldan pa rnams la/ nyan thos dang; rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pas rnam par dag par bya ba'i phyir snang bar bya'o/ /de'i 'og tu sems can dge ba'i bsam pa can mos pa'i theg pa dang ldan pa rnams la bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su smin par bya ba'i tshul gyis snang bar bya'o/ /de'i 'og tu chung ngu na sems can log par nges pa yan chad sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su sbyang bar bya'o/ /blta ba bsrang bar bya'o zhes rnam par rtog pa mi mnga'/ spros pa mi mnga' ste/ 'on kyang 'od zer mnyam par 'gyed pas/ 'od zer gyi mnyam pa nyid du kun tu bsgribs pa med par sems can thams cad la rab tu snang bar 'gyur te/ de ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor la rnam par rtog pa mi mnga' ba'i phyir ro/ /de yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor rnam par rtog pa med cing / 'od zer mnyam pa nyid du 'char yang ri chen po rnams la rnam pa tha dad du snang bar 'gyur ro/ /de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor rnam par rtog pa mi mnga' zhing / 'od zer mnyam pa nyid du 'char yang / sems can rnams kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam pa tha dad pa dang / bsam pa'i rnam pa tha dad pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'od zer rnam pa tha dad pa yang snang zhing yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo bzhi pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“When the sun rises, first it lights up the highest mountains, then the lower mountains, then the high plateaus, and finally the whole land; but the sun does not think, ‘First I will illumine here, afterward I will illumine there’—it is just because of difference in height of the mountains and land that there is a succession in illumination. The Buddha, similarly, having developed the boundless orb of knowledge of the realm of reality, always radiating the light of unimpeded knowledge, first of all illumines the high mountains, which are the great enlightening beings, then illumines those who are awakened by understanding of conditioning, then illumines those who listen to the message, then illumines sentient beings whose foundations of goodness are sure and stable, revealing vast knowledge according to beings’ mental capacities, finally illumining all sentient beings, even reaching those who are fixated on error, to be a beneficial cause for the future, that they may develop to maturity. But the light of the sun of great knowledge of Buddha does not think, ‘I will first illumine the great deeds of enlightening beings and at the very last shine on the sentient beings who are fixated on error’—it just radiates the light, shining equally on all, without obstruction or impediment, without discrimination. Just as the sun and moon appear in their time and impersonally shine on the mountains and valleys, so also does the knowledge of Buddha shine on all without discrimination, while the light of knowledge has various differences according to the differences in faculties and inclinations of sentient beings. This is the fourth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor de nyid shar kyang sems can dmus long rnams kyi mig lam du snang bar mi 'gyur te/ de ni mig dang mi ldan pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras; de ltar nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor de sems can dmus long rnams mig dang mi ldan pa'i phyir mig lam du mi snang du zin gyis kyang / sems can dmus long rnams la'ang nyi mar gdags pa dang / kha zas 'ju ba dang / bde bar spyod pa dang / lus kyi grang ba bsal ba dang / lus yang ba dang / mig nad dang / lus la gnas pa'i nad rlung ngam mkhris pa'am/ bad kan las byung ba de dag thams cad sel bar byed pa'i sgor mi phan pa ma yin te/ phan 'dogs so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor yang / sems can lhag pa'i bsam pa'i mig ldongs par gyur pa/ mos pa log pa/ lta ba log pa/ sbyor ba log pa/ 'tsho ba log pa/ dmus long lta bur gyur pa'i mig lam du snang bar mi 'gyur te/ de ni dad pa'i mig dang mi ldan pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor sems can dmus long lta bur gyur pa'i dad pa'i mig dang mi ldan pa de dag gi mig lam du snang bar ma gyur du zin kyang / sems can rnam pa de lta bu dag la de bzhin gshegs pa'i mthus/ sems can de dag gi lus la mi bde ba/ rtse zhil bar 'gyur ba dang / ma 'ongs pa'i nyon mongs pa'i rgyu'i lhags pa sel ba'i sgor de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor phan par mi 'gyur ba ma yin te/ phan 'dogs so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa la yon tan rin po che thams cad yang dag par bsags pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi snang ba dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang; rnam par dag pas rnam par rol pa'i ye shes kyi snang ba dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / dbyangs chen pos ye shes rnam par dgod pa'i don snang ba dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / spyod pa thams cad kyis shin tu tshim par byed pa'i ye shes snang ba dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / sems can thams cad kyi the tshom thams cad yongs su bcad pa'i yul la rnam par rol pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / mi gnas pa'i ye shes rnam par 'phrul ba'i snang ba dang ldan pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / spros pa thams cad yang dag par gcad pa'i yul la ye shes kyis rnam par rol pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang / theg pa tha dad pa'i snod la dbyangs rab tu bsgrags pa zhes bya ba'i 'od zer dang; zhing gi rgyan du sems can yongs su smin par mdzad cing / skye ba rnam par sbyong bas rnam par rol pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi dbyangs zhes bya ba'i 'od zer mnga' ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras; 'od zer de dag la sogs pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i mdzod spu'i gseb kyi sgo gcig nas kyang 'od zer stong tshang bar 'byung ste/ lnga brgya ni 'og gi phyogs su gtogs so/ /lnga brgya ni steng gi phyogs su gtogs so/ /'od zer de dag mthong bar gyur na byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing gzhan dang gzhan na 'khod pa rnams kyis/ de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan tha dad pa rnams rab tu shes par 'gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i yul la mgo yongs su dag pa bcu rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i yul la mig yongs su dag pa bcu dang / rna ba yongs su dag pa bcu dang / sna yongs su dag pa bcu dang / lce yongs su dag pa bcu dang / lus yongs su dag pa bcu dang / lag pa yongs su dag pa bcu dang / rkang pa yongs su dag pa bcu dang / sa yongs su dag pa bcu dang / ye shes 'byams klas pa yongs su dag pa bcu rab tu 'thob par 'gyur te/ de dag gi skye mched byang chub sems dpa'i sar grub pa de dag gis 'od zer de dag mthong zhing shes par gyur nas kyang / de dag gi skye mched de dag de bas kyang rnam par dag par gyur te/ de dag gi dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyang thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du yongs su smin par 'gyur ro/ /nyan thos kyi theg pa pa dang / rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa pa rnams la yang / phyogs gcig gi sar dri ma thams cad yongs su byang ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sems can dmus long lta bu rnams kyis kyang / lus kyi bde ba rab tu 'thob cing yongs su rdzogs pa dang / skyon med pa dang / rnam par dag pa dang / shin tu dul ba rab tu 'grub par 'gyur te/ de ni gong du yang rnam par bsgom pa'i ye shes rab tu 'grub pa'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sems can dmyal ba pa dang / byol song gi skye gnas pa dang / gshin rje'i 'jig rten pa'i sems can rnams dang / log par ltung ba'i sems can rnams la yang / lus kyi bde ba nye bar 'grub pa'i rgyur 'gyur te/ lus kyi bde ba de dang ldan par gyur nas kyang / log par ltung ba de dag nas shi 'phos shing 'grol bar 'gyur ro/ /log par ltung ba'i ngan song de dag nas shi 'phos nas kyang lha dang mir skye ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ sems can de dag gis ni/ khong ta bdag cag rgyu gang dang / rkyen gang dang / su'i mthus der skyes par gyur pa'ang mi shes/ khong du mi chud do/ / 'di lta ste/ dper na; sems can dmus long du gyur pa de dag 'di snyam sems te/ bdag cag ni tshangs pas byas pa ste/ tshangs pas sprul pa'o zhes bya ba'i lta ba'i rnam pa dang ldan yang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi dkyil 'khor kun tu rnam par 'phrul pa la bzhugs shing / sangs rgyas kyi gsung stong phrag drug cu dang ldan pas/ sems can de dag la bka' stsal te; grogs po dag / 'di ni tshangs pa'i zhing ma yin/ 'jig rten gyi mgon po'i zhing ma yin te/ 'di ni sangs rgyas kyi zhing ngo/ /khyed ni de bzhin gshegs pas yongs su smin par byas pa'o/ /zhes bka' stsal na/ sems can de dag kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis dran par gyur nas/ de dag de ma thag tu dga'; rangs shing yid bde bas rab tu dga' ba dang / bde ba'i nyams kyis yid spro ba dang ldan par gyur nas/ me tog gi sprin dang / spos kyi sprin dang / rol mo'i sprin dang; na bza'i sprin dang / gdugs kyi sprin dang / rgyal mtshan gyi sprin dang / ba dan gyi sprin dang / rin po che'i sprin dang / seng ge'i rgyal mtshan dang / zla ba kham pa'i khang pa brtsegs pa'i sprin dang / bstod pa'i sprin dang / rgyan sna tshogs shin tu bsgrubs pa'i sprin rgya chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa la rim gro byed do/ /bkur sti byed do/ /bsti stang byed do/ /mchod pa byed do/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de ni de dag gi lha'i mig rnam par dag par byas pa'i phyir te/ sems can de dag la'ang bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu/ de bzhin gshegs pa lung ston to/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sku nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor ni sems can dmus long du gyur pa rnams la yang dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su smin par mdzad pas phan 'dogs pa yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo lnga pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“When the sun comes out, those born blind cannot see it, because they have no faculty of vision; yet even though they do not see it, they are benefited by the light of the sun. Why? By this it is possible to know the times of day and night and to have access to food and clothing to comfort the body and free it from distress. The sun of knowledge of Buddha is also like this; the blind without faith or understanding, immoral and heedless, sustaining themselves by wrong means of livelihood, do not see the orb of the sun of knowledge of the Buddhas because they have no eye of faith, but even though they do not see it, they are still benefited by the sun of knowledge. Why? Because by the power of Buddha it makes the causes of future suffering of those beings—physical pains and psychological afflictions—all vanish.
“Buddha has a light called accumulating all virtues, a light called total universal illumination, a light called pure, free illumination, a light called producing great wondrous sound, a light called understanding all languages and gladdening others, a light called the realm of freedom showing the eternal cancellation of all doubts, a light called independent universal illumination of nondwelling knowledge, a light called free knowledge forever terminating all false descriptions, a light called producing marvelous sayings according to need, a light called producing free utterances adorning lands and maturing sentient beings. Each pore of the Buddha emits a thousand kinds of light like these: five hundred lights beam downward, five hundred lights beam upward, illumining the congregations of enlightening beings at the various places of the buddhas in the various lands; when the enlightening beings see these lights, all at once they realize the realm of buddhahood, with ten heads, ten eyes, ten ears, ten noses, ten tongues, ten bodies, ten hands, ten feet, ten stages, and ten knowledges, all thoroughly pure. The states and stages previously accomplished by those enlightening beings become more pure upon seeing these lights; their roots of goodness mature, and they proceed toward omniscience. Those in the two lesser vehicles have all their defilements removed. Some other beings, who are blind, their bodies blissful, also become purified in mind, gentle and docile, able to cultivate mindfulness and knowledge. The sentient beings in the realms of hells, hungry ghosts, and animals all become blissful and are freed from pains, and when their lives end are reborn in heaven or the human world. Those sentient beings are not aware, do not know by what cause, by what spiritual power, they came to be born there. Those blind ones think, ‘We are Brahma gods, we are emanations of Brahma.’ Then Buddha, in the concentration of universal freedom, says to them, ‘You are not Brahma gods, not emanations of Brahma, nor were you created by the king-god Indra or the world-guardian gods: all this is the spiritual power of Buddha.’ Having heard this, those sentient beings, by the spiritual power of Buddha, all know their past life and become very happy. Because their hearts are joyful, they naturally produce clouds of udumbara flowers, clouds of fragrances, music, cloth, parasols, banners, pennants, aromatic powders, jewels, towers adorned with lion banners and crescents, clouds of songs of praise, clouds of all kinds of adornments, and respectfully offer them to the Buddha. Why? Because these sentient beings have gained clear eyes, and therefore the Buddha gives them the prophecy of unexcelled, complete perfect enlightenment. In this way Buddha’s sun of knowledge benefits sentient beings born blind, fostering the full development of basic goodness. This is the fifth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it this way.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ zla ba'i dkyil 'khor 'char bar 'gyur ba'i tshe rmad du byung ba'i chos bzhi snga phyi med par byed de/ bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ skar ma thams cad zil gyis gnon to/ /'phel ba dang; 'grib pa yang yongs su ston to/ /'dzam bu'i gling thams cad kyi chu dang ba'i snod kun tu'ang gzugs brnyan rab tu snang ngo/ /sems can kun gyis bltas na'ang mngon sum du gnas par snang ste/ de la rnam par rtog pa med do/ /sprul pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku zla ba'i dkyil 'khor yang / rmad du byung ba'i chos bzhi snga phyi med par ston to/ /bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ slob pa dang mi slob pa thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyi yon tan rnam pa thams cad du zil gyis gnon to/ /ji lta bur mos pa'i sems can rnams kyi lta ba rnam pa tha dad pa'i tshul dang / sku tshe'i tshad rnam pa tha dad pa yang yang dag par ston te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku zla ba'i dkyil 'khor la 'phel ba dang / 'grib pa mi mnga'o/ /'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / sems yongs su dag cing / mos pa yongs su bsgoms pa'i stobs dang / shugs su ldan pa'i sems can byang chub kyi snod rnams la'ang gzugs brnyan rab tu 'byung ngo; ;sems can kun gyis bltas kyang / bdag bdag la mngon du gzigs par 'dzin te/ bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du chos nyan/ theg pa gang gis 'dul ba'i sa ci bzhin du rnam par grol bar 'gyur te/ sems can ji lta bur 'dul ba bzhin du snang ba'i tshul gyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'ang rab tu ston te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku zla ba'i dkyil 'khor de la rnam par rtog pa mi mnga'/ spros pa mi mnga'o/ /rnam par rtog pa mi mnga' zhing spros pa mi mnga' bas kyang 'phrin las de dag la rab tu spyod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo drug pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“Furthermore, it is like the moon, with four special extraordinary qualities: first, it outshines all the stars; second, as time passes it shows waning and waxing; third, its reflection appears in all clear waters; fourth, all who see it see it right before them, yet the moon has no discrimination and no arbitrary conceptions. The moon of the body of Buddha similarly has four special extraordinary qualities: it outshines all hearers and individual illuminates, whether they are in the stage of learning or beyond learning; according to the needs of the situation, it manifests different life spans, yet without increase or decrease in the Buddha-body; its reflection appears in all vessels of enlightenment, sentient beings with pure minds, in all worlds; all sentient beings who behold it think the Buddha is in their presence alone. According to their inclinations, Buddha teaches them, liberating them according to their states, causing them to perceive the Buddha-body according to their needs and potentials for edification, yet the Buddha-body has no discrimination, no arbitrary conceptions; all benefits it renders reach the ultimate end. This is the sixth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i bdag po tshangs pa chen po ni/ las gron chung ngus stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du lus yongs su ston te/ 'on kyang lus yongs su 'byed pa med do/ /lus tha dad par byed pa med do/ /stong gsum gyi stong chen por gtogs pa'i sems can rnams kyis kyang / bsam pa mnyam pa nyid ji lta bu dang ldan pa'i tshul bzhin du lus mnyam pa nyid du mthong ngo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras; de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa yang / sku yongs su 'byed pa mi mdzad/ sku tha dad par mdzad pa yang mi mnga' bar 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa'i sems can rnams la yang bsam pa dang / mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du sku yongs su ston te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku la rnam par rtog pa mi mnga'/ spros pa mi mnga'o/ /kye rgyal pa'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo bdun pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“Furthermore, just as the supreme Brahma god of a billion-world universe simply manifests its body in the billion worlds, and all beings see Brahma before them, yet Brahma does not divide its body and does not have multiple bodies, in the same way the buddhas have no discrimination, no false representations, and do not divide their bodies or have multiple bodies, yet they manifest their bodies in accord with the inclinations of all sentient beings, without thinking that they manifest so many bodies. This is the seventh characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it this way.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ sman pa'i rgyal po chen po sman gyi yo byad dang / cho ga la shin tu mkhas pa gtsug lag dang sngags thams cad kyi tshul shes pa zhig yod la/ 'dzam bu'i gling gi sman thams cad de'i dbang du gyur te/ sman pa'i rgyal po chen po de'i sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i stobs kyi shugs dang / sngags dang / rig sngags kyi mthu dang / thabs kyis mthong ma thag tu sems can rnams kyi nad yongs su 'tsho bar 'gyur zhing / nad med par 'gyur ba zhig yod de/ de nas sman pa'i rgyal po de 'chi ba'i dus la bab par gyur na/ de 'di snyam du sems par gyur te/ kyi hud sems can 'di dag bdag shi ba dang mgon med par 'gyur gyi/ bdag gi thabs mkhas pa'i stobs kyis sman thams cad yongs su bsdus te/ bdag gi lus la bsku'o/ /sngags dang rig sngags kyi stobs dang / byin gyi rlabs kyis kyang bdag gi lus byin gyis brlabs te/ ci nas kyang bdag shi nas lus mi 'jig pa dang / mi skam pa dang / mi nyams shing 'gro ba dang / 'ong ba dang / 'dug pas kyang spyod pa dang / nad thams cad sos par bya ba'i phyir/ sman pa'i las su bya ba thams cad kyang spyod cing blta ba dang / mnyan pa'i don spyod pas kyang sngon ji lta ba bzhin du phyin chad kyang gnas par bya'o snyam du sems pa zhig yod na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas sman pa'i rgyal po chen po bla na med pa nyon mongs pa'i nad thams cad rab tu zhi bar mdzad pa la mkhas pa/ bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong mang pos kun mkhyen pa'i rtsi la/ brtson 'grus shin tu mdzad pa/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i thabs mkhas pa dang / sngags dang / rig sngags la shin tu bslabs pa/ stobs dang mi bsnyengs pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos ma 'dres pa la rab tu mkhas pa sems can thams cad yongs su smin par bya ba dang / gdul ba'i tshul mkhyen pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi mnga' chen po brnyes pa des kyang / sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la bzhugs shing / bsod nams dang / ye shes kyi tshogs dang / shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i thabs mkhas pa'i sngags dang / rig sngags dang / sman gyi mthus phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i bskal par 'gro ba thams cad kyi nyon mongs pa'i nad gso ba'i phyir/ sku tshe'i tshad byin gyis brlabs pas/ de'i sku yongs su dag pa'i phyir/ mthong ma thag tu ched du mi mdzad cing lhun gyis grub par sems can rnams kyi nyon mongs pa'i nad thams cad rab tu zhi bar 'gyur te; sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las thams cad kyang rgyun mi 'chad par 'byung ngo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo brgyad pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“A master physician is well versed in all medications and the science of hypnosis, fully uses all the medicines in the land, and, also because of the power of the physician’s past roots of goodness, and because of using hypnotic spells as an expedient, all those who see the physician recover from illness. That master physician, sensing impending death, thinks, ‘After I die, sentient beings will have no one to rely on; I should manifest an expedient for them.’ Then the master physician compounds drugs, which he smears on his body, and supports his body by spell power, so that it will not decay or shrivel after death, so its bearing, seeing, and hearing will be no different from before, and all cures will be effected. The Buddha, the Truly Enlightened One, the unexcelled master physician, is also like this, having developed and perfected the medicines of the Teaching over countless eons, having cultivated and learned all skills in application of means and fully consummated the power of illuminating spells, is able to quell all sentient beings’ afflictions. Buddha’s life spans measureless eons, the body pure, without any cogitation, without activity, never ceasing the works of buddhas; the afflictions of all sentient beings who see Buddha dissolve away. This is the eighth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it in this way.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na nor bu rin po che chen po 'od thams cad 'dus pas rnam par snang ba'i snying po zhes bya ba yod de/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ nor bu rin po che chen po de'i 'od kyis/ sems can gang la bab pa de dag thams cad kyang 'di lta ste/ nor bu rin po che 'od thams cad 'dus pas/ rnam par snang ba'i snying po'i kha dog tu kha dog gcig par 'gyur ro/ /gang gis nor bu rin po che de mthong bar gyur ba de dag gi mig kyang yongs su dag par 'gyur ro/ /nor bu rin po che de'i 'od kyi dkyil 'khor gyis ji tsam du khyab par gyur pa de tsam du 'od kyi dkyil 'khor de las/ sems can bde bar byed pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che'i char 'bab par 'gyur te/ des sems can de dag kyang rab tu bde bar 'gyur la/ sdug bsngal yang rgyun 'chad par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ltos dang / nor bu rin po che de chos ci la yang mi rtog na/ 'on kyang don chen po rab tu sgrub bo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa la yang sku rin po che chen po bsod nams thams cad yongs su bsdus pas/ ye shes chen po'i snying po dang ldan pa mnga' ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku rin po che'i ye shes kyi 'od zer de dag gis/ sems can ji snyed la reg par gyur pa de dag thams cad kyang / 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'i kha dog tu kha dog gcig par 'gyur ro/ /sems can gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku mthong bar gyur pa de dag gi chos kyi mig kyang rnam par dag par 'gyur ro/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku rin po che'i 'od zer gyi dra ba'i dkyil 'khor gyis sems can ji snyed la reg pa de dag thams cad kyang / dbul ba dang yongs su bral bar 'gyur te/ byang chub kyi sgo'i bar gyi de bzhin gshegs pa'i bde ba yang rab tu 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ltos dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku chos gang la yang rtog pa mi mnga' ste/ spros pa mi mnga' yang 'gro ba thams cad kyi don yongs su thob par mdzad do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo dgu pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“In the ocean there is a great jewel called radiant repository, in which are assembled all lights: if any sentient beings touch its light, they become assimilated to its color; if any see it, their eyes are purified; whenever the light shines it rains jewels called felicity that soothe and comfort beings. The body of Buddha is also like this, being a treasury of knowledge in which are collected all virtues: if any sentient beings come in contact with the light of precious knowledge of the body of Buddha, they become the same as Buddha in appearance; if any see it their eye of reality is purified; wherever that light shines, it frees sentient beings from the miseries of poverty and ultimately imbues them with the bliss of enlightenment. The body of Buddha has no discrimination and no false conceptions, but can perform great buddha-works for all sentient beings. This is the ninth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it in this way.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ rin po che'i rgyal po chen po yid bzhin gyi nor bu 'gro ba thams cad kyi rgyan gyi snying po zhes bya ba yod de/ rin po che'i rgyal po de ni yon tan brgya stong phrag bcu dang ldan pa ste/ nor bu rin po che'i rgyal po de gang na 'dug pa de 'khor gyi sems can kun gyi nad dang / sdug bsngal gyi gtse ba thams cad med par 'gyur ro/ /sems can ji snyed cig nor bu rin po che'i rgyal po de la/ 'dod pas sems pa de dag thams cad kyi bsam pa yongs su rdzogs par byed de/ rin po che'i rgyal po chen po de ni bsod nams ma byas pa'i sems can rnams kyi mig lam du snang bar 'gyur ba ma yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de la nor bu rin po che'i rgyal po chen po zhes bya ba de ni / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku sems can thams cad shin tu tshim par mdzad pa'i tshig bla te/ gang na de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bltar yod cing mtshan mnyan du yod la/ yon tan dang / legs pa yongs su brjod du yod pa de phyogs kyi sems can kun gyi 'khor ba la gnas pa'i sdug bsngal dang / mi bde ba thams cad med par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku rin po che de ni/ ci ste sems can 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du gtogs pa kun gyis snga phyi med par sems rtse gcig tu yid la bya ba ma 'khrugs pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku blta ba'i phyir dmigs pa byas na de dag thams cad kyis so so nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'ang mthong bar 'gyur la/ thams cad kyi chos kyi bsam pa yang yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ro/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku de yang sems can 'dul ba'i dbang du de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis bstan pa ma gtogs par sems can bsod nams ma byas pa rnams kyi mig lam du snang bar mi 'gyur te/ sems can su la'ang rung ste/ dge ba'i rtsa ba de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bstan pas yongs su smin par bya ba zhig yod na/ de dag yongs su smin par bya ba'i don du de bzhin gshegs pa sku rin po che ston to; ; kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po sems tshad med pa'i rjes su song zhing / phyogs kyi dra ba thams cad rgyas par 'gengs pa/ nam mkha' lta bur chags pa med pa'i spyod yul dang ldan pa/ chos kyi dbyings mnyam pa nyid khong du chud pa yang dag pa'i mtha' mnyam pa nyid la gnas pa/ de bzhin nyid la gnas pa/ de bzhin nyid ma skyes ma 'gags pa dang / dus gsum mnyam pa nyid kyi rjes su song ba rtog pa dang / rnam par rtog pa dang / yongs su rtog pa thams cad dang bral ba phyi ma'i mtha'i mur thug pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa la zhugs pa; 'jig rten gyi khams dang / chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad du khyab pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad dang / sku'i rgyun gcig tu gyur pas khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo'dis kyang; de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi sku bltar yod pa shes par bya'o/ /

“In the ocean is a great wish-fulfilling jewel called treasury of adornments of all worlds, fully endowed with a million qualities, eliminating calamities and fulfilling wishes of beings wherever it is. However, this jewel cannot be seen by beings of little merit. The supreme wish-fulfilling jewel of the body of Buddha is also like this; called able to gladden all beings, if any sentient beings see the body of Buddha, hear the name, and praise the virtues, they will all be enabled to escape forever the pains and ills of birth and death. Even if all beings in all worlds focus their minds all at once on the desire to see Buddha, they will all be enabled to see and their wish will be fulfilled. The Buddha-body cannot be seen by sentient beings of little merit unless they can be tamed by the spiritual power of Buddha; if sentient beings, because of seeing the body of Buddha, plant roots of goodness and develop them, they are enabled to see the body of Buddha for their development. This is the tenth characteristic of the body of Buddha; great enlightening beings should see it thus, because their minds are measureless, pervading the ten directions, because their actions are as unhindered as space, because they penetrate everywhere in the realm of reality, because they abide in absolute truth, because they have no birth or death, because they remain equal throughout past, present, and future, because they are forever rid of all false discriminations, because they continue their eternal vows, because they purify all worlds, because they adorn each buddha-body.”
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos/ don 'di nyid yang brtag par bya ba'i phyir/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the great enlightening being Universally Good, in order to again clarify what he meant, said in verse,

ji ltar mkha' dbyings kun tu mu med dbyings yin te/ / gzugs dang gzugs med de bzhin dngos dang dngos med kun/ / phyogs dang phyogs mtshams kun dang sems can lus dang zhing / / dus gsum ma lus mkha' dbyings des khyab bo/ /
de bzhin gshegs sku kun nas bltar yod de bzhin te/ / 'jig rten khams dang chos dbyings mi khyab gang yang med/ / rnam pa kun tu bltar med gzung med rgyal ba'i sku/ / 'dul ba'i don yod mgon po'i sku ni bltar med min/ /
ji ltar mkha' dbyings 'di ni gzung med dbyings yin pas/ / 'gro ba kun gyi las kyi rnam pa ma lus gnas/ / 'on kyang bdag gis gang du ji ltar su yi don/ / ci dang ci zhig bya zhes mkha' dbyings rtog pa med/ /
de bzhin skyes mchog sku yi 'phrin las brten byas te/ / phyogs bcu kun nas dkar po'i chos rnams ci yod pa/ / sna tshogs mi rnams byed kyang sangs rgyas sku la ni/ / 'di yi don zhig bya zhes yongs su rtog mi mnga'/ /
ji ltar 'dzam bu'i gling du nyi ma 'char 'gyur tshe/ / mun pa ma lus sel cing rab tu snang ba byed/ / shing dang pad+mo'i nags tshal sa rnams gar bab pa'i/ / sna tshogs gnas kyis sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho/ /
de bzhin rgyal ba'i nyi ma sems can kun 'tsho ste/ / lha mi 'jig rten rnams kyi 'dus byas dge rtsa la/ / mun pa'i thibs po bsal cing shes rab snang 'gyur bas/ / mi yi dbang po mchog mthong bde ba thams cad 'thob/ /
nyi ma'i 'od zer thog ma ri rab khor yug la/ / shar nas de yi 'og tu ri bo mang la 'char/ / de nas sa steng 'di yi phyogs rnams mtho mtho la/ / de nas sa steng dma' ba'i phyogs rnams snang bar byed/ /
bde gshegs 'od zer thog mar rgyal sras lus la 'char/ / de yi 'og tu rang rgyal theg pa la gnas par 'char/ / de nas dbang bsgyur de nas slob pa'i rnams la 'char/ / de nas ma lus 'gro 'char sangs rgyas rtog mi mnga'/ /
mig dang mi ldan nyi ma kun tu snang mi mthong / / 'on kyang nyi ma'i grangs kyis de dag nye bar 'tsho/ / bkres pa spong zhing lus la shin tu lham par byed/ / de ltar sems can thams cad nyi mas nye bar 'tsho/ /
dad dang mi ldan sangs rgyas nyi ma mi mthong ste/ / 'on kyang rgyal ba'i byin gyis de yang nye bar 'tsho/ / rgyal ba'i mtshan thos bde gshegs 'od la reg gyur kyang / / de la byang chub go 'phang bar gyi rgyur 'gyur ro/ /

Just as space pervades the ten directions, Like form but not a form, existent but not existent, Omnipresent, without bounds, In beings’ bodies and lands, in all times,
So does the true body of buddhas Pervade all phenomena, Invisible, ungraspable, Yet manifesting bodies to teach beings.
Just as space cannot be grasped Yet lets all beings do their work Without thinking what it does, How it does it, or for whom,
The physical action of buddhas is also thus, Causing beings to practice good ways, Yet the buddha never has any notion Of acting on them variously.
When the sun comes up over the land It completely removes the darkness. Mountains, trees, lakes, flowers, earth, and all beings, All the various species receive benefit.
The sun of Buddha emerging too is thus, Causing human and celestial good actions to grow, Obliterating the darkness of ignorance so they gain the light of knowledge And always experience all glorious bliss.
When the sun first comes up It shines first on the high mountains, then the others, Then shines on the high plains, then the whole land, Yet the sun never has any discrimination.
The light of Buddha is also thus, First illumining the enlightening beings, then the self-enlightened, Then last the listeners and all sentient beings, Yet the Buddha basically has no stirring thoughts.
Just as the blind cannot see the sun, Yet sunlight still benefits them, Enabling them to know time and season and receive food and drink, To be freed from troubles and gain physical ease,
In the same way faithless beings do not see Buddha, Yet Buddha benefits them as well; By hearing Buddha’s name or being touched by Buddha’s light They can even reach enlightenment.

zla ba shar ba skar ma thams cad zil gyis gnon/ / 'gro ba rnams la 'phel dang 'grib pa yang du ston/ / chu mtsho kun la gzugs brnyan rab tu snang bar byed/ / gang rnams chu la lta ba de la mngon par snang / /
rgyal ba'i zla ba shar ba nyan thos zil gyis gnon/ / 'dul pa ji bzhin rang sku 'phel dang 'grib pa ston/ / lha dang mi yi sems la gzugs brnyan rab tu snang / / 'gro ba kun gyis bdag bdag mdun na bzhugs par shes/ /
tshangs pa ji ltar tshangs pa'i gnas nas ma g.yos kyang / / stong gsum tshangs gnas kun tu rang gi lus kyang ston/ / lha dang mi rnams rang gi lus kyi dbang du byed/ / tshangs pa rang gi lus kyang tha dad byed pa min/ /
de bzhin chos rnams kun la mnga' 'gyur ston pa yang / / phyogs bcu kun tu sku gzugs mtha' yas ston par mdzad/ / dpe zla med pa rnams kyi sku la dbye ba med/ / mi rnams kun kyang so so'i ston pa mngon 'gyur shes/ /
ji ltar gtsug lag kun la mkhas pa'i sman pa zhig / gang gis mthong bar gyur pa de dag nad 'jig pa/ / gang tshe tshe zad 'chir 'gyur de tshe sman bsdus shing / / rang gi lus la bskus te spyod pa thams cad ston/ /
de ltar mi mchog dbang po mtshungs med sman pa'i rgyal/ / thabs dang shes rab ye shes kun la rab mkhas pa/ / sngon gyi spyod pa'i khyad kyis ston pa'i sku ston te/ / mthong zhing 'gro ba'i nyon mongs ma lus nad kyang 'jil/ /
ji ltar gangs chen mtsho la rin chen 'byung yod pa/ / 'od kyi rnam pa thams cad kun tu 'gyed byed de/ / sems can gang la reg pa de dag de tshul 'gyur/ / gang gis mthong 'gyur de dag mig kyang rnam par dag /
rgyal ba rin chen de bzhin shes rab 'od 'gyed de/ / sems can sus reg de dag sangs rgyas kha dog 'gyur/ / gang gis rgyal ba mthong ba de dag mig lnga 'thob par 'gyur/ / mun pa rdul bsal rgyal ba'i sa la gnas par 'gyur/ /
ji ltar nor bu rin chen bsam pa kun ster ba/ / gang rnams ci 'dod de la de dag thams cad 'byin/ / de ni bsod nams gang gis byas pa des mthong ste/ / rin chen dam pa de la rnam rtog gang yang med/ /
de bzhin bde gshegs sku mchog bsam pa kun skong ba/ / mthong nas smon lam su 'debs de dag bsam pa 'grub/ / snying ring dma' ba'i sems ldan 'gro bas thub mi mthong / / bde gshegs rnam rtog mi mnga' ser sna mi mnga'o// //

Just as the moon in the sky Outshines the stars and appears to wax and wane, Shows its reflection in all waters, And appears face to face with those who behold it,
The clear moon of Buddha is also thus, Outshining other vehicles, showing length and brevity, Appearing in the clear mind-water of humans and gods, Seeming to be present to everyone.
Just as the god Brahma, while in its own palace, Appears in all the Brahma abodes in the universe So all humans and celestials can see it, Yet does not actually divide its body to go to them,
Likewise does the Buddha’s manifestation of bodies Pervade everywhere in the ten directions, Those bodies countless, incalculable in number, Yet without dividing bodies, without discrimination.
Like a physician skilled in his arts, Seeing whom all are cured, And though his life is ended he embalms his body So that it will work as before,
So also does the Supreme Healer Have all knowledge of techniques, Manifesting embodiment as Buddha by excellent practices of yore, So the afflictions of all who see are destroyed.
In the ocean is a superb jewel Which radiates countless beams of light; Those who come in contact with it become the same color, And the eyes of those who see it are purified:
The Supreme Jewel is also thus; Those whom its light touches become the same in appearance, In those who get to see it the five eyes open; They break through the darkness of the senses and dwell in buddhahood.
The wish-fulfilling jewel Satisfies all desires; Those of little virtue cannot see it, Though this is not by the jewel’s discrimination:
The jewel of Buddha is also thus, Fulfilling all desires; Faithless beings cannot see it, But not because Buddha abandons them.
bam po bdun cu gnyis pa/

de skad ces smras pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su 'byung ba'i dpal gyis/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ji ltar byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi gsung brjod pa khong du chud par bya/ de skad ces smras pa dang /
“How should great enlightening beings know the voice of Buddha?

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su byung ba'i dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi gsung brjod pa ni/ dbyangs kyi dkyil 'khor tshad med pas rgyas shing khyab par mdzad pa'i phyir/ kun tu khyab par shes par bya'o/ /chos bstan pa mngon par bsgrub pa'i phyir/ sems can thams cad kyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du tshim par mdzad par shes par bya'o/ /sems rab tu tshim par mdzad pa'i phyir/ 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor thams cad mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du dga' bar mdzad par shes par bya'o/ /dus las mi 'da' ba'i phyir/ dus la ji ltar 'das pa bzhin du 'bral ba med par shes par bya'o/ /sgra brnyan dang 'dra ba'i phyir shin tu mi skye mi 'gag par shes par bya'o/ /las bsags pa thams cad yongs su brjod pa'i phyir/ bdag po med par shes par bya'o/ /gting dpag dka' ba'i phyir shin tu zab par shes pa'o/ /chos kyi dbyings la zhen pas cis kyang mi tshugs par shes par bya'o/ /chos nyid la yang dag par gzhol bas rgyun mi 'chad par shes par bya'o/ /shin tu gnas la phebs pa'i mtha' thug pas skyor med par shes par bya ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung brjod pa ni bdag po yod pa yang ma yin/ bdag po med pa yang ma yin pa dang / rnam par dmigs pa yang ma yin/ rnam par mi dmigs pa yang ma yin par shes bya'o; ;de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ 'jig rten gyi khams 'jig par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ chos nyid thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po bzhi 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de dag la bdag po med cing yongs su 'dzin pa med do/ /bzhi gang zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ 'jig rten gyi khams 'jig par 'gyur ba'i tshe / sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po thog ma rnam pa 'di lta bu 'byung ste/ kye ma grogs po dag /bsam gtan dang po ni 'dod pa dang / gnod sems med pas shin tu bde ba ste/ 'dod pa'i khams las yang dag par 'da' ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sgra de thos nas sems can rnams bsam gtan dang po bsgrubs te /'dod pa'i khams las 'das nas/ tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du skye'o/ /de nas chos nyid thob pas/ sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po gnyis pa 'byung ste/ kye ma grogs po dag /bsam gtan gnyis pa 'di ni rnam par rtog pa med cing / rnam par dpyod pa med pas shin tu bde ba ste/ tshangs ris kyi lha las yang dag par 'da' ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can rnams bsam gtan gnyis pa bsgrubs te/ tshangs pa'i 'jig rten las 'das nas gya nom snang ba'i lha dang skal ba mnyam par skye'o/ /de nas chos nyid rab tu thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po gsum pa 'byung ste/ kye ma grogs po dag /bsam gtan gsum pa 'di ni dga' ba med pas shin tu bde ba ste/ gya nom snang ba'i lha las yang dag par 'da' ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can rnams bsam gtan gsum pa bsgrubs te/ gya nom snang ba'i lha las 'das nas/ dge rgyas kyi lha dang skal ba mnyam par skye'o/ /de nas chos nyid rab tu thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po bzhi pa 'byung ste/ kye ma grogs po dag /bsam gtan bzhi pa 'di ni shin tu zhi ba ste/ dge rgyas kyi lha las yang dag par 'da' ba'i rgyur 'gyur ro/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can rnams bsam gtan bzhi pa bsgrubs te/ dge rgyas kyi lha las 'das nas/ 'bras bu che ba'i lha dang skal ba mnyam par skye'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar 'jig rten gyi khams 'jig par 'gyur ba'i tshe/ chos nyid rab tu thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po de bzhi 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de la bdag po'am rjod par byed pa gang yang med mod kyi/ de ltar tshad med pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa'i sgra rnams 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung la'ang bdag po gang yang med de/ rjod par byed pa med do/ /'phro bar byed pa med do/ /len pa med do/ /gtong ba med do/ /'on kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid thob pas/ sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po bzhi 'byung bar 'gyur te/ bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid thob pas sgra chen po gcig 'byung ba ni/ kye ma/ 'dus byas 'di dag sdug bsngal pa ste/ sems can dmyal ba ni sdug bsngal lo/ /byol song gi skye gnas ni sdug bsngal lo/ /gshin rje'i 'jig rten ni sdug bsngal lo/ /bsod nams ma byas pa ni sdug bsngal lo/ /bdag gir 'dzin pa ni sdug bsngal te/ sdig pa'i las spyod pa ni sdug bsngal gyi/ lha dang mir skye ba'i phyir dge ba'i rtsa ba skyed cig /'phags pa'i skye mched yongs su gzung zhig /mi khom par skye ba yongs su spongs shig /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can rnams ma nor bar nan tan rab tu byed de/ de dag ma nor bar nan tan byed cing dge ba yongs su spyod do/ /de dag dge ba spyod pa'i nan tan la zhugs pas/ mi khom par skye ba yongs su spong ste/ lha dang mir skye ba'i skye mched kyang rab tu 'dzin to/ /de nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid rab tu thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po gnyis pa 'byung ste/ kye ma/ 'dus byas 'di dag ni/ shin tu sdug bsngal ba ste/ 'bar ba/ kun nas 'bar ba /rab tu 'bar ba lcags kyi gong bu dang 'dra ba/ mi rtag cing 'gyur ba'i chos can dag go /'dus ma byas ni zhi ba/ gdung ba med pa/ bsil ba/ yongs su gdung ba dang bral ba'o/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can rnams dge ba'i chos la mngon par brtson par byed de/ de ltar mngon par brtson pas nyan thos kyi theg pa la sgra'i rjes su 'gro ba'i bzod pa thob par 'gyur ro/ /de nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po gsum pa 'byung ste/ kye ma/ nyan thos kyi theg pa 'di ni gzhan gyi sgra'i rjes su 'brang bas shin tu chung ba ste/ 'di bas mtho ba'i theg pa 'di lta ste/ rang gis mngon par 'tshang rgya bar bya ba slob dpon med par rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa yod do/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can mos pa che ba rnams rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa la nan tan byed cing / nyan thos kyi theg pa spangs nas/ rang sangs rgyas kyi byang chub tu 'jug go /de nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid rab tu thob pas sgra chen po'i dbyangs chen po bzhi pa 'byung ste/ kye ma; nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa las 'das pa'i theg pa chen po/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa dang mthun pa/ pha rol tu phyin pa drug dang / byang chub kyi spyod pa rgyun mi 'chad pa/ byang chub kyi sems yongs su mi gtong ba/ bsod nams dang / ye shes kyi tshogs tshad med pas yongs su bzung ba yod de/ nyan thos kyi theg pa ni gzhan gyi sgra'i rjes su 'brang ba'o/ /rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa ni shin tu chung ba'o/ /theg pa chen po ni theg pa'i dam pa/ theg pa'i gtso bo/ theg pa'i mchog ste/ bla na med pa'i theg pa/ sems can thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba'i theg pa'o/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can de bas kyang yangs pa la mos pa/ dbang po rno ba/ sngon dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed pa; de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs kyis byin du brlabs pa de dag snying thag pa nas/ de bzhin gshegs pa rang 'byung gi byang chub tu sems bskyed de/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung de yang sku las 'byung ba ma yin/ thugs las 'byung ba ma yin te/ sems can rnams kyi dge ba'i las shin tu bsags pas khong du chud par 'gyur ba'ang med pa ma yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo dang po 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o/ /

They should know Buddha’s voice is omnipresent, because it pervades all sounds. They should know Buddha’s voice pleases all according to their mentalities, because its explanation of truth is clear and comprehensive. They should know Buddha’s voice gladdens all according to their resolve, because their minds gain clarity and coolness. They should know Buddha’s voice teaches without error in timing, because all who need and are able to hear it do. They should know Buddha’s voice has no birth or death, because it is like the echo of a call. They should know Buddha’s voice has no owner, because it is produced by cultivation of all appropriate practices. They should know Buddha’s voice is extremely profound, because it cannot be measured. They should know Buddha’s voice has no falsehood or deviousness, because it is born of the realm of truth. They should know Buddha’s voice has no end, because it permeates the cosmos. They should know Buddha’s voice has no change, because it reaches the ultimate.
“Great enlightening beings should know that Buddha’s voice is neither quantified nor unquantified, neither has a master nor lacks a master, neither communicates nor does not communicate. Why? It is as when the world is about to disintegrate, there is no master, no maker, yet it spontaneously emits four voices. One says, ‘You all should know that the well-being of the first meditation stage, free from the ills of desire, surpasses the realm of desire.’ The sentient beings hearing this are naturally able to accomplish the first meditation stage, relinquish the body of the realm of desire and be born in Brahma heaven. The second voice says, ‘You should know that the well-being of the second meditation stage, without reflection and rumination, surpasses the Brahma heaven.’ The sentient beings hearing this naturally manage to accomplish the second meditation stage, relinquish the body of Brahma heaven, and are born in the light-sound heaven. The third voice says, ‘You should know that the well-being of the third meditation stage has no flaws and surpasses the light-sound heaven.’ Hearing this, the sentient beings are naturally able to achieve the third meditation stage, relinquish the body of the light-sound heaven, and are born in the heaven of universal purity. The fourth voice says, ‘You should know that the tranquillity of the fourth meditation stage surpasses the heaven of universal purity.’ Hearing this, the sentient beings are naturally able to achieve the fourth meditation stage, relinquish the body of the heaven of universal purity, and are born in the heaven of vast results. These voices have no master or maker—they are just produced by the power of good practices of sentient beings.
