“The voice of Buddha is also like this, without master or maker, without discrimination, not entering, not emerging, yet producing four great voices from the power of the virtuous qualities of Buddha. One voice says, ‘You all should know that all conditioned states are miserable. There is the misery of hells, the misery of animality, the misery of hungry ghosthood, the misery of lack of virtue, the misery of clinging to self and possessions, the misery of evildoing. If you want to be born human or divine, you should plant roots of goodness. Born in the human world or in a heaven, you will leave all situations in which enlightenment is difficult.’ Sentient beings, having heard this, give up error and perversity, practice good actions, leave all difficulties behind, and are born in the human world or in heaven. The second voice says, ‘You should know that the myriad pains of all conditioned states are as searing as balls of hot iron. Conditioned states are impermanent and pass away. Nirvana is tranquil, unfabricated well-being, beyond all burning, extinguishing all inflaming afflictions.’ Having heard this, sentient beings diligently practice good principles, and in the vehicle of listeners to Buddha’s voice attain the tolerance of conformity to the message. The third voice says, ‘You should know that those in the vehicle of listeners follow the words of another to understand; their knowledge and wisdom is narrow and inferior. There is a higher vehicle called the vehicle of the individually awakened, whose enlightenment does not depend on a teacher. You should learn it.’ Those inclined to a superior path, having heard this voice, give up the path of listeners and cultivate the vehicle of the individually awakened. The fourth voice says, ‘You should know that there is an even higher path beyond the ranks of these two vehicles, which is called the great vehicle, practiced by enlightening beings, following the six transcendent ways, not stopping enlightening practice, not relinquishing the determination for enlightenment, being in the midst of infinite birth and death without getting sick of it. Going beyond the two vehicles of individual liberation, it is called the Great Vehicle, the foremost vehicle, the preeminent vehicle, the supreme vehicle, the highest vehicle, the unexcelled vehicle, the vehicle of benefiting all sentient beings.’ If there are any sentient beings whose resolve is very great, whose faculties are strong and keen, who have planted roots of goodness in the past, who are spiritually empowered by the buddhas, who have superior inclinations and seek buddhahood, once they have heard this voice they arouse the determination for enlightenment. Buddha’s voice does not come from the body or from the mind, yet it can benefit infinite sentient beings. This is the first characteristic of Buddha’s voice; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

“Furthermore, just as an echo arises due to mountains, valley, and sound, and has no form, cannot be seen, and though it has no discrimination can follow all words, so also is the voice of Buddha—it has no form, cannot be seen, has no direction or location yet is not without direction and location; it just emerges according to the conditions of sentient beings’ inclinations and understandings. Its nature ultimately has no words, no information, and cannot be explained. This is the second characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ lha rnams kyi chos kyi rnga chen po chos la yang dag par skul ba zhes bya ba steng gi bar snang las yang dag par sgrog ste/ nam lha rnams bag med par spyod par gyur pa de'i tshe/ chos kyi rnga chen po de 'di skad du/ kye grogs po dag /'dod pa'i bde ba 'di dag ni shin tu mi rtag cing slu la myur du 'jig cing byis pa 'drid pa ste/ byis pas bsnyen pa'o/ /byis pas bsngags pa'o/ /de bas na bag yod par gyis la bag med par ma byed cig /ngan song dag tu lhur bar gyur ta re zhes bya ba'i sgra sgrog go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar sgra de thos nas bag med par spyod pa'i lha'i bu rnams kyang so so nas skyo bar gyur te/ rang rang gi gnas kyi 'dod pa'i dga' ba spangs nas/ lha'i rgyal po'i gnas su 'dong ngo/ /de dag der phyin nas kyang chos la dga' bas nyi ma stung zhing chos la spyod par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ltos dang / lha'i rnga de la byung ba'am/ 'jig pa gang yang med la/ lha rnams la'ang don chen po de lta bus shin tu phan 'dogs so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung yang sems can gyi khams ma lus pa rgyas par mdzad de/ sems can bag med par spyod pa rnams yang dag par bskul ba'i phyir chos chen po'i sgra sgrog cing 'byung ngo/ / 'di lta ste/ yongs su gzung ba med pa'i sgra 'byung ngo/ /bag yod pa'i sgra 'byung ngo/ /mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / bdag med pa'i sgra 'byung ngo/ /zhi ba mya ngan las 'das pa'i sgra 'byung ngo/ /'jig rten gyi khams ma lus par rgyas par bkang ste; sems can bag med par spyod pa rnams mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du rab tu dga' bar bya ba dang / theg pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'byung bar bya ba'i phyir yang dag par skul ba mdzad cing / rang 'byung gi ye shes tshad med pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa mi 'phrogs pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi ye shes kyis thams cad du khyab cing lhun gyis grub pa yang rab tu brjod do/ /sgra de thos nas kyang sems can tshad med grangs med pa dge ba'i chos la shin tu brtson par 'gyur te/ la la ni nyan thos kyi theg pa la/ la la ni rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa la/ la la ni bla na med pa'i theg pa chen po la mngon par 'jug kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsungs de ni gang la'ang zhugs pa med de/ gang gis kyang tshig tu mi brjod do/ /kye rgyal pa'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo gsum pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Furthermore, it is like the heavens’ great drum of law, called awakener: when the celestials act without restraint, the drum produces a voice in the sky saying, ‘You should know that all pleasures are impermanent, unreal, illusory, changing and disintegrating in a moment. They only fool the ignorant, causing attachment. Don’t be indulgent, for the unrestrained fall into bad ways, and it is of no use to regret afterward.’ The indulgent celestials, having heard this voice, are greatly distressed and frightened; they leave the pleasures in their own abodes, go to the king of gods, seek the truth and practice the way. The sound of that drum has no master, no maker, no origin, no destruction, yet it can benefit infinite sentient beings. Know that Buddha likewise utters the voice of infinite sublime truths in order to awaken indulgent beings: the voice of non-attachment, the voice of nonindulgence, the voice of impermanence, the voice of suffering, the voice of selflessness, the voice of impurity, the voice of annulment, the voice of nirvana, the voice of measureless spontaneous knowledge, the voice of incorruptible enlightening practices, the voice of all-pervasive effortless knowledge of buddhas. These voices pervade the cosmos, awakening the beings therein; countless sentient beings, having heard them, all become joyful and diligently cultivate good ways, each seeking emancipation by their respective vehicles of emancipation—that is, some practice the vehicle of listeners, some practice the vehicle of individual awakening, and some practice the unsurpassed Great Vehicle of enlightening beings. Yet the voice of Buddha does not remain in any place; it has no speech. This is the third characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ lha'i rgyal po dbang sgyur gyi lha'i bu mo bzang mo zhes bya ba'i kha'i dbugs gcig gis lha rdzas kyi rol mo'i sgra yan lag brgya stong dang ldan pa'i nga ro 'byung ste/ sgra de byung ba na/ sgra rnam pa tha dad pa brgya phrag stong gi dbyangs su grag go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ltos dang / de ltar kha'i dbugs gcig pu las kyang / sgra'i dbyangs tshad med pa 'byung bar rung ngo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung gcig 'byung yang tshad med par khyab pa ste/ sems can gyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du sems kyi rgyud las mos pa'i tshul dang 'dra bar tshad med pa'i sgra'i rnam par de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung grag go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo bzhi pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Again, it is like the case of the celestial concubine of the great lord god, named Beautiful Mouth, whose voice corresponds to a hundred thousand kinds of music, within each of which are also a hundred thousand different tones. Just as that goddess Beautiful Mouth produces countless sounds in one utterance, in the same way Buddha produces innumerable voices in one utterance, according to the differences in mentalities of sentient beings, reaching them all and enabling them to gain understanding. This is the fourth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

“Also it is like the case of the great god Brahma, abiding in the Brahma palace, uttering the voice of Brahma, which all the Brahma masses hear, while the sound of the voice does not go outside that group; the Brahma divinities all think Brahma is speaking to them alone. The sublime voice of Buddha is also like this; all in the congregation at the site of enlightenment hear it, while the sound does not go outside that group. Why? Because those whose faculties are not yet mature cannot hear it. Those who hear the voice each think Buddha is talking to them alone. The voice of Buddha neither emerges nor remains, yet can accomplish all works. This is the fifth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nam mkha'i dbyings las char gyi ro gcig pa bab kyang snod kyi rnam pa tha dad pas chu rnam pa tha dad par snang gi chu la rnam par rtog pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung yang 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par grol bar ro gcig kyang / sems can gyi bsam pa'i snod rnam pa tha dad pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung rnam pa tha dad du snang ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung la rnam par rtog pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo drug pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Also, just as waters are all of one flavor, but according to the difference of the vessel water has distinctions, yet the water has no thought or discrimination, similarly the speech of Buddha is of one flavor only, the flavor of liberation, but has innumerable distinctions according to the differences in mental vessels of sentient beings, yet without thought or discrimination. This is the sixth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

“Also, it is like the case of the water spirit Heatless producing great dense clouds covering the continent, showering sweet rain all over, so all the crops can grow and all the rivers, streams, springs, and lakes are full; this great rainwater does not come from the water spirit’s body or mind, yet can benefit sentient beings in various ways. Similarly, Buddha produces the cloud of great compassion covering all worlds in the ten directions, showering the rain of immortal truth, causing all sentient beings to become joyful, increase in goodness, and fulfill all vehicles of liberation. The voice of Buddha does not come from without and does not emerge from within, yet can benefit all sentient beings. This is the seventh characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ klu'i rgyal po yid du 'ong ba ni/ nam char chen po dbab par 'dod pa de'i tshe/ nam mkha' thams cad sprin gyi dra bas yog par byed de/ zhag bdun du sprin chen po kun nas sdud do/ /sems can gyi las kyi mtha' rnams yongs su ma zin gyi bar du char gyi rgyun kyang kun tu gtong bar mi byed do/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ klu'i rgyal po chen po yid du 'ong ba ni/ mi 'tshe ba'i ngang tshul dang ldan pa ste/ zhag bdun 'das nas char gyi rgyun shin tu phra bas sa thams cad yongs su ngoms par byed do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas chos kyi rgyal po chen po yang thugs rje chen po'i sprin bsdus te/ nam chos kyi char chen po dbab par dgyes pa de'i tshe/ shes rab dang thabs mkhas pas sems can yongs su smin par mdzad do/ /sems can rnams kyi dbang po yongs su ma smin gyi bar du ni/ bdud rtsi'i char sngar 'bebs par mi mdzad de/ nam sems can rnams yongs su smin par gyur pa de'i tshe gzod chos kyi char chen po bdud rtsi'i ro dang ldan pa 'bebs so/ /phra zhing zab la mkhas pas shes par bya ba'i chos brjod cing / sems can rnams 'jigs par ma gyur par rim gyis thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi chos kyi ro bla na med pas yongs su ngoms par mdzad do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo brgyad pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Also it is like when the water spirit Thoughtful is going to shower rain, it does not do so immediately but first produces great clouds covering the sky, remaining still for seven days waiting for people to finish their work, because that water spirit is benevolent and compassionate and does not want to trouble them; after seven days it showers a fine rain, moistening the earth. Similarly, when Buddha is going to shower the rain of truth, he does not do so at once, but first produces great clouds of teaching in order to mature sentient beings so they will not be startled or frightened; after they are mature he showers on all the rain of immortal truth, expounding the most profound, subtle good teaching, gradually filling them with the flavor of the unexcelled teaching of omniscience of buddhas. This is the eighth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras / 'di lta ste/ dper na /rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na lag gis 'gro ba'i bdag po rgyan chen po zhes bya ba yod de/ de 'dod na rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du rgyan gcig dang ldan pa'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /de 'dod na rgyan bcu dang ldan pa'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /de 'dod na rgyan brgya dang ldan pa'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /de 'dod na rgyan stong dang ldan pa'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /de 'dod na rgyan brgya phrag stong dang ldan pa'i char rab tu 'bebs kyang / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ char pa de dag la rnam par rtog pa gang yang med de/ 'on kyang klu'i rgyal po de'i khyu mchog gi mthu phyung ba bsam gyis mi khyab pa rnam par phye ba'i byin gyis rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan brgya phrag stong dang ldan pa'i char 'bab pa yod cing snang ngo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras /de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyang / nam chos kyi char chen po dbab par dgyes pa de'i tshe/ bzhed na chos gcig rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan gyis kyang chos ston to/ /bzhed na chos bcu rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan dang / bzhed na chos nyi shu rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan dang / bzhed na chos brgya rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan dang / bzhed na chos stong rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan dang / bzhed na chos brgya phrag stong rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan dang / bzhed na sems can gyi spyod pa stong phrag brgyad cu rtsa bzhi la gsung rnam pa tha dad pa stong phrag brgyad cu rtsa bzhi rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan gyi chos ston pa nas/ gsung gi rnam pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong tshad med pa'i bar du rnam par dgod pa'i rgyan gyis chos ston to/ /sems can tshad med pa yongs su tshim par mdzad kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i gsung la rnam par rtog pa gang yang mi mnga'o/ /'on kyang so sor ci rigs su sems can rnams kyi dbang po yongs su tshim par bya ba'i phyir 'di lta ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi dbyings kyi dkyil 'khor shin tu dag pa'i phyir; de ltar gsung gi rnam pa tshad med par 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo dgu pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung khong du chud par bya'o; ;

“In the ocean is a great water spirit called Magnificent Array; when it showers rain on the ocean, it may shower rain in ten kinds of arrays, or a hundred, or a thousand, or rain in a hundred thousand kinds of arrays. The water has no discrimination; it is just the inconceivable power of the water spirit that causes its arrays to be infinitely different. Similarly, when Buddha teaches truth, it may be expressed in ten different tones, or a hundred, or a thousand, or a hundred thousand, or eighty-four thousand tones explaining eighty-four thousand practices, up to countless hundreds of thousands of millions of tones, each explaining the truth in particular ways to gladden all who hear. The voice of Buddha makes no discrimination; it is just that buddhas, complete and pure in the profound realm of truth, are able to make various utterances in accord with the needs of sentient beings, making them happy. This is the ninth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ klu'i rgyal po gangs chen mtsho ni/ nam klu'i rgyal po chen po'i rnam par rtse bas rnam par rtse bar 'dod cing sems can rnams kyang bde ba dang yongs su tshim par bya bar 'dod par gyur pa de'i tshe/ gling chen po bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi sa'i steng nye bar bzung ba yan chad lha'i dbang po dbang sgyur gyi gnas kyi bar du sprin gyi dra ba kha dog sna tshogs can kha dog du ma dang ldan pas yongs su khebs par byed do/ /sprin gyi dra ba'i rgyan de dag la yang kha dog rnam pa tha dad pa'i gzugs rnam par phye ba 'di lta bu dag snang zhing yod de/ 'di ltar la la ni dzam+bu chu klung gi gser gyi kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni bai DUr+ya bzang po'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni dngul gyi kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni shel gyi kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni mu sa ra gal ba'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni asma gar ba'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni dpal snying po'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni mu tig dmar po'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni spos sna tshogs kyi kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni gos dkar po dri ma med pa'i kha dog tu snang ngo/ /la la ni kha dog gcig tu snang ngo/ /la la ni kha dog rnam pa tha dad pa sna tshogs su snang ngo/ /rnam pa de lta bu'i sprin gyi dra bas gling bzhi pa kun nas khebs par byas nas/ rnam pa sna tshogs kyi glog 'gyed do/ / 'di ltar sprin gser gyi kha dog tu 'dug pa las glog gi phreng ba bai DUr+ya'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ sprin bai DUr+ya bzang po'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba gser gyi kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin dngul gyi kha dog tu 'dug pa las glog gi phreng ba mu sa ra gal ba'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin mu sa ra gal ba'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba dngul gyi kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin asma gar ba'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las; glog gi phreng ba mu tig dmar po'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin mu tig dmar po'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba asma gar ba'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin asma gar ba'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba dpal gyi snying po'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin dpal gyi snying po'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba spos rnam pa tha dad pa'i kha dog lta bu 'gyed do/ /sprin spos rnam pa tha dad pa'i kha dog lta bur 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba shel gyi kha dog lta bur 'gyed do/ /sprin shel gyi kha dog lta bur 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba rin po che sna tshogs cho ma cho dgu'i kha dog lta bur 'gyed do/ /sprin rnam pa sna tshogs rnam pa tha dad pa'i kha dog tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba kha dog gcig tu snang bar 'gyed do/ /sprin kha dog gcig tu 'dug pa las/ glog gi phreng ba sna tshogs rnam pa tha dad pa'i kha dog dang ldan pa 'gyed do/ /rnam pa ji lta bur mos pa'i tshul bzhin du sems can dga' bar bya ba'i phyir 'brug gi sgra dbyangs rnam pa du ma'i nga ro 'byin te/ la lar ni lha'i rnga'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni lha'i bu mo'i glu dang rol mo'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni rol mo brdung ba dang dkrol ba'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni klu'i bu mo'i glu'i sgra dbyangs sna tshogs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni dri za'i bu mo'i glu'i sgra dbyangs dang nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni mi'am ci'i bu mo'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni sa grum pa'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni rgya mtsho'i 'brug gi sgra zab mo'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni seng ge'i rgyal po'i sgra'i gdangs kyi sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni bya btsun pa'i skad kyi sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /la lar ni rnam pa sna tshogs tha dad pa'i glu'i sgra dbyangs kyi nga ro 'byin to/ /de lta bu'i sprin gyi dra ba chen po bsdus te/ glog gi phreng ba bkye nas 'brug gi sgra dbyangs dang nga ro rnam pa de lta bu dag kyang phyung ste/ dga' ba dang spro ba chen po bskyed pa zhes bya ba'i klu'i rlung chen po 'gyed do/ /rlung chen po de dag langs pas kyang sems can rnams kyi lus sil bar gyur te/ dga' ba dang spro ba yang rab tu skye'o/ /de nas sems can rnams kyi bsod nams dang mos pa'i khyad par gyi tshul ji lta ba bzhin du las kyis rnam pa sna tshogs tha dad du gyur pa'i char chen po 'bebs te/ lha'i rgyal po dbang sgyur gyi gnas nye bar gzung ba man chad sa'i steng na yod pa'i gnas kyi bar du char pa rnam pa tha dad pa 'bebs te/ 'di ltar rgya mtsho chen por ni tha mi dad pa zhes bya ba'i char sprin chen po'i char 'bebs so/ /dbang sgyur gyi lha rnams la ni shin tu snyan cing mnyan par 'os pa zhes bya ba'i sgra snyan pa'i glu dang / rol mo'i char chen po 'bebs so/ /'phrul dga'i lha rnams ni snang bar rab tu gtong ba zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po ba lha rdzas kyi gos kyi char chen po 'bebs so/ /klu'i rgyal po chen po'i gnas su ni 'od shin tu 'phags pa zhes bya ba mu tig dmar po'i char chen po 'bebs so/ /lha ma yin gyi gnas su ni pha rol shin tu 'joms pa zhes bya ba gzhu dang mtshon cha'i char chen po 'bebs so/ /byang gi sgra mi snyan du ni me tog shin tu rgyas pa zhes bya ba me tog sna tshogs kyi char chen po 'bebs so/ /gzhung de bzhin du gling chen po bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gnas sna tshogs su rnam pa tha dad pa'i char sna tshogs rab tu 'bebs so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ klu'i rgyal po gangs chen mtsho la ser sna rol pas rnam par rol pa'i tshe/ chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad chos kyi sku'i sprin gyis rgyas par bkang zhing sems can ji ltar mos pa'i tshul bzhin du/ sku'i sprin yang dag par ston te/ 'di ltar sems can la la la ni skye ba 'byung ba'i sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni sprul pa'i sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni byin gyi rlabs kyi sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni gzugs kyi sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni sku sna tshogs mngon par bsgrub pa'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni bsod nams kyi sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni ye shes kyi sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni stobs la thub pa med pa'i sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni mi bsnyengs pa zil gyis mi non pa'i sku'i sprin yongs su ston to/ /sems can la la la ni chos kyi dbyings lus pa med pa'i sku'i sprin yongs su ston te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras; de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ni 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad chos kyi sku'i sprin gyis bkang zhing / sems can rnams kyis sems dang / bsam pa dang / mos pa ji lta ba'i tshul bzhin du de dag la 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba 'gyed do/ 'di ltar sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba kun tu khyab pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba sangs rgyas kyi gsang ba la 'jug pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba spobs pa snang ba zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba snang bar byed pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba gzungs kyi sgo mi zad pa la 'jug pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba dran pa 'khrug pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba blo gros mi 'phrogs pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba rigs pa'i rjes su 'jug pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ /sems can la la la ni 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba bsam pa thams cad shin tu tshim par byed pa zhes bya ba 'gyed do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi rnam pa de lta bu'i 'od zer gyi dra ba'i glog tshad med pa de dag rab tu bkye nas/ ting nge 'dzin chen po 'brug gi sgra dbyangs rnam pa 'di lta bu dag rab tu sgrog ste/ 'di ltar sems can la la la ni blo shin tu rnam par sangs rgyas pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni shin tu sbyangs pas dri ma med pa'i phyag rgya zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni chos thams cad la dbang bsgyur ba zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni rdo rje'i dkyil 'khor zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go / sems can la la la ni ri rab rgyal mtshan zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni gangs can rgya mtsho zhes bya ba la ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni nyi ma sgron ma zhes bya 'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni 'gro ba thams cad yongs su tshim par byed pa zhes bya'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni mdzod mi zad pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug gi sgra dbyangs sgrog go /sems can la la la ni mi 'khrugs pa'i mos pa yongs su 'dzin pa zhes bya ba'i ting nge 'dzin gyi sgra dbyangs sgrog ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku'i sprin las/ de dag la sogs pa ting nge 'dzin rnam pa tha dad pa'i sgo'i 'brug chen po'i sgra dbyangs chos mnyan pa'i sngon gyi ltas 'gro ba thams cad shin tu tshim par byed pa rab tu sgrog go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku'i sprin rnam pa de lta bu byung ba dang / 'od zer gyi glog gi phreng ba bkye ste; ting nge 'dzin gyi 'brug sgras 'gro ba thams cad tshim par byed pa shin tu bsgrags pa'i tshe/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku'i sprin sngon byams pa chen po dang / thugs rje chen po sgribs pa med pas mngon par bsgrubs pa las ye shes chen po'i dkyil 'khor gyi rlung 'byung ba yod de/ de ni thog mar sems can thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi sems dang lus tshim par byed do/ /de'i 'og tu chos kyi sprin gyi char chen po 'bebs so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ chos kyi sku'i sprin chen po bsam gyis mi khyab pa thugs rje chen po las byung ba bsdus shing / sems can lus dang sems sim par gyur pa rnams la de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi char chen po bsam gyis mi khyab pa 'bebs te/ 'di ltar byang chub sems dpa' snying po byang chub kyi mchog tu phyin pa rnams la chos kyi dbyings tha mi dad pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' srid pa tha ma pa rnams la de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba byang chub sems dpa'i thabs kyis rnam par rol pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' dbang bskur ba thob pa rnams la de bzhin gshegs pa'i rgyan gyis rnam par klubs pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' tshe gcig gis thogs pa rnams la kun nas snang ba yongs su sbyong pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' bzod pa thob pa rnams la yon tan rin po che ye shes kyi me tog shin tu rgyas pas/ byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rgyun mi 'chad pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' spyod pa la zhugs pa rnams la sprul pas mngon par 'jug pa'i spyod pa rgyun mi 'chad cing / yongs su skyo ba med pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /byang chub sems dpa' sems dang po bskyed pa rnams la de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyod pa'i rjes su bsnyegs shing byams pa chen po dang / snying rje chen pos 'gro ba thams cad yongs su skyob pa zhes bya ba'i sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /sems can rang sangs rgyas kyi theg pa la mos pa rnams la rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba'i tshul khong du chud pas mtha' gnyis kyi lta ba dang bral zhing / rnam par grol ba'i 'bras bu chud mi za ba zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /sems can nyan thos kyi theg pa la mos par mos la nyon mongs pa'i dgra thams cad 'joms pa zhes bya ba'i shes rab kyi ral gri'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char rab tu 'bebs so/ /sems can dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu bsags shing theg pa la nges par gyur pa rnams la dga' ba dang / spro ba rab tu bskyed pa zhes bya ba'i chos kyi sgo sna tshogs mngon par bsgrubs pa'i char rab tu 'bebs te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa ni chos kyi sgo bcu po 'di dag la sogs pa tshad med pa'i chos kyi sprin chen po'i char sems can ma lus pa thams cad kyi mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du chos kyi dbyings thams cad rgyas par bkang ste/ rab tu 'bebs pa mdzad do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams la chos kyi ser sna gang yang mi mnga' yang / sems can rnam pa ji lta bu smin pa'i tshul dang; bsam pa dang / dbang po dang / mos pa dang / brtson 'grus rnam pa tha dad pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi char chen po rnam pa tha dad par snang bar gyur to/ /kye rgyal ba'i bas/ khong du chud pa bya ba'i sgo bcu pa'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi gsung brjod pa khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“When the water spirit Ocean wants to manifest the controlling power of the water spirit for the benefit of sentient beings to make them happy, it raises a great network of clouds from the earth to the heaven of control of others’ emanations, covering all over: those clouds are of infinite different colors—some are the color of golden light, some are the color of lapis lazuli light, some are the color of silver light, some are the color of crystal light, some are the color of emerald light, some are the color of agate light, some are the color of red pearl light, some are the color of light of infinite fragrances, some are the color of light of spotless cloth, some are the color of light of pure water, some are the color of light of various ornaments. This network of clouds, having spread all over, emits lightning of various colors: the golden clouds emit lapis lazuli lightning; the lapis lazuli clouds emit golden lightning; the silver clouds emit crystal lightning; the crystal clouds emit silver lightning; the emerald clouds emit agate lightning; the agate clouds emit emerald lightning; the infinite-fragrance-colored clouds emit spotless-cloth-colored lightning; the spotless-cloth-colored clouds emit infinite-fragrance-colored lightning; the pure-water-colored clouds emit various-ornament-colored lightning; the various-ornament-colored clouds emit pure-water-colored lightning; multicolored clouds emit one-colored lightning; one-colored clouds emit multicolored lightning. There also issue from the clouds various sounds of thunder, according to the minds of sentient beings, making them all happy—sounds like goddesses singing, like celestial musicians playing, like water nymphs singing, like gandharva girls singing, like kinnara girls singing, like earthquakes, like the waves and tide of the ocean, like the king of beasts howling, like beautiful birds calling, as well as innumerable other kinds of sounds. When the thunder has sounded, there arises a cool breeze, delighting the mind of sentient beings. Finally it rains, various kinds of rain, benefiting and comforting infinite beings. In all places from the heavens to earth the rain is different: on the ocean it rains clear, cool water called endless; in the heaven of control of others’ emanations it rains various music such as pipes and flutes, named beautiful; in the heaven of enjoyment of emanation it rains jewels called radiating great light; in the heaven of happiness it rains great ornaments, called hanging crests; in the heaven of timely portion it rains large, beautiful flowers, called various adornments; in the thirty-three-fold heaven it rains many sublime fragrances, called pleasing; in the heaven of the four world guardians it rains precious celestial robes, called covering; in the palace of water spirits it rains red pearls, called flowing light; in the palace of the titans it rains weapons, called conquering enemies; in the northern region of earth it rains various flowers, called blooming; in the other regions of earth it also rains differently according to the place. Though the mind of the water spirit is impartial, without discrimination, simply because the roots of goodness of sentient beings are different, the rain has distinctions. Similarly, when Buddha, the truly enlightened, the supreme spiritual sovereign, wants to edify sentient beings with right teaching, first he spreads clouds of embodiments over the cosmos, appearing differently according to inclinations of beings. For some beings he manifests clouds of mortal bodies; for some, clouds of emanated bodies; for some, clouds of power-bodies; for some, clouds of form-bodies; for some, clouds of glorified bodies; for some, clouds of virtue-bodies; for some, clouds of knowledge-bodies; for some, clouds of bodies whose powers do not deteriorate; for some, clouds of bodies of fearlessness; for some, clouds of cosmic bodies. Buddha covers all worlds with infinite such body-clouds and manifests various kinds of lightning in accord with the individual differences in inclinations of sentient beings: for some beings he manifests lightning called reaching everywhere; for some, lightning called boundless light; for some, lightning called penetrating the secret teaching of Buddha; for some, lightning called reflected light; for some, lightning called illumination; for some, lightning called entering the door of endless mental command; for some, lightning called right mindfulness undisturbed; for some, lightning called ultimately incorruptible; for some, lightning called adaptively entering all states of being; for some, lightning called fulfilling all wishes and making everyone happy. Having manifested lightnings of infinite such lights, Buddha then produces infinite thunders of concentration, according to the inclinations of sentient beings: the thunder of the concentration of well-aware knowledge; the thunder of the concentration of the refulgent, undefiled ocean; the thunder of the concentration of mastery of all the teachings; the thunder of the adamantine wheel concentration; the thunder of the concentration symbolized by the polar mountain; the thunder of the ocean-seal concentration; the thunder of the solar lamp concentration; the thunder of the inexhaustible treasury concentration; the thunder of the concentration of the indestructible power of liberation. After the thunder of infinite different concentrations such as these have emerged from the clouds of embodiments of Buddha, when about to shower the rain of truth, first he manifests an auspicious sign to awaken sentient beings: from the mind of unhindered compassion he manifests the atmosphere of great knowledge of Buddha, called able to cause all sentient beings to develop inconceivable happiness and well-being. Once this sign has appeared, the bodies and minds of all enlightening beings and sentient beings become clear and cool. After that, from the cloud of the great reality-body of Buddha, the cloud of great compassion, the cloud of great inconceivability, showers the inconceivable, far-flung rain of teaching, causing all beings’ bodies and minds to be pure: for enlightening beings sitting at the site of enlightenment there showers a great rain of teaching called nondifferentiation of the realm of reality; for enlightening beings in their final embodiment there showers a great rain of teaching called enlightening beings’ easy mastery of the esoteric teaching of Buddha; for enlightening beings to become fully enlightened in the next life there showers a great rain of teaching called pure universal light; for coronated enlightening beings there showers a great rain of teaching called adornment by the embellishments of buddhahood; for enlightening beings who have attained tolerance there showers a great rain of teaching called flowers of knowledge with jewels of virtue blooming, not ceasing the compassionate practices of enlightening beings; for enlightening beings in progress there showers a great rain of teaching called entering the profound method of manifestation of occult transformations and carrying on enlightening practice without stopping or wearying; for newly inspired enlightening beings there showers a great rain of teaching called producing the practice of great love and compassion of buddhas to save sentient beings; for those who seek the vehicle of individual enlightenment there showers a great rain of teaching called deeply knowing the principles of conditional origination, avoiding extremes, and attaining the nondecaying fruit of liberation; for those who seek the vehicle of listeners there showers a great rain of teaching called cutting down all obstructing afflictions with the sword of great knowledge and wisdom; for stabilized and unstabilized sentient beings who accumulate roots of goodness there showers a great rain of teaching called facilitating the accomplishment of various ways into the teaching, producing great happiness. The Buddha showers great rains of teaching like these in accordance with the mentalities of sentient beings, filling all worlds. A buddha, perfectly enlightened, is impartial in mind and does not begrudge the teaching; simply because the faculties and inclinations of sentient beings are not the same, the rains of teaching appear differently. This is the tenth characteristic of the voice of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsung de ni tshad med pa shin tu bstan pa bcus khong du chud par bya ste/ bcu gang zhe na/ 'di ltar thams cad rjes su song ba'i phyir/ nam mkha'i dbyings ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /ma lus pa'i mthar thug pas chos kyi dbyings ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /sems can thams cad kyi sems rab tu sim par byed pas/ sems can gyi khams ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o; ;rnam par ston pas las ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /shin tu zhi bar byed pas nyon mongs pa ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /sems can rnams kyi mos pa ji lta ba bzhin du khong du chud par byed pas sgra dbyangs rnam pa tha dad pa ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /rnam par grol ba shin tu rtogs pas mos pa tshad med pa ltar khong du chud par bya'o/ /mtha' dang dbus med cing sa mtshams med pas/ dus gsum ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /chos thams cad rnam par 'byed pas ye shes ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya'o/ /de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi dbyings kyi rjes su song bas sangs rgyas kyi yul phyir mi ldog pa ltar tshad med par khong du chud par bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa mngon par bsgrubs pa tha dad pa shin tu bstan pa brgya stong mang pos/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi gsung brjod pa khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“The voice of Buddha has ten kinds of infinity: it is as infinite as the realm of space because it extends to all places; it is as infinite as the cosmos because it pervades everywhere; it is as infinite as the realm of sentient beings because it gladdens all hearts; it is as infinite as all acts because it explains their results and consequences; it is as infinite as afflictions because it removes them all; it is as infinite as the speech of sentient beings because it enables them to hear according to their understanding; it is as infinite as the inclinations and understandings of sentient beings because it observes them all to rescue and liberate them; it is as infinite as past, present, and future because it has no boundaries; it is as infinite as knowledge because it distinguishes everything; it is as infinite as the realm of buddhahood because it enters the cosmos of reality of buddhahood. The voice of Buddha, the completely enlightened, comprises incalculable infinities such as these; great enlightening beings should know it thus.”
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos/ don 'di nyid yang brtag pa'i phyir tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Universally Good, to again clarify what he meant, spoke these verses:

'jig rten 'jig par 'gyur tshe gzhal med sgra dbyangs bzhi/ / sems can dge ba'i 'bras bus bar snang mkha' las 'byung / / bsam gtan bzhi ni zhi ba sdug bsngal med pa yod/ / de skad sgra thos 'dod pa'i khams rnams rnam par spong / /
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' gsung dam pa tshad med pa/ / sems can don du chos dbyings rnam par bkang zhing 'byung / / des ni srid pa'i mtsho las 'da' zhing brgal bar 'gyur/ / bde gshegs gsung de skul med de thugs la min/ /
ri dang brag dang lung sul gnas pa'i sgra brnyan ni/ / mi yi sgra bzhin sgra brnyan thams cad rab tu brjod/ / gzhan gyi sgra phyung rnam par dmigs pas sgra de 'byung / / de la sgra rtog rnam pa kun tu yod pa min/ /
stobs bcu mnga' ba'i gsung dbyangs chos nyid rnam mi rtog / gzhan gyi spyod dang dbang po yongs su smin pa 'byung / / sems can mang po 'dul zhing bsam pa dga' bar mdzad/ / stobs bcu mnga' ba rnams la rlom sems bskyod mi mnga'/ /
ji ltar rnga chen chos la bskul ba'i sgra ldan pa/ / gang tshe lha rnams 'dod la zhen cing bag med pa/ / de tshe mkha' yi dbyings las chos kyi sgras ston te/ / sgra de thos shing lha rnams bag yod spyod par 'gyur/ /
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba'i chos sgra ldan pa'i rda/ / phyogs bcu kun tu sems can yang dag rab tu skul/ / rgyal ba'i gsung ni skye med 'gag pa mi dmigs so/ / de yi sgra thos sems can byang chub thob par 'gyur/ /
lha yi dbang po dbang sgyur lha rdzas rtse ba'i tshe/ / lha mo'i kha dbugs gcig kyang yan lag mang ldan pas/ / kha dbugs sgra dbyangs gcig las sna tshogs sgra mang 'byung / / sgra dbyangs brgya stong mang po 'byung yang de la rnam rtog med/ /
de bzhin stobs bcu mnga' ba'i gsung gcig bsgrags pa las/ / sems can rnyed kyi gsung gi yan lag dus gcig 'byung / / sems can ji bzhin ji ltar mos par gsung nyan cing / / thos nas nyon mongs spong byed sgra la rtog pa med/ /
ji ltar tshangs pa tshangs pa'i stan la ma g.yos par/ / sgra dbyangs gcig brjod tshangs pa bsam yas dga' bar byed/ / 'on kyang tshangs pa'i dbyangs de 'khor gyi phyir mi 'byung / / 'khor rnams ji snyed thams cad khong du chud par byed/ /
stobs bcu legs mnga' tshangs pa sangs rgyas gdan bzhugs shing / / gsung gcig chos dbyings ma lus bkang ste rab tu sgrog ; 'khor las mi 'da' sangs rgyas ser sna mnga' ba min/ / sems can dad dang bral bas rgyal ba'i gsung mi thos/ /

When a billion-world universe is about to dissolve, The power of beings’ virtue announces that The four meditations are peaceful and painless, Causing them to leave desire when they have heard.
Ten-Powered Buddha, also like this, Produces a sublime voice pervading the cosmos, Explaining that conditioned states are painful and impermanent, So beings may cross for good the sea of birth and death.
Just as a canyon deep in the mountains Echoes any sound, And though it accords with others’ voices The echo has no discrimination,
So also is the speech of Buddha Revealed according to the maturity of faculties, Causing them to be controlled and happy, Yet without self-consciousness of preaching.
As the celestial drum called awakener Vibrates with the sound of the law in the sky, Admonishing the self-indulgent celestials, Causing them to give up attachments when they hear,
So too is the drum of Buddha’s teaching like this, Producing various wonderful sounds, Awakening all living beings So they all realize enlightenment.
The lord god has a precious concubine Who voices all kinds of music Producing a hundred thousand sounds in one voice With a hundred thousand tones in each sound.
The voice of Buddha is also like this, Producing all tones in one voice, Different according to beings’ characters and inclinations, Causing each to end afflictions when they hear.
Just as king Brahma utters a sound Which makes all Brahmas happy, The voice reaching only Brahmas, no one else, Each thinking he alone hears it,
So also does the Buddha utter a word Which fills the cosmos, Yet only reaches the faithful Because the faithless cannot receive it.

ji ltar chu rgyun thams cad rang bzhin gcig pa ste/ / ro mthun mi rtog dag cing yan lag brgyad dang ldan/ / sa steng snod kyi khyad par gzhan dang gzhan gyur pas/ / rkyen dang phrad gyur chu yi rnam pa tha dad 'gyur/ /
de bzhin rgyal sras thams cad mkhyen gsung thams cad kyang / / ro mthun mi rtog sangs rgyas byang chub rang bzhin yin/ / sems can spyod pa'i khyad kyis rnam pa tha dad 'gyur/ / sems can bde gshegs gsung la gzhan dang gzhan du nyan/ /
ma dros klu ni 'dzam bu'i gling chen kun bkang zhing / / sa gzhi ngoms par bya phyir char pa'i rgyun kyang gtong / / lo tog nags tshal chu klung rim gyis skye bar byed/ / 'on kyang chu rgyun lus las ma byung sems las min/ /
bcom ldan 'das kyang de bzhin chos kyi dbyings bkang zhing / / sems can ngoms par bya phyir chos kyi char chen 'bebs/ / dge ba brgya 'phel sems can nyon mongs zhi bar mdzad/ / rgyal ba'i gsung ni phyi nang gang yang yod pa min/ /
lag gis 'gro ba'i bdag po yid du 'ong ba ni/ / nyin zhag bdun du mkha' dbyings 'di la sprin sdud de/ / dgos pa ma grub bar du char gyi rgyun mi 'bebs/ / phan pa'i don du char rgyun phra mo phyis 'bebs so/ /
stobs bcu 'gro pa'i don du chos dbyings rgyas mdzad cing / / sems can yongs su smin phyir don dam mi gsung ste/ / nam zhig snod du gyur tshe zab mo'i chos kyang gsung / / thos nas mi dngang sangs rgyas ye shes 'jug par 'gyur/ /
ji ltar rgya mtsho'i klu yi rgyal po rgyan chen ni/ / sprin gyi rgyan bcu bsdus shing char chen rab tu 'bebs/ / 'on tam sprin rgyan brgya bsdus brgya stong rgyan bsdus shing / / ro gcig char las rnam pa sna tshogs mang po 'bebs/ /
sangs rgyas tha dad yang dag mkhyen gyi mthar phyin pa'i/ / rang byung sgo bcu 'on tam nyi shu brgya gsung ste/ / gal te yang na brgya stong tshad med mang po gsung / / 'on kyang chos dbyings rnam par 'byed par mdzad pa med/ /
lag 'gro kun gyi gtso bo klu dbang gangs chen mtsho/ / gling bzhi 'di dag sprin gyi dra bas kun tu dgengs/ / gnas rnams kun tu char pa rnam pa sna tshogs 'bebs/ / gangs chen mtsho bdag de la gnyis su bya ba med/ /
sangs rgyas 'gro kun gtso bo chos rgyal dam pa yang / / thugs rje chen po'i stobs kyi sku sprin rgyas brdal cing / / byang chub lam du zhugs la chos rab char 'bebs te/ / mi rtog 'jig rten kun la gzhan dang gzhan yang gsung // //

Just as all waters are of one and the same essence, With no difference in flavor, But the land they are on and the vessels they are in are not the same, So that causes them to be variously different,
The voice of Omniscience is similar to this; The essence of truth has one flavor, undifferentiated, Yet according to beings’ actions, which are not the same, It causes them to hear in various different ways.
When the water spirit Heatless Showers rain to moisten the land Causing plants and trees to grow, The rain does not come from its body or mind.
Likewise the wondrous voice of buddhas Rains throughout the cosmos, filling all, Fostering good and extinguishing evil, But not coming from inside or outside.
Just as the water spirit Thoughtful Raises clouds for seven days before raining, Waiting for all people to finish their work And then showering rain for their benefit,
The teaching of Buddha is likewise, First civilizing beings and developing them, And afterward expounding the profound truth, So the hearers will not be frightened.
The water spirit Great Adornment in the ocean Showers ten arrays of rain, Or a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand; Though the water is one flavor, the arrays are different.
The ultimate teacher likewise Explains ten or twenty teachings, Or a hundred, a thousand, up to infinity, Without any notion of difference.
The supreme water spirit Ocean Covers the earth with clouds; The rain in each place is different, But the spirit has no thought of distinction.
Likewise Buddha, sovereign of truth, Extends clouds of great compassion in all directions, Raining differently for each practitioner, Yet without discriminating among them.
bam po bdun cu gsum pa/

de skad ces smras pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su byung ba'i dpal gyis/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos ji lta bur de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya/ de skad ces smras pa dang /
“How should great enlightening beings know the mind of Buddha, the truly awake?

byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po kun tu bzang pos/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs su byung ba'i dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /kye rgyal pa'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams ni sems kyis rnam par dgod pa ma yin/ yid kyis rnam par dgod pa ma yin/ rnam par shes pas rnam par dgod pa ma yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i thugs skye ba ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes tshad med pas khong du chud par bya'o/ /kye rgyal pa'i sras/ 'di lta ste/ dper na/ nam mkha' la brten cing bya ba thams cad rnam par dgod par 'gyur te/ nam mkha' ni mi gnas pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la brten cing / 'jig rten pa dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i shes pa thams cad rnam par dgod pa yin te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes ni mi gnas pa'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo dang po 'dis/ byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

The mind, intellect, and consciousness of Buddha are ungraspable. One can know the mind of Buddha only in terms of the infinity of knowledge. Just as space is the resting place of all things, while space has no resting place, so also is the knowledge of Buddha the resting place of all mundane and transcendental knowledge, while the knowledge of Buddha has no resting place. This is the first characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ chos kyi dbyings su ni nyan thos thams cad kyang rnam par grol bar 'gyur ro/ /rang sangs rgyas thams cad kyang rnam par grol te/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyang yang dag par 'byung mod kyi/ chos kyi dbyings la 'phel zhing 'grib pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la brten cing 'jig rten dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i shes pa 'grangs pa thams cad kyang rnam par dgod cing / las dang bzo'i gnas thams cad rnam par dgod kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la 'phel zhing 'grib pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo gnyis pa 'dis kyang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Just as the realm of truth always produces the liberations of Buddhist followers, individual illuminates, and enlightening beings, while the realm of truth has no increase or decrease, in the same way the knowledge of Buddha always produces all kinds of worldly and transmundane knowledge without itself increasing or decreasing. This is the second characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ gling chen po bzhi dang / gling phran bye ba brgya phrag brgyad cu dag ni/ rgya mtsho chen pos mngon par spangs pa'i phyir/ gang dang gang du sa'i khams bshong ba de dang de nas chu 'byung ste/ rgya mtsho chen po la rnam par rtog pa med do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du sems can thams cad kyi sems dang bsam pa yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyis mngon par brlan pas/ de dag dmigs pa gang dang gang la rnam par dpyod cing / chos kyi sgo gang dang gang la brtson par byed pa de dang de nas ye shes kyi snang ba 'byung ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rgya mtsho chen po de ni snyoms shing rnam par mi rtog la/ rim par 'byed pa mi mdzad kyang bsam pa dang sbyor ba'i khyad par gyis de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes snang ba'i khyad par du 'gyur ba'ang yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo gsum pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Just as the ocean water flows under the continents and islands, so that all who drill for water find it, yet the ocean does not form any notion of itself giving out water, in the same way the water of the ocean of knowledge of Buddha flows into the minds of all sentient beings, so that if they examine things and practice ways of entering truth they will find knowledge, pure and clear, with lucid understanding—yet the knowledge of Buddha is equal, nondual, without discrimination; but according to the differences in sentient beings’ mental patterns, the knowledge they obtain is not the same. This is the third characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus,

kye rgyal ba'i sras; gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ nor bu rin po che chen po yon tan tshad med pa phun sum tshogs pa bzhi yod de/ nor bu rin po che de dag gi gzi brjid dang mthus rgya mtsho chen por rin po che thams cad 'byung ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gal te rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ nor bu rin po che de bzhin med du zin na ni/ rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ nor bu rin po che gcig kyang yod par mi 'gyur ro/ /bzhi po de dag kyang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ rin po che thams cad yang dag par sdud pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che chen po dang / mi zad pa'i mdzod ces bya ba'i nor bu rin po che chen po dang / snying blas med pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che chen po dang / rgyan thams cad yang dag par sdud pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che chen po ste/ nor bu rin po che tshad med pa'i yon tan phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa de bzhi yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras / nor bu rin po che chen po bzhi po de dag ni bsod nams ngan ngon dang ldan pa'i lha ma yin nam/ nam mkha' lding ngam/ klu'am/ de ma yin pa'i sems can chu la gnas pa'i mig gis mthong bar mi 'gyur ro/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ nor bu rin po che chen po de bzhin ni/ klu'i rgyal po gangs chen mtsho'i mdzod na 'khod pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /rin po che chen po bzhi po de dag ni gru bzhir 'dug pa ste/ klu'i rgyal po gangs chen mtsho'i gnas kyi phyogs bzhir bkod pa dag go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ ye shes kyi rin po che chen po bsod nams dang / ye shes dang / yon tan phun sum tshogs pa bzhi yod de/ ye shes rin po che chen po de dag gi brjid dang mthus de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rgya mtsho chen po'i nang nas/ slob pa dang / mi slob pa thams cad dang / rang sangs rgyas thams cad dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi ye shes rin po che 'byung ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gal te de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rgya mtsho chen po'i nang nas ye shes rin po che chen po de bzhi med du zin na ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ chung ngu na byang chub sems dpa' gcig gi ye shes rin po che yang 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ /bzhi po de dag kyang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ thabs mkhas pa chags pa med pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / 'dus byas dang / 'dus ma byas su mnyam pa'i chos rab tu rtog pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / chos kyi dbyings tha mi dad kyang rnam pa tha dad du shin tu ston pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / dus dang dus ma yin pa las mi 'da' zhing / dus phebs par byed pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po de bzhi yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /ye shes rin po che chen po bzhi po de dag ni/ sems can bsod nams ngan don dang ldan pa rnams kyi mig gis mthong bar mi 'gyur te/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ ye shes rin po che chen po de bzhi ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi mdzod na 'khod pa'i phyir te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ye shes rin po che chen po bzhi po de dag ni rnam pa kun tu bzang po ste; phyogs bzhir rnam par bkod cing / byang chub sems dpa' nye bar 'tsho ba dang / byang chub sems dpa'i ye shes snang bas 'thob pa dag ste/ phyogs bzhir byang chub sems dpa' yang dag par bsgrub pa'i phyir rnam par bkod pa dag go / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo bzhi pa 'dis kyang byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“In the ocean there are four jewels imbued with infinite qualities that produce all the precious jewels in the ocean; if these jewels were not in the ocean, it would be impossible to find even one jewel. What are these four? One is called accumulation of treasures; another is called inexhaustible treasury; another is called removal of burning heat; the other is called replete with adornments. These jewels cannot be seen by any ordinary people or sea creatures. Why? The king water spirit Ocean, because the jewels are magnificent with perfect lines and proportions, keeps them in a deeply hidden place within the palace.
“The great ocean of knowledge of Buddha similarly has four great jewels of knowledge, with infinite qualities of knowledge and virtue, whereby are produced all the jewels of knowledge of the stages of learning and beyond learning of ordinary people, Buddhist followers, and individual illuminates, and of enlightening beings. What are the four? They are the jewel of great knowledge of unattached skill in means; the jewel of great knowledge of skillfully distinguishing the conditioned and the unconditioned; the jewel of great knowledge analytically explaining countless things without violating the essential nature of things; and the jewel of great knowledge knowing appropriate and inappropriate timing without ever a miss. If these four jewels were not in the Buddha’s ocean of knowledge, not a single being would ever be able to enter the Great Vehicle of liberation. These four jewels of knowledge cannot be seen by unworthy beings. Why? Because they are kept in the deeply secret treasury of Buddha. These four jewels of knowledge are even, symmetrical, straight and true, immaculately beautiful, and able to universally benefit all enlightening beings, enabling them to attain the light of knowledge. This is the fourth characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ rgya mtsho de nyid kyi 'og na nor bu rin po che chen po drag shul gyi gzi brjid dang ldan pa mthu shin tu che ba bzhi yod de/ nor bu rin po che chen po de dag gi gzi brjid dang mthus rgya mtsho chen por blugs pa'i chu'i phung po thams cad yongs su 'grib par 'gyur te/ de yod pas rgya mtsho chen po yang 'phel ba dang / 'grib par mi 'gyur ro/ /nor bu rin po che chen po de bzhi ni rgya mtsho chen po'i 'og gi mtshams na gnas te/ bzhi gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ nyi ma'i snying po zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che dang / rlan med pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che dang / mi'i 'od ces bya ba'i nor bu rin po che dang / ma lus pa'i mthar thug pa zhes bya ba'i nor bu rin po che dag ste/ nor bu rin po che chen po de bzhi yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras; gal te rgya mtsho che chen po la nor bu rin po che chen po de bzhi med du zin na ni/ gling chen po bzhi pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyang gcig tu chus yongs su rgyas par 'gyur te/ khor yug dang khor yug chen po'i ri las kyang 'das shing / chu'i phung pos srid pa'i rtse mo man chad du'ang gang bar 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ rgya mtsho chen por 'dus pa'i chu'i phung po de dag kyang nor bu rin po che nyi ma'i snying po'i 'od gyis phog na/ chu'i rang bzhin spangs nas 'o ma dang zhor gyur te 'dug go /nor bu rin po che chen po rlan med pa'i 'od kyis phog na/ 'o ma dang zho'i rang bzhin spangs nas/ mar gyi snying khu lta bur 'gyur ro/ /me'i 'od kyi nor bu rin po che chen po'i 'od kyis phog na/ mar gyi snying khu lta bu'i rang bzhin spangs te/ me lta bur 'bar bar 'gyur ro/ /nor bu rin po che chen po ma lus pa'i mthar thug pa'i 'od kyis phog na/ thams cad lhag ma med cing ma lus pa mi snang bar 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes kyi rgya mtsho chen po la/ ye shes rin po che chen po mthu dang 'od shin tu che ba bzhi yod de/ ye shes rin po che chen po de bzhi'i mthu dang 'od kyis ma phog na/ byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam gyi bsam pas byung ba'i bsod nams kyi chu'i phung po yongs su 'grib par 'gyur te/ de dag yod pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi rgya mtsho chen po gang ba dang / 'grib par mi mngon no/ /bzhi po de dag kyang gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ dba' rlabs thams cad zhi bar byed pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / chos kyi rjes su 'brang zhing sred pa yongs su dag par byed pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / shes rab kyi 'od chen pos shin tu snang ba'i ye shes rin po che chen po dang / mun pa med cing snang ba med pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes rin po che chen po ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rin po che mthu dang / gzi brjid shin tu che ba 'di bzhi yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po 'di bzhi'i gzi brjid dang mthus byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes mnyam pa nyid 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi rgya mtsho chen po de la/ byang chub sems dpa' bsod nams dang / byang chub kyi tshogs chen po bsags pa rnams kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i dba' rlabs kyi shugs drag po lha dang mi dang lha ma yin gyi 'jig rten du bcas pas/ mi zlog cing bsam gyis mi khyab pa ldang ste/ byang chub sems dpa' dge ba'i rtsa ba'i dba' rlabs kyi shugs bsam gyis mi khyab pa de dag la de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po dba' rlabs thams cad zhi bar byed pa'i 'od kyis phog na/ dge ba'i rtsa ba'i dba' rlabs kyi shugs drag po spangs nas ting nge 'dzin la rtse gcig tu gnas par 'gyur ro/ /chos kyi rjes su 'brang zhing sred pa zad par byed pa'i ye shes rin po che chen po'i 'od kyis phog na/ ting nge 'dzin gyi ro dang / gnas rnam par spangs te/ mngon par shes pa rgya chen po mngon par bsgrub pa'i tshul la gnas par 'gyur ro/ /shes rab kyi 'od chen pos shin tu snang ba'i ye shes rin po che chen po'i 'od kyis phog na/ mngon par shes pa rgya chen po mngon par bsgrub pa'i tshul rnam par spangs te/ rig pa'i snang ba chen po mngon par bsgrub pa'i tshul la gnas par 'gyur ro/ /mun pa med cing snang ba med pa de bzhin gshegs pa'i mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes rin po che chen po'i 'od kyis phog na/ rig pa'i snang ba chen po mngon par bsgrub pa'i tshul rnam par spangs te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sa mnyam pa nyid ched du bya ba yongs su zhi ba 'phrin las lhun gyis grub par 'byung ba rab tu thob bo/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ye shes rin po che chen po 'di bzhi'i 'od snang bas phog pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mnyam pa nyid bzhi po de dag 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gal te de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi rgya mtsho chen po'i nang na/ ye shes rin po che chen po 'di bzhi med du zin na/ chung ngu na byang chub sems dpa' gcig gis kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i sa mnyam pa nyid 'thob par 'gyur ba'i gnas med/ skabs med de/ de ni gnas ma yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo lnga pa 'dis kyang / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Also, the ocean has four jewels of blazing light spread on its floor, which by nature are extremely, fiercely hot; they are able to drink up and shrink the immeasurable quantities of water poured in by all the rivers, so that the ocean neither increases nor decreases. What are these four? One is called solar matrix; the second is called removing moisture; the third is called flame light, the fourth is called thorough exhaustion. If these four jewels were not in the ocean, the whole world, up to the highest heaven of material existence, would all be flooded. The light of this great jewel solar matrix, when it shines on seawater, turns it to milk; the light of the great jewel removing moisture, when it shines on the milk, turns it to cream; the light of the great jewel flame light, when it shines on the cream, turns it to butter; the light of the great jewel thorough exhaustion, when it shines on the butter, turns it to ghee, blazing like fire, consuming it without remainder.
“Buddha’s ocean of great knowledge similarly has four kinds of jewels of great knowledge, with light of immeasurable power; when the light of these jewels of knowledge touches enlightening beings, it ultimately causes them to attain the great knowledge of Buddha. What are the four? They are the jewel of great knowledge stopping all the waves of scattered goodness; the jewel of great knowledge eliminating all emotional attachment to the teachings; the jewel of great knowledge of the universal illumination of the light of intelligence; the jewel of great knowledge of boundless effortlessness equal to Buddha.
“When enlightening beings practice the methods of fostering enlightenment, they rouse innumerable waves of scattered goodness, which all worldly beings, celestials, humans, or titans cannot destroy; when Buddha touches those enlightening beings with the light of the jewel of great knowledge of stopping all the waves of scattered good, it causes them to leave behind the waves of scattered good, keep their minds on one point, and dwell in concentration. Then, touching the enlightening beings with the light of the jewel of great knowledge, removing all emotional attachment to the teachings, causes them to give up clinging to the taste of concentration and awaken great spiritual powers. Then, touching the enlightening beings with the light of the jewel of great knowledge of the universal intelligence causes them to relinquish the occult powers they exercise and to engage in the active employment of great science. Then, touching the enlightening beings with the light of the jewel of great knowledge of boundless effortlessness equal to Buddha causes them to relinquish the active exercise of great science they have been engaged in so that they finally reach the equanimity of Buddhas and cease all effort completely. Without the contact of the great light of these four jewels of knowledge of Buddha it would be impossible for a single enlightening being to attain buddhahood. This is the fifth characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ 'og gi chu'i phung po nye bar bzung ba yan chad/ 'du shes med 'du shes med min gyi skye mched kyi srid pa'i rtse mo'i bar gyi stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad nam mkha' la gnas pa ste/ gzugs med pa la spyod pa'i sems can gyi gnas dang / gzugs la spyod pa'i sems can gyi gnas dang / 'dod pa la spyod pa'i sems can gyi gnas ji snyed pa de dag thams cad nam mkha' la gnas shing nam mkha'i dbyings las byung ba'o/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyis thams cad du khyab pa'i phyir te/ nam mkha' la gnod pa'am/ mi bde bar 'gyur ba med kyang / khams gsum du 'grub pa'i grangs su'ang 'gro'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du phyogs bcu'i 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa ma lus pa dag na nyan thos kyi ye shes sam/ rang sangs rgyas kyi ye shes sam/ byang chub sems dpa'i ye shes sam/ 'dus byas la spyod pa'i ye shes sam/ 'dus ma byas la spyod pa'i ye shes gang ji snyed pa de dag thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi nam mkha' la gnas shing / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes nam mkha' las byung ba'o/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi nam mkha'i dbyings kyis kun tu khyab pa'i phyir te/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la gnod pa'am/ mi bde bar 'gyur ba med kyang / ye shes yang dag par 'grub pa rnam pa tha dad par 'gyur ba'ang yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo drug pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen po de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“The million lands from the sphere of water up to the heaven of neither perception nor nonperception, the abodes of sentient beings in the realm of desire, the realm of form, and the formless realm, all arise from space and rest in space. Why? Because space is everywhere. But though space contains all the realms of desire, form, and formlessness, yet it has no discrimination. The knowledge of Buddha is also like this: the knowledge of listeners, the knowledge of individual illuminates, the knowledge of enlightening beings, the knowledge of formulated practices, and the knowledge of unformulated practices, all arise from the knowledge of Buddha and rest in the knowledge of Buddha, because the knowledge of Buddha pervades all; though it contains innumerable knowledges, it has no discrimination. This is the sixth characteristic of the knowledge of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ ri'i rgyal po kha ba dang ldan pa'i rtse mo la sman gyi rgyal po rtsa ba ma grags pa zhes bya ba yod de/ de ni sa chen po'i 'og rdo rje'i dbyings kyi chu'i phung po'i gzhi'i gting nas/ dpag chad [*tshad?] brgya stong phrag drug cu rtsa brgyad mngon par brtol te/ gyen du byung bas rtsa ba shin tu brtan pa'o/ /sman gyi rgyal po chen po de'i rtsa ba'i 'od las 'dzam bu'i gling na yod pa'i shing thams cad kyi rtsa ba chags par 'gyur te/ sdong po'i 'od kyis sdong po chags par 'gyur ro/ /yal ga'i 'od kyis yal ga chags par 'gyur ro/ /lo ma'i 'od kyis lo ma chags par 'gyur ro/ /me tog gi 'od kyis me tog chags par 'gyur ro/ /'bras bu'i 'od kyis 'bras bu chags par 'gyur ro/ /sman gyi rgyal po chen po de'i rtsa ba las snying po 'grub bo/ /snying po las rtsa ba 'grub bo/ /de'i phyir na rtsa ba ma grugs pa zhes bya ste/ sman gyi rgyal po chen po de ni gnas rnam pa gnyis su mi skye ste/ gnyis gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ sems can dmyal ba'i nang dang chu'i phung po las mi skye'o/ /de gnyis las mi skye zhes yongs su mi skye ba'i chos can yang ma yin te/ 'di ltar sa'i dkyil 'khor ji tsam du mnyam zhing skabs yod pa de tsam du sman gyi rgyal po chen po skye ba'i skabs yod do/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin du de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po rtsa ba ma grugs pa yang sngon gyi lhag pa'i dgongs pa dang / thugs rje chen pos rtsa ba brtan par byung zhing / rtsa ba gnas pa med pa de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rigs su byung ba/ dus gsum gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyis ye shes kyi shing yang dag par 'grub pa/ 'jig rten gyi khams ma lus pa thams cad du dge ba'i rtsa bas kun tu khyab pa/ ngan song thams cad rnam par zlog pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par byung ba/ thabs mkhas pas brtan zhing sra la mi g.yo ba'i sdong po can/ pha rol tu phyin pas chos kyi dbyings rgyas par 'gengs pa'i yal ga can/ bsam gtan dang / rnam par thar pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang snyoms par 'jug pa'i lo ma kun tu 'gebs pa can gzungs dang / spobs pa dang / byang chub kyi yan lag gi me tog shin tu rgyas pa can thams cad mkhyen pa'i rnam par grol ba rtog pa dang bral ba'i 'bras bu can te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po rtsa ba ma grugs pa zhes bya ba de la/ ci'i phyir rtsa ba ma grugs pa zhes bya zhe na/ shin tu rgyun chad pa med pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa'i dkyil 'khor rgyun mi 'chad cing / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa las kyang de bzhin gshegs pa nyid du 'gyur la/ de bzhin gshegs pa nyid las kyang byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa 'byung bas/ de'i phyir rtsa ba ma grugs pa zhes bya ba'o/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po rtsa ba ma grugs pa de'i rtsa ba'i 'od las/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad 'gro ba thams cad yongs su mi gtong ba'i snying rje chen po'i rtsa ba 'dzin to/ /sdong po'i 'od las brtson 'grus dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa dang / thabs mkhas pa'i sdong po 'dzin to/ /yal ga'i 'od las pha rol tu phyin pa'i yal ga 'dzin to/ /lo ma'i 'od las tshul khrims dang / bslab pa dang / sbyangs pa'i yon tan dang / sdom pa thams cad kyi lo ma 'dzin to/ /me tog gi 'od las mtshan dang dpe byad bzang po dge ba'i rtsa ba sna tshogs kyis grub pa'i me tog 'dzin to/ /'bras bu'i 'od las ma skyes ma byung ba'i bzod pa nas/ sangs rgyas su dbang bskur ba'i sa'i bar gyi 'bras bu 'dzin to/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po rtsa ba ma grugs pa de ni gnas gnyis nas mi skye ste/ gnyis gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ 'dus ma byas kyi g.yang du lhung ba nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas rnams dang / dbang po dang bsam pa nyams pa'i snod lta bu dang / sred pa'i chus gang pa las mi skye ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po de mi skye ba'i chos can la mi skye zhes yongs su mi skye ba'i chos can yang ma yin te/ byang chub sems dpa' lhag pa'i bsam pa chen po can/ mnyam pa'i sems dang ldan pa rnams la skye ste/ ji tsam du sems can rnams kyi mos pa dang / lhag pa'i bsam pa yod pa de tsam du de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes sman gyi rgyal po chen po de rnam par skye ba'i chos can du 'gyur ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ltos dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes la 'phel zhing 'grib pa med la/ rtsa ba grug pa med kyang gtan du rgyun mi 'chad par snang ba yin te/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo bdun pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“Atop the Snowy mountains there is an excellent medicinal tree called inexhaustible roots; the roots of that medicinal tree grow from 168,000 leagues, all the way down to the adamantine ground and the sphere of water. When that medicinal tree grows roots, it causes the roots of all trees on the continent to grow; when the medicinal tree grows a stem, it causes the stems of all trees on the continent to grow. The same is true of the branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits. The roots of the medicinal tree can grow stems, and the stems can grow roots the roots are inexhaustible, so it is called inexhaustible roots. That medicinal tree can foster growth everywhere, except for two places where it cannot perform the beneficial action of promotion of growth—that is, in the pits of hells and in the sphere of water; yet it has no aversion to them. The great tree of the supreme medicine of the knowledge of Buddha, likewise, by past development, fully perfects all good qualities of knowledge, shades all realms of sentient beings, and destroys all the miseries of bad states. Universal compassion and commitment form its roots; it is born from the seed of true knowledge of all buddhas. It is steadfast and immovable; skill in means is its trunk, the transcendent perfections of cosmic knowledge are its branches; meditations, liberations, and the great concentrations are its leaves; mental command, intellectual skills, and the elements of enlightenment are its flowers, and the ultimate unchanging liberation of buddhas is its fruit. Why may the medicinal tree of knowledge of Buddha be called ‘inexhaustible roots’? Because of ultimately never ceasing, because of not stopping enlightening activity. The practice of enlightening beings is the nature of Buddha, the nature of Buddha is the practice of enlightening beings. Therefore it can be called inexhaustible roots. When the roots of the medicinal tree of buddha-knowledge grow, it causes enlightening beings to grow the root of great love and compassion, which does not abandon sentient beings. When its trunk grows, it causes all sentient beings to grow the trunk of profound determination with steadfast vigor. When its branches grow, it causes all enlightening beings to grow the branches of all transcendent ways. When its leaves grow, it causes enlightening beings to grow the leaves of pure conduct, austerity, virtue, paucity of desire, and contentment. When its flowers grow, it causes all enlightening beings to be replete with the flowers of magnificent arrays of the marks and embellishments of virtues. When its fruit grows, it causes all enlightening beings to gain the fruits of acceptance of nonorigination up to acceptance of coronation by all buddhas. The supreme medicine tree of knowledge of Buddha cannot perform its beneficial growth-fostering function in two places only: in those in the two vehicles of individual salvation who have fallen into the abyss of nondoing, and in unsuitable sentient beings with rotten roots of goodness who are sunk in the floodwaters of erroneous views and craving—yet Buddha never has rejected these people. The knowledge of Buddha has no increase or decrease, because its roots are stable and grow ceaselessly. This is the seventh characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.

kye rgyal ba'i sras/ gzhan yang 'di lta ste/ dper na/ mes 'jig pa'i bskal pa byung ba'i tshe/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams nyi ma bdun shar cing / 'tshig pa dang / 'bar ba dang / rab tu 'bar ba dang / me'i phung po chen por gyur te/ gcig tu 'bar bar gyur nas/ rtswa dang / gel ba dang / sman dang / nags tshal yan chad khor yug dang khor yug chen po'i bar du 'tshig cing thal ba'ang mi mngon par 'gyur ba de'i tshe/ /mi la la zhig gis skam po dud pa rlan gyi bag med pa khur chen po gcig cig bkur bkur te bcug na/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de la ji snyam du sems/ rtsa khur gcig po de las chung ngu na zegs pa gcig kyang ma tshig pa yod dam/ smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ma yin te/ ma tshig pa yod par 'gyur ba ni gnas med/ skabs med do/ /smras pa/ kye rgyal ba'i sras; me'i phung po chen po de'i nang gi zegs ma 'ga' zhig ma tshig pa ni yod kyang srid kyi/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyis ni dus gsum na yod pa'i sems can 'grangs pa dang / zhing 'grangs pa dang / bskal pa 'grangs pa dang / chos 'grangs pa gang yang thugs su ma chud pa rnyed par mi rung ste/ de ni gnas ma yin no/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ci'i phyir zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyis tha mi dad pa'i ye shes thugs su chud pa'i phyir ro/ / kye rgyal ba'i sras/ khong du chud par bya ba'i sgo brgyad pa 'dis kyang / byang chub sems dpa' sems dpa' chen pos de bzhin gshegs pa'i thugs skye ba khong du chud par bya'o/ /

“When the eonic holocaust starts in the universe, it burns up all the plants and trees, and even the mountains, consuming all without leaving anything. Suppose someone picked up some dry straw and threw it in that fire—do you think it could do aught but burn?”
“No.”
“It is more possible for that straw not to burn than for Buddha’s knowledge, analyzing all sentient beings, all lands, all ages, and all phenomena of all times, not to know something. Why? Because that knowledge impartially comprehends all clearly. This is the eighth characteristic of the mind of Buddha; great enlightening beings should know it thus.
